article_title: Adventures in a Forgotten Country
text:
Published 1975. Author, Kerima Polotan. With an introduction by Edith Tiempo and illustrations by Dani Reyes. Manila: Alemar-Phoenix Publishing House. Reprinted, Manila: Focus Philippines Publishing Co., 1977; Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1999.

Polotan’s sharp perception of Philippine society, succinct prose, and mastery of the act of storytelling are visible in both her fiction and nonfiction. According to Edith L. Tiempo’s introduction, the 35 pieces that make up this collection were written for journalistic purposes—many had appeared in the martial law-era Focus magazine—but they “summon the wry and haunting evocations of the personal essay.”

In the first section, “Adventures in a Forgotten Country,” Polotan reflects on nostalgia, journeying, and encountering new faces across the country. Details from trips to provinces—the landscape, the characters on the bus rides, and the changes wrought by trends in politics and society—are carefully remembered and pondered on in “The View from Here” and “To Baguio and Back.” The physical and personal journeying begins from the airport in “Palawan Stopover,” a survey of the everyday life of the island, and in “Commuter,” where she describes flight schedules, fellow passengers, and sights upon landing in Cebu. The title essay “Adventures in a Forgotten Country” combines revelation and detailed description of Polotan’s travels in Cebu, where she bids farewell to a dying man in Perpetual Succor Hospital, Tacloban, where she challenges a friend about the changes in Philippine culture; and Cagayan de Oro, where she ties together two ends of life when she meets a proud dollar dealer and a poor but dignified young shoemaker.

The second section, “Notes on Domesticity and Other Exotica,” opens with the “The Wives”: Berta from Luzon, Benita from the Visayas, and Marie from Mindanao share their struggles, their past bleak and the futures for themselves and for their families unclear. In depicting her own wedding (“Anniversary”) and an affair (“A Man and a Woman”), Polotan is gentle and introspective. The title essay is about Polotan’s mother-in-law and Polotan’s daughter, a generation of goats in her property, and a failed attempt to mate two pet birds. The section ends with “After the Season,” expressing Polotan’s insights into the commercial culture of Christmas and leaving readers to ask, what remains of the value of gift-giving in the home?

The essays in the third section, “Derelict Thoughts between Coming and Going,” contain Polotan’s signature commentary on Philippine politics, the nouveau riche and socialites, and an increasingly commercialized culture: “The Government Paunch,” “The Bureaucratic Character,” “The Public Servant as a Fashion Plate,” “A Country Full of Experts,” and “Philippine Society in Motion.” The vignettes in “Derelict Thoughts between Coming and Going”—about a trip to Cebu City to observe the Ganzon trial, survey the Opon-Mandaue bridge, and explore the district of Fuente Osmeña—pave the way for Polotan’s self-revelation of her place in the martial law era, a difficult time in Philippine history.

The last section, titled “The Hills of Vermont,” documents Polotan’s transnational journeys and her encounters with Filipinos and foreigners. In “Filipinos in America” and “The Midwife from Pampanga,” questions on the trend of immigration are interwoven with poignant personal encounters. This section’s title essay, “The Hills of Vermont,” is Polotan’s humorous account of her experiences at a writers’ conference; and “Travel Notes: New Delhi” and “Persepolis without the Trimmings” are vignettes of trips where Polotan served as First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos’s companion.

Of Polotan’s craft and contribution to Philippine society through literature, Tiempo states: “For this kind of writing which blends reminiscence, comment, and tart philosophy, one would be hard put to find Kerima Polotan’s peer in this country.”  Written by Maria Amparo Warren

article_title: Agaw-Dilim, Agaw-Liwanag
text:
(Dusk, Dawn). Published 2009. Author, Lualhati Milan Abreu. Quezon City: University of the Philippines (UP) Press. With forewords by the author and Ramon Guillermo. Gawad Likhaan: The UP Centennial Literary Prize for creative nonfiction in Filipino, 2008; Madrigal-Gonzalez Best First Book Award, 2010.

This autobiography tells how Abreu matured from a curious youth activist to a full-fledged revolutionary cadre, culminating in what she calls the “nightmare” of 1988, when over a hundred cadres suspected of being military infiltrators were tortured and killed in an operation called “Oplan Missing Link” (OPML). In the prologue, “Boots” orders Abreu to write down how she allegedly became a deep penetration agent. Instead, she tells her readers how she became an active member of the revolutionary movement.

Abreu’s revolutionary roots can be traced to her mother or Nanay, whose father was a friend and supporter of the first Communist Party founded by Crisanto “Ka Anto” Evangelista. Through Ka Anto’s help, Nanay learns the principles of commerce at the marketplace. Abreu is heir to Nanay’s practical marketplace skills, which she uses in everyday life and in mass organizing and mobilizing. Abreu’s activist phase is formally realized when she joins the Student Cultural Association of the University of the Philippines (SCAUP). She later learns that her comrades-to-be suspect her of being a military intelligence unit because of her advanced knowledge of societal issues. The suspicion causes the delay of her SCAUP membership.

Abreu heeds the call of full-time activism as authorities arrest comrades and leaders. She endures a near-jail experience in rural Central Luzon, and she suffers the difficulties of managing the urban headquarters of the youth activist group Kabataang Makabayan.

Foreshadowing 1988, a certain comrade Karla is sentenced by a top-ranking party member to death without due process. Another chapter recounts how comrades in Davao city feel demoralized because of their leader’s unilateral decision making. The tyrannical ways of high-ranking leaders are narrated in the next chapters. They are depicted as gangsters that purge suspected “demons” who threaten their leadership.

“Liwanag sa Piitan” (Light in the Dungeon) recounts Abreu’s arrest in Davao, her detention in the Davao City Jail, a brief stay at Fort Bonifacio, eventual transfer to Camp Bagong Diwa in Bicutan, and her subsequent escape. While she resumes her propaganda work for the party, Abreu’s differences with the organization’s leaders on such matters as the rule against premarital sex and the 1986 snap elections persist. Most importantly, she objects to the torture of suspects during the execution of OPML.

The final chapters continue where the memoir’s prologue ends. Abreu is vindicated when top-level cadres argue over the correctness of OPML. Finally, in the chapter “Bangungot sa Katanghalian” (Nightmare at Noontime), she is released and welcomed by comrades chanting “Long Live the Communist Party of the Philippines” and singing “Internationale.” Abreu continues the struggle but now the military tries to convince her to cooperate with them. Despite being a victim of the excesses of little factions within the Communist movement that have cost the party considerable damage, Abreu expresses a sober optimism.

Abreu’s book clarifies certain issues about an important period in the history of the party and counters Bobby Garcia’s To Suffer Thy Comrades. The autobiography is commendable for its careful initiation of non-activists to the language and the values of the revolutionaries. It provides a moving, first-person account for the reader seeking to comprehend how a revolutionary movement rectifies itself in its attempt to fulfill its dream of a better world. A companion book is Cesar Lacara’s Sa Tungki ng Ilong ng Kaaway: Talambuhay ni Tatang (On the Tip of the Enemy’s Nose: Diary of Tatang).  Written by Arbeen Acuña

article_title: Albay Viejo
text:
(Old Albay). Published 2010. Author, Raffi Banzuela. Legazpi City: Aquinas University.

A collection of essays, historical narratives, and short stories on Albay, this book entertains, informs, and provokes many questions and reflections on the province and its people. Written in contemporary and elegant Bikol prose, the works are a remembrance of things past in Albay. The words “bihira na,” “bumagsak na,” and “wala na”recur in the essays, an indicator that too many things have disappeared in the region: history, story, and words.

Banzuela’s essays point out research areas in Bikol culture and language, such as whether the ancient Bikol verse called the tigsik was really used for subversive purposes during World War II. They also inquire into the discourse of names and power, such as a barangay in Rapu-Rapu called Manila; a town named after an oppressive Spanish official, Jovellar; a river called Yawa, a word that means devil; and the letter “h” in Albay Bikol when other varieties of Bikol have dropped it—for instance, harog/arog.

These areas of Bikol culture, the author says, are “not in particular circulation or are taken for granted by Albayanos and by scholars.” The essay “Albay Viejo,” the book’s central piece, uses the site of Peñaranda Park, the “navel” of old Albay, to chart the transformation not only of the space but “attitudes.” There are also “brief and measured” incursions in nearby places that had had an impact on the development of the greater old Albay district. The essay also makes use of documented historical events to explain the origin of the name “Albay.” In the end, though, he asserts that “the name has no legal leg to stand on but only a memory to hang on to.”

In form, Albay Viejo blurs the distinction between story and history, of folktale, short fiction, and essay in what could well be an indigenous Bikol narrative form. It preserves a rich trove of Bikol words long missing from everyday discourse for contemporary use. He expresses the hope that using the Albay variant of the Bikol language—“with all its ramifications”—will help develop a “truly regional Bikol language” that is not anchored in one standard but drawn from contributions from the many languages in the region.

Most of all, the publication of this book itself allays the Bicolnon’s fear that, in Banzuela’s own words, “Dai kiano man nanawalat. Maski istorya” (Nothing will be left. Not even stories).  Written by Paz Verdades Santos

 

Source

Banzuela, Raffi. 2010. “Albay Viejo: Notes from the Author.” Aquinas University of Legazpi. 9 Dec. http://www.aq.edu.ph/index.php?p=main&s=feature&taskId=article&id=265.

article_title: Ang Apat na Himagsik ni Francisco Balagtas
text:
(The Four Revolts of Francisco Balagtas). Published 1955. Author, Lope K. Santos. Monograph. Anthologized in Himalay: Kalipunan ng mga Pag-aaral kay Balagtas (Gleanings: Anthology of Studies on Balagtas), edited by Patricia Melendrez-Cruz and Apolonio Bayani Chua. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1988. According to the Himalay editors, an earlier edition seems to have been printed that reached a wider audience, but data are not available.

This study is one of the interpretations that have been canonized in the body of criticism of the awit (metrical romance) Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), ca 1838. Like the pioneering work of Hermenegildo Cruz, Kun Sino ang Kumatha ng “Florante” (On Who Authored Florante), 1906, it argues that Francisco "Balagtas" Baltzar’s poem could be read as a political text, specifically as a passionate indictment of the Spanish colonial regime.

Santos focuses on how Balagtas’s work manifested its subversive quality in four different ways. First, the very choice of materials explored was revolutionary. Balagtas was not weaving a simple narrative that featured the conflict between Christians and Moors; he was producing a text that actually described the people’s plight in the hands of the Spaniards. Albania was the Philippines, and Conde Adolfo was the symbol of the wicked usurper. By referring to particular lines, Santos reinforces his political reading of the poem. The poem’s subversive quality is also manifested in its exposition of the injustices perpetrated by the Catholic Church. Balagtas paints the Muslim characters in a positive light. Moreover, he did not dedicate his work to the Virgin Mary as other awit writers were wont to do, but to Celia, an earthly beloved. The third revolt lies in the social critique that Balagtas expounded. Santos adds that Jose Rizal later deepened the same theme of social cancer as would Andres Bonifacio in his Kartilya (Primer). Finally, Santos argues that the poet must be perceived not only as a Tagalog writer but also as a national poet whose work stirred the passions and emotions of countless readers, including such heroes as Rizal and Bonifacio.

The desire to affirm the centrality of Balagtas’s role as an authentic hero is the rationale for Santos’s relatively lengthy analysis. This study is notable for its use of the historical, sociological, and moral approaches, which by the 1950s had become the more established modes of criticism.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: The Authentic Voice of Poetry
text:
Published 1962. Author, Ricaredo Demetillo. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This book is a collection of critical essays on poetry in general, including Philippine poetry in English. Demetillo employs the method of New Criticism, which involves close reading, with special attention to lexical, grammatical, and phonetic analysis. The poems he analyzes include the sonnets of William Shakespeare, the English and Scottish ballads, the poems of John Donne, and the odes of John Keats. Demetillo also discusses works by French poets like Arthur Rimbaud and Paul Valery, works by American poets like Robert Frost and Emily Dickinson, and works by the Indian writer Rabindranath Tagore.

The last six essays in his book deal with Philippine poetry in English. His aim in his discussion of Philippine poetry is explicit: he believes that “a close analysis of these poems [in Six Filipino Poets], especially in their use of linguistic means to achieve meaning, will be helpful in understanding the achievements so far of Philippine poets.” The critical approach is “close analysis”; the critical object is language.

Demetillo evaluates poems as good or bad on the basis of the poetic qualities extolled by New Criticism. The few “realized poems” are lined up against the many “fractured and halting verses.” The New Critical orientation is evident in Demetillo’s reading of Carlos Angeles’s “Storm Warning.” After faulting the first line of the poem for being “abrupt,” he praises Angeles’s use of disparate elements. He focuses on the symbols and notices the “objective correlatives” in the poem. Among the other Filipino writers he critiques are Jose Garcia Villa, Nick Joaquin, Bienvenido Santos, and Alejandrino Hufana.   Written by Isagani R. Cruz

article_title: Author's Choice: Selected Writings of Kerima Polotan
text:
Published 1971. Author, Kerima Polotan. Parañaque: Bustamante Press Inc. Reprinted, Manila: Focus Philippines Publishing Co., 1980; Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1998.

This is a compilation of 42 essays, originally published in the Philippines Free Press in 1964-70, by Polotan, covering politics, the dichotomy between the city and the country, human relationships, and relevant cultural trends.

Polotan mostly takes a satirical approach to the political culture of the 1960s in the section titled “Politics and People.” She vividly describes familiar politicos and their personal idiosyncrasies in “Professional Bright Boys,” about governors and their public relations teams, and in “The Chorus around Imelda,” about the former First Lady and her entourage of aspiring politicians. Memorable events in the presidential election of 1965, such as the candidates’ assembly (“The LP Show at Plaza Miranda”) and the frantic vote-counting and media reportage of the candidates’ and political parties’ success (“The Uneasy Hours”), are narrated with dry wit. Polotan lays bare the atmosphere in both chambers of the legislature in “Now Showing: Congress” and “Now Showing: The Senate.” Polotan takes on a more somber tone, however, in discussing political tragedies, such as that in “‘Tatang’ and the Lapiang Malaya” and “The Widows of Balutu.”

The section titled “Town and Country” contains Polotan’s sketches of prominent personalities in Philippine society, such as the nouveau riche in “The Ways of the Rich” and the title-seeking socialites and top-tier professionals in “Call Me Mister!” Polotan critiques the rise of a new breed of the Filipino man in “Death of the Gentleman.” She also explores unique cultural landscapes in “The Rise and Fall of Pasay,” “Letters from Bacolod,” “Letter to New York,” and “Remembering Saigon” and tells of her personal love of adventure and escape in “Road Trip Ticket to Nowhere.” She describes the features of various ethnic groups in “The Bicolana,” “Success Comes to the Ilocano,” and “Small Town Filipinos.”

The section “Sex, Love, and Fashion” unravels the workings of modern-day relationships, whether early romance in “The Trappings of Love,” or marriage and family in “Marriage—Philippine Style,” “Love and Passion,” and “The Man with a French Wife.” In other essays in this section, Polotan gives commentaries on modern-day women, the widening range of ideas on the nature and expressions of female sexuality, and cultural trends as manifested in fashion. “Sex in Advertising” is about the rise of sexualized mass media and marketing, and “Under the Dryer,” about the Filipino fixation with beauty.

The section “Hearth and Home” consists of memoir pieces. In “Memories,” Polotan recalls her childhood in her hometown of Tarlac, speaking of, among others, her father. She chronicles people in her neighborhood, such as a memorable acquaintance during the Japanese occupation, in “Irma”; and a neighboring family’s ordeals with the Social Security System, in “To Build a House.” She writes with both tender amusement about her children in “Bringing Up Pen Pals,” “There’s a Teenager in the House,” and “A House Full of Daughters,” and about the major concerns of the home—upbringing, education, and forming values—in “The Education of a Woman” and “School Opening Blues.”

Polotan’s essays contain the essence of the decade in which they were written. The collection is a testament to her skill in crafting clear, gripping works of prose.  Written by Maria Amparo Warren

This is a compilation of 42 essays, originally published in the Philippines Free Press in 1964-70, by Polotan, covering politics, the dichotomy between the city and the country, human relationships, and relevant cultural trends.

Polotan mostly takes a satirical approach to the political culture of the 1960s in the section titled “Politics and People.” She vividly describes familiar politicos and their personal idiosyncrasies in “Professional Bright Boys,” about governors and their public relations teams, and in “The Chorus around Imelda,” about the former First Lady and her entourage of aspiring politicians. Memorable events in the presidential election of 1965, such as the candidates’ assembly (“The LP Show at Plaza Miranda”) and the frantic vote-counting and media reportage of the candidates’ and political parties’ success (“The Uneasy Hours”), are narrated with dry wit. article_title: Aves de Rapia
text:
(Birds of Prey). Published 1908. Author, Fidel Reyes. El Renacimiento. English translation, “Birds of Prey” by Maria Kalaw-Katigbak in Aide-de-Camp to Freedom by Teodoro M. Kalaw. Manila: Teodoro M. Kalaw Society Inc, 1965.

This is an editorial that sought to expose the opportunism of American colonial officials and thus prompted a libel suit and a civil suit against El Renacimiento, filed by then commissioner of the interior Dean C. Worcester. He felt alluded to in the following extract from the editorial: “Hay hombres que ademas de ser aguilas, reunen en si las caracteristicas del buitre, del buho y del vampiro” (There are human beings, who, besides being like an eagle, also have the characteristics of the vulture, the owl, and the vampire bat).

The editorial enumerated the modus operandi of the “aves de rapiña.” They scale the Benguet mountains supposedly to civilize the Igorot, but, in truth, they go to locate hidden gold deposits, which they claim through legal machinations; they authorize the illegal slaughter of sick cattle to make a profit; they misrepresent themselves as scientists; they encourage the search for mines in Mindanao, Mindoro, and other places and promote the sale of worthless property to the city at fabulous prices. In sum, the bird of prey is an “aguila que sorprende y devora, buitre que se solaza en las carnes muertas y putreficas, buho que aparenta una omnisciencia petulante y vampiro que chupa en silencio la sangre de las victimas hasta dejarle exangue” (eagle that surprises first and then devours, a vulture that gorges itself on dead and putrid meat, an owl that affects a petulant omniscience, and a vampire bat that silently sucks its victim bloodless).

Convicted in the civil suit were the publisher Martin Ocampo, editor Teodoro M. Kalaw, and other editors, publishers, and stockholders of El Renacimiento. They were ordered to pay 60,000 pesos in damages, and the newspaper was ordered closed. There was an outcry at the decision, and even the American-owned the Philippines Free Press called for the ouster of Worcester. The general indignation poured out in satire and cartoons, and the phrase “aves de rapiña” soon entered the anticolonial vocabulary. Although Ocampo and Kalaw were pardoned upon the assumption of Gov-Gen Francis Burton Harrison, the point had been made: the colonial administration would brook no opposition.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson

article_title: Balagtas y Su Florante
text:
(Balagtas and His Florante). Published 1916. Author, Epifanio de los Santos. Philippine Review, Aug 1916. Included in the book “Florante”: Version Castellana del Poema Tagalo con un Ensayo Critico (Florante: Spanish Version of a Tagalog Poem with a Critical Essay), Manila: G. Nieva, 1916; and anthologized in Himalay: Kalipunan ng mga Pag-aaral kay Balagtas (Gleanings: Anthology of Studies on Balagtas), edited by Patricia Melendrez-Cruz and Apolonio Bayani Chua, Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1988.

This is a scholarly study of Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar’s masterpiece Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), ca 1838. It was a response to the author’s own concern for a more extensive study of the metrical romance, expressed in his critique of Hermenegildo Cruz’s book Kun Sino ang Kumatha ng “Florante” (On Who Authored Florante), 1906.

In his book, de los Santos analyzes the structure of the poem, the literary devices Balagtas used to avoid censorship, the public’s reception of the book, and the subsequent impact it had on later writers, notably Jose Rizal. De los Santos notes: “Asi el Menandro del poema no es el clasico Menandro … ni siquiera el ateniense Menandro, de Moratin, sino el precursor de Elias … Tambien la Laura del poema no es la de Petrarca … sino … la precursora de Maria Clara” (Thus the Menandro of the poem is not the classical Menandro … neither of Athens nor of Moratin; he is the precursor of Elias … Similarly, the Laura of the poem is not of Petrarch … but Maria Cara’s precursor).

Moreover, a linguistic analysis of the Hispanisms—that is, the Spanish words that entered Tagalog either with their original meaning intact or with modified meanings—is made, as are an analysis of the poem’s versification and a comparison of four conflicting versions of the poem that resulted from the absence of a definitive edition during Balagtas’s lifetime. Especially notable about de los Santos’s work are the musical annotations and the data about the actual singing of the poem. The book also contains a short biography of Balagtas, spiced with interesting anecdotes, and a history of Tagalog literature from 1593 to 1886, in which period de los Santos contextualizes Balagtas’s poem. He cautions students of Tagalog literature from being misled by the religious titles of books meant for studying the language. With the grammatical examples and the didacticism are data on folk customs and traditions.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson and Victoria S. Calizo

article_title: Balagtasismo versus Modernismo
text:
Published 1984. Author, Virgilio S. Almario. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This book is a critical study in Tagalog of two schools of Tagalog writing, balagtasismo and modernismo, as reactions to Americanization. Three basic aspects of the relationship between these two schools are scrutinized: the worldview, especially the extent of American influence on it; the basis of Philippine aesthetics; and the use of language.

Almario begins with a criticism of the lopsided and limited concerns of Western-influenced literary theory, which views the Balagtas tradition, or the indigenous elements persisting in Philippine literature, as an anachronism and a weakness of craft and imagination. Balagtasismo was a literary movement that looked up to the poet Balagtas, aka Francisco Baltazar, as the symbol of a pure Philippine culture. It sought to counteract American colonialism by clinging to the traditions of the pre-Spanish and Spanish colonial past. Its use of rhyme and meter was an expression of patriotism, whereas the use of free verse was deemed an act of treason. Balagtasismo reaffirmed the values of indigenous traditions, of Christianity, and the spirit of the propaganda and revolutionary movements. Thus, at this stage, the insistence on the glories of the past was a progressive stance.

The resistance movement, however, gradually began to stifle the new, emerging generation of Tagalog writers, who chafed at the restriction to poetic conventions. They complained that nationalistic themes had begun to be tainted with feudalism and chauvinism, that there was no realistic nor scientific analysis of the Philippine situation, that the use of the language was puristic, and that the use of imagery was being sacrificed for a rigid rhyme-and-meter scheme. As the Balagtas school became more and more insistent on the correctness of its beliefs, it became more didactic, abstract, stilted, and stagnant. What had once been the quintessence of political activism became reactionary. The clearest example of this phenomenon was the insistence on a puristic Pilipino, which, while symbolizing Filipino nationalism, was a dead and stultifying language. Patriotism became florid sentimentalism as American colonial culture began to take root. Modernismo then emerged as the new nationalistic movement when the style and themes of balagtasismo became obsolete. Its borrowings from and adaptations of Western sources were not a sign of colonial mentality; rather, they were practical, meaningful, and creative attempts at meeting the needs of the new Filipino sensibility.

Thus, the terms balagtasismo and modernismo, according to Almario, have undergone shifts in meaning in the course of history. What was revolutionary in one period soon became reactionary as the tides of Philippine history turned. Eventually, balagtasismo became bakya or popular mass literature. In the meantime, modernismo moved into the academe and, as such, alienated itself from the Filipino people because of its obscurity. However, it greatly contributed to the development of the Filipino language that was realistic and dynamic and which became the official language of youth activism as against the Pilipino being propagated by the Institute of National Language, which had become the bastion of balagtasismo.

In conclusion, Almario sees the beginning of a new era of Tagalog poetry, which is a synthesis of balagtasismo and modernismo. He suggests the need for a Filipino literary theory based on a “suspension of partisan politics” (as against the Western “suspension of disbelief”) and “political distance” (as against “aesthetic distance”), which should provide for the creation of poetry that is meant for mass readers and mass media outlets. Most importantly, this literary theory, he adds, should be based on a proper understanding of the place of balagtasismo in Philippine literary history.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Bamboo and the Greenwood Tree: Essays on Filipino Literature in English
text:
Published 1961. Author, Miguel Bernad, SJ. With an introduction by Alfred Sterling. Manila: Bookmark.

This book is a collection of 12 critical essays on Philippine fiction in English and on Philippine culture. Seven of the essays are critiques of the short story collections of Manuel Arguilla, Alejandro R. Roces, Bienvenido Santos, N. V. M.Gonzalez, Nick Joaquin, Gregorio Brillantes, and Aida Rivera-Ford. In his essay on Rivera, Bernad also touches on other women writers, including Edith Tiempo, Kerima Polotan-Tuvera, and Estrella Alfon. One essay is a commentary on Raul Manglapus and his book of speeches, Freedom, Nationhood and Culture. Another essay gives an overview of the state of contemporary Filipino theater by providing a list and description of plays written and anthologized, of theater groups then existing, and of college drama guilds that were contributing significantly to the theater scene. Three essays dwell on the Filipinos’ dilemma of being both Western and Asian in orientation. Bernad invariably offers one resolution, as stated in “Western Humanism and the Filipino”: that Filipinos “can be proud of being Asians and at the same time … of their western heritage, for they are the heirs of Greece and Rome as well as of China, India and Borneo.” The most anthologized essay in the collection is “Philippine Literature: Perpetually Inchoate.” It traces the causes of instability of Philippine literature to economic insecurity, to the lack of a broader cultural formation, and to linguisitic difficulties. The book also contains two very helpful appendices: appendix 1 contains a summary of literary awards and anthologies available at the time; and appendix 2 reprints in full N. V. M. Gonzalez’s and Gregorio Brillantes’s detailed explanation of their books.

Bernad is classicist in his approach to literature: that is, his assessment of the language and style of the literary works is based on the notion of decorum or appropriateness; and he examines the “truthfulness” of the events and characters in the text based on the concept of literature as mimesis or imitation of reality.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and David Jonathan Bayot

article_title: Banaag at Sikat: Metakritisismo at Antolohiya
text:
(Banaag at Sikat: Metacriticism and Anthology). Published 2010. Editor, Maria Luisa Torres Reyes. With an introduction to the editor by Bienvenido L. Lumbera and a foreword by the editor. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for literary criticism, 2011.

Lope K. Santos’s landmark novel Banaag at Sikat (Glimmer and Light) was first serialized in the newspaper Muling Pagsilang in 1904 and was published as a book in 1906. Since then, it has attracted debates among literary critics concerning its socialist theme and literary merits. This book commemorates the centennial of the novel’s publication by gathering 17 critical essays written on the novel over a span of almost eight decades, arranged chronologically.

Torres Reyes’s introduction, “Sa Pagitan ng Estetika at Etika” (Between Aesthetics and Ethics), demonstrates metacritical practice on several levels. It surveys and contextualizes the critical directions and trends that the anthologized essays represent. It examines how the novel has sparked debates on its form and content, noting that critics praised it for its unflinching exploration of social issues like labor exploitation and socialism while criticizing its literary elements, particularly the loose plot and long-winded dialogues. Finally, it analyzes how these modes of criticism are linked with the issues of nationhood and history.

The first 10 essays, originally published in Muling Pagsilang in 1907, are sharp and candid exchanges among Gabriel Beato Francisco (writing as A. ng L.), Manuel B. Francisco (writing as B. ng S.), and Godofredo Herrera. The critics debate on thematic issues like the compatibility of the novel’s prescribed socialism with the country’s social situation, and on more formal elements like the verisimilitude of specific plot situations in the novel.

Teodoro Agoncillo’s essay, “Ang Banaag at Sikat ni Lope K. Santos” (Lope K. Santos’s Banaag at Sikat), 1936, criticizes both the novel’s theme and form. He notes the author’s extensive borrowing of foreign ideals and the novel’s inconsistencies of characterization brought about by plot contrivances. He unfavorably compares the novel with Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, concluding that Santos’s novel is more propaganda than art.

Juan C. Laya’s “Ang Banaag at Sikat ni Lope K. Santos: Isang Pagpapaliwanag” (Lope K. Santos’s Banaag at Sikat: An Explanation), 1947, provides significant details on the author’s personal and intellectual history, citing possible sources of Santos’s radical ideas in the novel. Laya echoes earlier criticisms on the work’s lengthy digressions and offers suggestions for editing, though he recognizes the novel’s value in propagating socialist ideals. Romeo P. Virtusio’s “A Second Look at a Tagalog Classic,” 1966, offers a more positive assessment of the novel as a significant work of protest art. Vedasto Suarez’s “Don Lope K. Santos: Ang Banaag at Sikat ng Bagong Panahon” (Don Lope K. Santos: Banaag at Sikat of the New Era), 1969, emphasizes the novel’s link with protest movements formed across the chapters of the nation’s history.

Rogelio Mangahas’s “Ilang Silahis ng Banaag at Sikat” (Some Rays of Banaag at Sikat), 1970, highlights the novel’s merits, such as its ushering in of realism in Philippine literature; its use of humor, irony, and symbolic characterization; and its social relevance. He adds, however, that its weaknesses include verbosity and lack of subtlety. E. San Juan’s “Lope K. Santos: Critique of Individualism and Bourgeois Ideology,” 1971, focuses on the novel’s depiction of the roots and evils of socioeconomic exploitation in the country and its dramatization of social relations and norms that are founded on an elite-controlled social order.

Staying true to the official ideology of Ferdinand Marcos’s martial law, Gregorio C. Borlaza’s “Ang Banaag at Sikat at ang Bagong Pilipinas” (Banaag at Sikat and the New Philippines), 1979, claims that Marcos’s “New Society” program succeeded in fulfilling the novel’s vision of a country that can be free from exploitation without requiring socialist reform or revolution. It won first prize in the essay competition of the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa.  Written by Laurence Marvin Castillo

He notes the author’s extensive borrowing of foreign ideals and the novel’s inconsistencies of characterization brought about by plot contrivances. He unfavorably compares the novel with Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, concluding that Santos’s novel is more propaganda than art.

Juan C. Laya’s “Ang Banaag at Sikat ni Lope K. Santos: Isang Pagpapaliwanag” (Lope K. Santos’s Banaag at Sikat: An Explanation), 1947, provides significant details on the author’s personal and intellectual history, citing possible sources of Santos’s radical ideas in the novel. Laya echoes earlier criticisms on the work’s lengthy digressions and offers suggestions for editing, though he recognizes the novel’s value in propagating socialist ideals. Romeo P. Virtusio’s “A Second Look at a Tagalog Classic,” 1966, offers a more positive assessment of the novel as a significant work of protest art. Vedasto Suarez’s “Don Lope K. Santos: Ang Banaag at Sikat ng Bagong Panahon” (Don Lope K. Santos: Banaag at Sikat of the New Era), 1969, emphasizes the novel’s link with protest movements formed across the chapters of the nation’s history.

Rogelio Mangahas’s “Ilang Silahis ng Banaag at Sikat” (Some Rays of Banaag at Sikat), 1970, highlights the novel’s merits, such as its ushering in of realism in Philippine literature; its use of humor, irony, and symbolic characterization; and its social relevance. He adds, however, that its weaknesses include verbosity and lack of subtlety. E. San Juan’s “Lope K. Santos: Critique of Individualism and Bourgeois Ideology,” 1971, focuses on the novel’s depiction of the roots and evils of socioeconomic exploitation in the country and its dramatization of social relations and norms that are founded on an elite-controlled social order.

Staying true to the official ideology of Ferdinand Marcos’s martial law, Gregorio C. Borlaza’s “Ang Banaag at Sikat at ang Bagong Pilipinas” (Banaag at Sikat and the New Philippines), 1979, claims that Marcos’s “New Society” program succeeded in fulfilling the novel’s vision of a country that can be free from exploitation without requiring socialist reform or revolution. It won first prize in the essay competition of the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa.  Written by Laurence Marvin Castillo

article_title: Beyond Futility: The Filipino as Critic
text:
Published 1984. Author, Isagani R. Cruz. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

This is a collection of five essays on Philippine literary criticism, literary scholarship, and the teaching of Philippine literature. Cruz makes the following main points:

First, there is an urgent need for textual scholars who can establish definitive editions of works written by Filipino authors, scholars who “are willing to postpone literary criticism until that ideal time when we shall know, at least, what exactly our literary artists have written.”

Second, Filipino critics need to outgrow their “modern” stage and enter into the “postmodern” phase. Postmodern criticism brings back into criticism authorial intention and reader responses, two areas which modern criticism considers to be extraliterary.

Third, teachers of literature must stop using New Critical standards. Instead, they must encourage the students to rely on their own interpretation instead of depending on scholars, expand their reading lists beyond the so-called masterpieces to include Philippine regional literature, refrain from imposing their ideological position on a literary work that does not have it, and study the work as literature and not as a social or political tract.

Finally, Cruz asserts that Filipinos must study their own literature first.

The last essay in this book surveys and evaluates the books of such critics as Ricaredo Demetillo, Leonard Casper, Epifanio San Juan Jr, I. V. Mallari, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, Buenaventura Medina Jr, Doreen G. Fernandez, Reynaldo Ileto, Edna Z. Manlapaz, Gemino Abad, and others.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and David Jonathan Bayot

article_title: Bikols of the Philippines
text:
Published 1983. Author, Maria Lilia F. Realubit. Naga: AMS Press.

 

A 450-page literary history of the region, this book is divided into three parts: a capsule history of the Bicol region from precolonial times until World War II, the literary history proper, and a list of Bikol texts. The introductory section on Bikol history could have been reserved for another book, so that more space might have been allotted to the second, an immensely valuable literary history.

 

There, Realubit outlines the development of Bikol literature, identifies important genres and writers, and provides sample texts and analysis. A notable chapter in this history focuses on the authenticity of the Ibalon, the Bikol folk epic-fragment. Another focal section deals with Bikol orthography, still a contentious issue for writers and the academe today.

 

The third section, a listing of published and unpublished Bikol works from 1570 to 1975, is an important tool for researchers in Bikol literature. Some of the texts listed, however, are no longer extant, and most are available only in the archives of the University of the Philippines Diliman.

 

Bienvenido L. Lumbera states that “Bikol writing has survived because there are scholars and teachers like Maria Lilia F. Realubit who tried to save it from oblivion.” This book has indeed preserved for posterity the golden age of Bikol literature in the first half of the 20th century, when periodicals in the language were still in circulation and when plays in Bikol were still being performed in town plazas. The book is the starting point for research in Bikol literature and an important reference for the teaching of Bikol letters. One may wish that there were longer excerpts or even an anthology appended, so that one might be able to evaluate the value of the texts. Nonetheless, the book has informed and inspired writers and indicated avenues for research in Bikol literature.  Written by Paz Verdades M. Santos

article_title: Biografia de Rizal
text:
(Biography of Rizal). Published 1949. Author, Rafael Palma. Manila: Bureau of Printing. English translation, Pride of the Malay Race by Roman Ozaeta. New York: Prentice-Hall, 1949.

Written under the pseudonym Lakandula, this book was the winning entry in a national contest on the national hero’s biography, organized by the Commonwealth Government in 1938. The only entry in Spanish, as the eleven other entries were in English, it was awarded the first prize of 3,000 pesos. In 34 chapters, it covers Jose Rizal’s formative years up to his execution. Included are details of his parentage, his early education, his Ateneo schooling, and his adolescent loves.

An eyewitness to Rizal’s execution, Palma describes events with unequalled vividness. Being a patriot and a nationalist himself, he offers a penetrating observation on the development of the hero’s nationalism. Rizalist Jaime de Veyra notes that Palma succeeds in portraying the human side of Rizal, especially as he shows Rizal in the context of home and family.

Palma’s incisive and critical analyses of Rizal’s life and works, his interpretation of the hero’s novels, and his presentation of new facts that bring to light Rizal’s versatility were duly noted by the jury. Palma rather persuasively builds a case on the issue of Rizal’s retraction, but on this issue and on some points of research, de Veyra finds vagueness and a number of inaccuracies. De Veyra also observes that Palma’s work does not have the abundance of minor details found in earlier biographies, such as Vida y Escritos del Doctor Jose Rizal (Life and Writings of Doctor Jose Rizal), 1907, by the Spanish Rizalist Wenceslao Retana and Lineage, Life and Labors of Jose Rizal, 1913, by the American Rizalist Austin Craig.  Written by Edgardo Tiamson

article_title: The Bird-Catcher Was a Poet: The Life and Passion of Eduardo A. Makabenta Sr., 1885-1973
text:
Published 2002. Author, Eduardo T. Makabenta Jr. Quezon City: Eduardo A. Makabenta Sr. Foundation.

This book was compiled by Eduardo “Danding” T. Makabenta Jr, his father’s youngest son by his first marriage, 29 years after the poet’s death. It is divided into three parts. Book 1, “My Memoirs,” is Eduardo Makabenta’s autobiography, translated from Spanish into English by Francisco O. Javines and edited by Makabenta Jr. Book 2 contains three essays about Makabenta by Conrado de Quiros, Yen Makabenta, and Gregorio A. Makabenta, and a note by Nicanor Tiongson. Book 3 presents a few of Makabenta’s siday or poetry.

In his 45-chapter memoir, Makabenta describes the early years of his life up to 1932 when his wife, Rosalia, died. About this part of his life, he recounts that his math teacher at Liceo de Manila caused him to change the spelling of his family name from Macaventa to Macabenta to make it more in keeping with the baybayin or native alphabet; that he had to work as a houseboy to pay for his board and lodging when he was a student; that he returned to Leyte to work as a teacher in the public school system, which the Americans were just starting to establish; and that he joined the judicial district of Tacloban three years later, working in various capacities and in different places in Leyte and Samar.

Of Makabenta’s experiences with his writer-contemporaries and carousing companions Iluminado Lucente, Casiano Trinchera, Kikoy Enfectana, Norberto Romualdez, Francisco Alvarado, Espiridion Brillo, and Juan Ricafort, he recalls that drunk, they once broke into a house where old women were singing the pasyon. Makabenta stepped on a coffee pot and spilled the coffee. They found refuge in a friend’s house where they took turns throwing up.

Of his romantic dalliances, he recounts his eight-year courtship of Rosalia Tonolete. She was so closely guarded that he could hardly talk to her face-to-face and had to write to her in code. Their marriage was arranged when his grandfather finally spoke to Rosalia’s family. In 1919, the couple moved to Zamboanga City, where Makabenta served as clerk of court until 1922.

Book 2 supplements the memoir. Conrado de Quiros’s “Eduardo A. Makabenta Sr: The Life and Passion of a Bird Catcher” reports that Makabenta was so scrupulous that he would go into a fit of rage if a litigant attempted to give him a gift. Yen Makabenta’s “Sands against the Wind” rues the loss of literature in the mother language and extols his uncle’s defense of it against the hegemony of English and Tagalog. A brief piece by Gregorio Makabenta, another nephew, describes the honor that Carigara awarded to its illustrious son. Tiongson’s note extols Makabenta as “one of the towering figures in Waray Literature.”

Book 3 presents nine of Makabenta’s most beloved poems, including “Mga Sulat nga Hinipos” (Hidden Letters) and his translation of Jose Rizal’s “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell) into Waray Binisaya, titled “Katapusan nga Panamilit.”

The name Macaventa means “bird catcher.” This book catches that rare bird, the poet himself, and that fragile past which is part of the Waray literary heritage.  Written by Merlie Alunan

article_title: Brains of the Nation: Pedro Paterno, T. H. Pardo de Tavera, Isabelo de los Reyes and the Production of Modern Knowledge
text:
Published 2006. Author, Resil B. Mojares. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press. Gintong Aklat Award for social science, 2008.

The title of the book alludes to Jose Rizal’s characterization of fin de siècle Filipino ilustrados (enlighted class) as “cerebro del pais” (brains of the country). The book concerns the history of the development of the Filipino intelligentsia in the 19th century. In particular, the book recounts the life and analyzes the thought of Pedro Paterno, T. H. Pardo de Tavera, and Isabelo de los Reyes. For various political reasons, the works of these three key figures of Philippine enlightenment “are now mostly unread.”

The book is divided into four sections, each with three chapters. The first section is devoted to Paterno. In the first chapter, “Lord of Luzonica,” Mojares explains why Paterno’s life story has never been written in full and why he is no longer read today despite his being “one of the country’s premier intellectuals.” The next chapter, “Conjuring a Civilization,” reassesses Paterno’s theory of Tagalog civilization and his writings like Ninay, 1885; Antigua Civilizacion Tagalog (Ancient Tagalog Civilization), 1887; Los Itas (The Aeta), 1890; Los Tagalog (The Tagalog), 1894; and the 11-volume Historia de Filipinas (History of the Philippines), 1908-12. In the third chapter, “Cannibalizing Theory,” Mojares critiques the way in which Paterno “cannibalized European knowledge” and positioned himself as a subject, rather than an object, of Orientalism.

The second section centers on Pardo de Tavera. “A Man Apart” presents a biographical overview of Pardo de Tavera, whom Mojares calls the “independent-minded creole.” “Apostle of Reason” considers the main currents of his thought expressed in his many publications on medicine, language, painting, cartography, history, and politics. “Constituting the Nation” locates him vis-à-vis the nation. He was an outsider by virtue of his race, class, education, personality, and politics, but he had an insider’s stake in interpreting “what the Philippines was and who the Filipinos were.”

The third section is devoted to de los Reyes. In “Brother of the Wild,” Mojares traces the life of de los Reyes and gives an account of how he emerged as “the country’s most unorthodox intellectual.” “Deploying Local Knowledge” traces de los Reyes’s career of collecting and deploying folklore and demonstrates how enlightenment was “locally produced” and not merely imported. “Producing Isabelo” explicates how de los Reyes’s intellectual activities were distinct from those of his compatriots based in Europe.

The last section, “The Filipino Enlightenment,” gives a genealogy of Filipino thought. Mojares contextualizes the lives of Paterno, Pardo, and de los Reyes within historiographic and ethnological writings, historic events, and historical shifts before and during the 19th century. In the chapter “Entangled Genealogies,” Mojares delineates the complex results of the native encounter with European knowledge. “The Rise of an Intelligentsia” is an account of how colonial education and modern, voluntary associations precipitated the formation of a national intelligentsia and, eventually, the revolution. In “Writing about Ourselves,” Mojares demonstrates how a generation of Filipino intellectuals laid claim to knowledge, paved a way for national agency, and birthed the “self-consciousness of the Filipino nation.”  Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: A Brief History of Iloko Literature
text:
Published 1936. Author, Leopoldo Y. Yabes. Manila: By the author.

In the preface, the author states that the purpose of the work, which is part of a series of studies on Ilocano literature he was then undertaking, is to acquaint “non-Ilokos with Ilocano literature, particularly the more important works, and to help create a deeper interest in and a greater appreciation for Philippine culture among our people.”

The book contains 10 chapters, the first being an introduction to the land, people, language and literature in general, of the Ilocano. Chapter 2 deals with what is referred to by Yabes as “floating literature,” consisting of folk songs, folktales, and folk philosophy, from which he traces the origins of Ilocano literature. The development of Ilocano literature from the 17th to the 20th century, as shown in the period’s religious literature, linguistic works, drama, fiction, poetry, and even biography, history, ethnology, and scientific works, is discussed in chapters 3-8. Chapter 9 focuses on Ilocano journalism and literature printed in Ilocano periodicals in the 19th to the 20th century. The final chapter is the author’s critique of Ilocano literature. The bibliography compiled by the author and Jose Resurreccion Calip contains 1,918 book and periodical entries, a list of 81 Ilocano periodicals, and location of the materials.

The book is a pioneering effort and has become an essential reference material for scholars and students. Conscientious scholars have been careful, however, to avoid the perpetuation of the author’s bias for Western standards, which is shown in his critical and impressionistic evaluation of some Ilocano writers and writings.  Written by Herminio Beltran Jr

article_title: Brown Heritage: Essays on Philippine Cultural Tradition and Literature
text:
Published 1967. Editor, Antonio S. Manuud. With a prefatory note by James F. Donelan, SJ, and presentation by Horacio de la Costa, SJ. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This collection of essays on Philippine literature and its cultural, societal, and historical background was the product of the short-lived Institute of Philippine Literature of Ateneo de Manila University. Organized in 1965, the institute sponsored lectures during the summers of 1965, 1966, and 1967. Many teachers of Philippine literature in schools, colleges, and universities nationwide attended.

The anthology is divided into four sections: essays on the Philippine cultural tradition, essays on “vernacular literature,” essays on Philippine literature in Spanish, and essays on Philippine literature in English. The book also contains an appendix of essays originally published elsewhere. These include selections from Hispanidad en Filipinas (Hispanism in the Philippines) by Jaime de Veyra, as translated by R. Paradies and J. Araneta, and an essay on the Ifugao hudhud or epic. Jose Rizal’s poem “Mi Retiro” (My Retreat) is also appended.

Contributors to the book are renowned names in Philippine scholarship and letters: Bienvenido Lumbera; Jaime Bulatao, SJ; Domingo Abella; F. Landa Jocano; Mary Hollnsteiner; Julian E. Dacanay Jr; Alfredo Roces; Antonio Manuud; John Schumacher, SJ; Miguel Bernad, SJ; Emy Pascasio; Rolando Tinio; Francisco Arcellana; Francis Lambrecht, CICM; and Francisco Demetrio, SJ.

The anthology covers diverse topics in Philippine literature and culture: folklore, language, and regional art. General surveys of the different literary genres in the Philippines are also included, as are more detailed studies of individual writers like Jose Rizal, N. V. M.Gonzalez, and Nick Joaquin. This collection of essays on Philippine literature and its cultural, societal, and historical background was the product of the short-lived Institute of Philippine Literature of Ateneo de Manila University. article_title: Bukod na Bukod: Mga Piling Sanaysay
text:
(Totally Incomparable: Selected Essays). Published 2003. Author, Isagani R. Cruz. Editor, David Jonathan Y. Bayot. With an introduction by the editor. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The 29 essays in this collection were written by Cruz in the 1980s and the 1990s. The book is divided into four sections. The first and theoretical section deals with criticism, which Cruz labels “Kritika.” In six essays, Cruz offers an incisive look into what ails Philippine criticism. We are not only the West’s Other, he avers, simply because we are powerless in the face of Western hegemony. Our critical writing is the “Other Other” because of its lack of identity, its pitiful reliance on Western paradigms, its inability to look at its texts on their own terms, and as importantly, its denigration of women. “Ang Papel ng Kritiko’t Kritika sa Ating Lipunan” (The Role of the Critic and Criticism in Our Society) spells out in more detail the functions of a critic: decolonizing minds and problematizing various forms of hegemonic discourse, retrieving forgotten texts and reinterpreting canonical texts from an anticolonial perspective, producing more critical works, junking all forms of Neo-Universalism.

The second section, composed of nine essays, deals with key issues in language and translation. Cruz explains the linguistic features of Filipino, underscores the importance of putting Filipino and Filipino literature in the curriculum, and demonstrates how popular texts, such as novels and romances, have continually vivified the language. In “Ang Wika bilang Ideolohiya o Ang Wika ng Teorya bilang Teorya ng Wika” (Language as Ideology or The Language of Theory as Theory of Language) and “Kung Bakit Malabo ang Ingles pero Hindi Dapat Lumabo ang Ating Paningin / Deconstructing English as a Language for Philippine Theory: Isang Papel, Dalawang Wika” (Why English Is Dim but Our Eyesight Should Not Be / Deconstructing English as a Language for Philippine Theory: One Paper, Two Languages), Cruz discusses the various theories of language that have been proposed in Western literary theory, exposing how deeply steeped these have been in the ideologies of the culture from which they emerged. The crucial task of the Filipino scholars, therefore, is to further examine their language as constitutive of their realities.

In the third section, “Panitikan/Literatura,” Cruz offers a deconstructive reading of a poem by Leona Florentino, engages Bienvenido Santos and his works in a conversation, and analyzes the achievements of Cirilo Bautista. In explicating their diverse texts, Cruz demonstrates the practical application of relevant critical theories. “Kasaysayan ng Literaturang Filipino” (History of Filipino Literature) provides a brief overview of the nation’s past literary achievements, while “Saan Patungo ang Ating Literatura?” (Where Is Our Literature Headed?) offers an optimistic forecast.

In the final section, Cruz combines his understanding of the tight connection between theory and praxis. In six provocative studies, he shows how crucial it is for any critic to focus on the text not only as a formal artifact, as a Formalist critic would, nor pass off the text as a “reflection” or “mirror” of reality, as a socialist critic would. The variety of the texts he examines is staggering—from the canonical Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1838, to the presidency of Corazon Aquino, from the epic hero Lam-ang to the movie idol Fernando Poe Jr and the political martyr Benigno Aquino Jr, from violence-themed Filipino films to the EDSA Revolt, from the vulgar, ribald jokes of Filipinos and the pleasurable game of mah-jong to the elements of the Filipino’s psyche. These are made to yield a variety of exciting and sometimes contradictory meanings.

This book sums up Cruz’s basic concerns: the problematic concept of literature, language as constitutive of reality, the need for a critical imagination to bring about freedom from oppression (colonial, patriarchal, class), and most important, the need for the critic to oscillate between concrete texts, on the one hand, and the sociopolitical realities that the texts could help reveal or unravel, on the other.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: The Cardinal's Sins, the General's Cross, the Martyr's Testimony and Other Affirmations
text:
Published 2005. Author, Gregorio C. Brillantes. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for essay, 2006.

One of three collections of Brillantes’s essays that were released between 2004 and 2005 (the other two being Looking for Jose Rizal in Madrid: Journeys, Latitudes, Perspectives, Destinations, 2004, and Chronicles of Interesting Times: Essays, Discourses, Gems of Wisdom, Some Laughs and Other Non-Biodegradable Articles, 2005), this book contains 34 essays and columns, written between 1967 and 2002, previously published in Leader, Philippines Free Press, Philippine Graphic, and other publications. The book is divided into six sections: “Lives and Legends,” a selection of profiles on  Jose Rizal, Teilhard de Chardin, Jaime Cardinal Sin, and others; “Interesting Times,” which deals with the country’s changing sociopolitical situation, from imperialism to bad roads; “Ancient and Ever New,” which reflects on Catholicism; “Critical Conditions,” which examines Filipino writing, culture, and creativity; and “Last Laughs,” pieces without a unifying theme apart from their humor, formal ingenuity, and analyses of the post-Marcos years.

Almost all these works are politically charged. One of the earliest, “Ferdinand Marcos: An Appreciation,” 1970, is a brilliant satirical defense of the then six-year reign of President Marcos, showcasing Brillantes’s wit and ability to be both oblique and pointed. Both of these traits would be put to good use in the articles to follow, published during martial law, when criticism must necessarily be veiled and—this a by-product of censure and unrest—full of ingenuity.

Catholicism and faith play important roles in his articles. In pieces like “The Phenomenon of Teilhard de Chardin,” 1967, and “Christians for Revolution,” 1971, Brillantes discusses the ways that certain priests and intellectuals, with or without the approval of their superiors, have succeeded in modernizing Catholicism in the 20th century. Other articles focus on the histories of events important to Catholicism and the faith in the Philippines, such as the miracles of Lourdes, and the presentation of the Santo Niño. Unfortunately, there are times when Brillantes’s strong Catholic sensibility borders on exclusivity, privileging Catholic discourses on the nation over other interpretations.

Another prominent theme in Brillantes’s work is his apologia for using English in the Philippines. He argues across many articles that the language has been useful for literacy, for its tradition, and for providing access to international literatures. These arguments reach their peak in his essay, “Nick Joaquin / Quijano de Manila and Other Anomalies,” 1978, where the “anomaly” in the works of Nick Joaquin is that his use of English and of foreign/colonial heritage makes his works every bit as Filipino, if not more so, than those by the enemies of English.

The wide coverage of the book is itself one of its most interesting aspects, because a collection that spans four decades is itself a historical document revealing the evolution of Filipino consciousness. Although Brillantes is consistently sharp, witty, and political, his style and politics noticeably changed with the years. From 1967 to 1971, the articles are clearly irreverent and leftist. The aforementioned “Ferdinand Marcos: An Appreciation” pokes fun at the president, and “Christians for Revolution” asserts that Christians and Marxist-Leninists must learn from each other for the good of the country. While the irreverence is toned down somewhat at the beginning of martial law, when indirection becomes the norm, it returns again in the turbulent 1980s, and is seen best in “The Testimony to Ninoy Aquino,” 1984.

The 1990s show a different story. In the wake of purges and the loss of a common enemy, the Left itself divided and fell apart. In the articles written in this decade, Marxists and corrupt politicians alike are targets of Brillantes’s pen, which declares itself openly in “Stories” as being “liberal, capitalist, democratic.”

Thus, in this collection of essays of four decades, we find both the conscious concerns of the author and the heartbeat of his age, the currents of the country’s history, hidden, interwoven, and living in the text.  Written by Dominic Sy

article_title: Children of the Ever-Changing Moon: Essays by Young Moro Writers
text:
Published 2007. Editor, Gutierrez Mangansakan II. With an introduction by the editor. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

The 16 essays explore the multifaceted aspects of a people’s identity and shed light on the culturally complex matter that is the Moro identity.

In his introduction, Mangansakan recounts his own grappling with his Moro identity. He concludes that identity is irreducible to a specific variable, and is rather an “evolutionary process,” which includes one’s ancestry, upbringing, immediate environment, among other things. Similarly, there is no unified identity among the different groups that are collectively called Moro, though they share a common religion.

The essays bring up various issues related to being a young Muslim. “A Letter to My Father” by Pearlsha Abubakar addresses the estrangement between a child and a parent who disapproves of her secular spirituality. Language as a marker of otherness is described in “Language Barriers” by Sahara Alia Jauhali Silongan. The persistent struggle to effect dialogues between Muslims and Christians is foregrounded in Samira Ali Gutoc’s “My Journey as an Empowered Journalist.” Sitti Djalia Turabin-Hataman draws the line between compromise and dialogue in “Compromise,” which recounts how her son prays publicly in a Catholic pre-nursery. “What’s in a Name?” by Gonaranao B. Musor is about how his name is a metonym of his being Maranao.

The book also brings to the table issues of sex and gender. “Nashiza Speaks on Peace Talks” by Mucha-Shim Quiling Arquiza argues for the female representation in peace negotiations. Allyson Banga-an in “Pink Is the Color of the Crescent Moon” unflinchingly stands his ground before both Catholic and Muslim homophobia. “Salam! Motherland” by Mangansakan recounts how he reconnected with himself when he returned to his grandfather’s red house in Pagalungan.

The other essays in the anthology are “A Superpower’s Puff Girl” by Sarah Matalam-Alvarez, “A Malaysian Hariraya” by Ayesah Abubakar, “Living Life out of the Box” by Ayesha Merdeka Alonto-Datu Ramos, “Linuk in My Childhood Memories” by Sittie Jamairah Disomimba, “Tawi-Tawi Impressions, 1990” by Nefertari Al-Raschid-Arsad, “The Complex Path towards My Epiphany” by Loren Hallilah Lao, “Daddy-Yo” by Farida D. Mending, and “Ramadan Musings” by Zainudin Malang.

Black-and-white photographs capture quotidian Bangsamoro lives: a circle of elderly men on the linoleum floor on which a microphone rests, a schoolgirl wearing a hijab (veil) of embroidered tulle, a man at his woodwork, an elderly lady at a loom. The photographs are by Al Jacinto, Gandhi Kinjiyo, Gutierrez Mangansakan II, Carlos H. Conde, and Bobby Timonera.  Written by Julian dela Cerna

article_title: Coming Home
text:
Published 1997. Author, Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Coming Home is a collection of magazine articles, newspaper columns, journal entries, and conference papers written over a period of time. The contents are varied: reminiscences, literary criticism, confessions, reviews, an interview with fictionist Gilda Cordero-Fernando, and travel essays, probably Hidalgo’s forte.

Nostalgia is the keynote of much of the collection. Hidalgo revisits antique haunts and familiar faces, relives childhood pleasures and adolescent mischief, celebrates old family rituals and social ceremonies. Her essays are peopled by old teachers, maiden aunts, itinerant friends, priests and nuns, writers and academics, some of them already gone but all lovingly recollected from, and perhaps also mystified by, the magic of memory.

In her reminiscences, Hidalgo brings to mind, except for the suburban settings in some of them, scenes from Amorsolo’s idylls or stills from a well-made costume drama. In “Boomtown,” she describes a family picnic to Tagaytay with details consisting of buko (coconut) juice, a hammock, bicycles, a cottage, a motel named Cliffview, a coffee farm, farmers peddling sundry vegetables and fruits, and bucayo (a sweet made of grated coconut meat). Hidalgo is at her best describing places, especially those that no longer are or else have been irreversibly altered. As in a pointillist painting, she lays out the details, piece by seemingly trivial piece, until she creates not just a picture but a complete mood. Her description of her family’s old house in New Manila—from the dirt road that led to it to the rooms it contained; from the capiz-shell windows to the garden of dahlias, chichirica, begonias, bougainvillea, and yellow bells that they overlooked; from the sari-sari (general merchandise) store across from it to the empty lot turned basketball court beside it—evokes, rather than states, the meaning of “home.”

In some instance, the reminiscences come with a wistfulness, a mourning for the “good old days” that are no more. In “Colegio,” Hidalgo takes us back to a world without computers or calculators, video players or CDs, where leisure meant stopping by the Rizal Monument “to watch the changing of the guard.”

But these essays are more than sentimental musings about times past. Here and there Hidalgo provokes her readers to rethink the familiar. In “Pampahaba ng Buhay” (For Longevity), she describes a typical Sunday in Hong Kong where she and her friends are taking a break. Here she observes overseas contract workers, and she is aware of being (to quote from another of her essays in the collection) “yet another alienated middleclass woman” (159), identifying with the poor Filipinas in Hong Kong who are certainly not there on a vacation. In “Pinoys Down Under,” Hidalgo recounts the travails of being a woman; and in “A Gentle Colonization,” which may be the best essay in the collection, Hidalgo describes the subtle—and hence effective and ineradicable—“colonization of the mind.”

When Hidalgo ceases to reminisce, she discusses literature, although even then the memories trickle in. She tells us about her influences and favorite writers, her childhood reading and favorite characters. More fascinating, however, is her account of how her stories and the novel Recuerdo, 1996, were conceived.

The nostalgic tone ends when she reviews books. Her incisive comments reveal a keen mind, cutting without being tactless, critical without being destructive.

These essays record Hidalgo’s thoughts about various topics, but what ultimately emerges as the subject is Hidalgo herself, the woman as writer. We are introduced to a sensibility well-informed, sensitive, and sophisticated, but not unblemished by doubts. Ultimately, it is her honesty—and humanity—that disarm.  Written by Jonathan Chua

The nostalgic tone ends when she reviews books. Her incisive comments reveal a keen mind, cutting without being tactless, critical without being destructive.

These essays record Hidalgo’s thoughts about various topics, but what ultimately emerges as the subject is Hidalgo herself, the woman as writer. We are introduced to a sensibility well-informed, sensitive, and sophisticated, but not unblemished by doubts. Ultimately, it is her honesty—and humanity—that disarm.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Confessions of a Q. C. House-Husband and Other Privacies
text:
Published 1991. Author, AlfredA.Yuson. Manila: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This is a collection of some 80 personal essays previously published between 1986 and 1991 in the periodicals where Yuson wrote. Yuson writes on a broad spectrum of subjects that ranges from the ordinary—seemingly trivial—matters, like basketball, Robert Jaworski, buying cigarettes, jeans, names and nicknames, typographical errors; to raising children, politics and political figures, art and literature.

Several essays are about domestic affairs. Reversing traditional gender roles, Yuson recounts the travails—and little joys—of keeping a household in order while his wife is “in some building in pursuit of a career in the field.” Changing diapers, trimming the lawn, “barking” at maids who refuse to work, sending the kids to school through rain and flood, paying the bills and fixing the leak in the ceiling, getting the best bargains in groceries, coping with sibling rivalry and adolescent hang-ups—in short, “all these daily aggravations and series of glitches that positively suck”—these, the concerns of a Quezon City “house-husband,” are colorfully, meticulously detailed.

Other essays portray Filipino traits and contemporary Philippine life. He describes dubious voting habits and the Filipinos’ penchant for coining neologisms, such as “Imeldific,” “Corified,” and “salvage,” from political events and personalities. He satirically draws a hypothetical “Philippine Eden,” whose economic activities would include “multinational and intraregional agencies supplying security guards, domestics, overseas workers, folk dancers, barbed wire, Paltiks, fake passports, monthly pedophilia cruise packages and, above all, international loans.” Yuson is generally playful even with serious sociopolitical issues, but elsewhere he can be scathing, as in his definition of “Marcosian.”

In the opening essay, he recreates the scenes and sounds of the festive 1960s—the Beatles, Muhammad Ali, pot sessions at the UP Chapel, the beginnings of student activism—but tempers his nostalgia with an afterthought: “Of course memory’s an artificial sweetener, not always trustworthy. The past reconstitutes itself perennially as greener grass; the song gets better in its haunting reprise.”

Yuson’s essays reflect a middle-class urban sensibility, sensitive to the flux of modern Philippine life. His prose sparkles with wit and, sometimes, sarcasm, but always his images are strikingly original, endowing the commonplace—a typo, a doorknob—with a fresh glow. Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Contracting Colonialism: Translation and Christian Conversion in Tagalog Society under Early Spanish Rule
text:
Published 1988. Author, Vicente L. Rafael. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press. Another edition in New York: Cornell University Press, 1988, 2000.

This book examines the relationship among the concepts of conversion, translation, and colonialization. Criticizing the view that colonialism is a unilinear event whereby the colonizers impose their will, Rafael asserts that it relies on how successfully the colonizers encode or adapt their system of meanings into the native’s mentality. Thus, one “contracts” colonialism, implying the existence of covert resistance, instead of merely succumbing to it.

Chapter 1 notes how the native baybayin, the local system of writing, resists the totalizing tendency of Spanish to fix meaning. The ambiguity of the baybayin makes it open to a multiplicity of meanings; the Spanish missionaries, then, replaced it with the Roman alphabet. However, even as the indio (Christianized native) employed the Roman alphabet, the tendency to be elusive still remained, as can be observed, for instance, in the frequent confusion of the Tagalog vowels: between e and i and between o and u. Thus, instead of being determined or controlled, meaning had to be “guessed.”

Rafael then discusses how Tomas Pinpin, one of the earliest teachers of the Spanish language, through his books, circumvents Spanish authority while appearing to submit to it. For instance, rather than showing correspondences between Spanish and Tagalog or discussing grammar and syntax, Pinpin emphasizes the attachment of proper affixes: “for eis, one responds with the ending emos; for ais, amos; and so forth.” He thus made Spanish a pairing game and diluted its claim to authority, in contrast to the tendency of the missionaries’ artes (grammar books) to show a hierarchy of languages. The next sections discuss how Christianity was translated into the Tagalog notions of utang na loob, or debt of gratitude, and hiya or shame. However, the discrepancy between the Spanish understanding of these notions and the native’s understanding of them resulted in a “hollowing out [of] the Spanish call to submission,” even as the Filipinos appeared to have embraced Christianity. Rafael proceeds to discuss the economic and social conditions in Tagalog society. He notes how Spanish leaders co-opted the native elite and enforced tributes by adapting extant local practices. The last chapter examines Gaspar Aquino de Belen’s Pasyon, in which he finds the native’s reformulation of death.

Contracting Colonialism is significant not only for providing an alternative view of Spanish colonialization and Christianization of the Tagalog but also for applying Western poststructuralist theories in the analysis of a chapter in the history of a non-Western society.  Written by Jonathan Chua

 

Source

San Juan, Epifanio Jr. 1991. “Power, Language, Resistance.” Review of Contracting Colonialism by Vicente Rafael. Diliman Review 39:41-44.

article_title: The Critical Villa: Essays in Literary Criticism by Jose Garcia Villa
text:
Published 2002. Author, Jose Garcia Villa. Editor, Jonathan Chua. With a foreword by Doreen G. Fernandez and an introduction by the editor. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for editing, 2003.

The book is the first and only comprehensive anthology of Jose Garcia Villa’s critical essays written from the 1920s to the 1950s, which are among the most significant in Philippine literary criticism in English. It embodies precisely how Villa, known primarily as a poet, influenced the creation of a canon of Philippine fiction and poetry during this period.

The first section, “The Annual Selections,” collects Villa’s better-known essays from 1927 to 1941 on what he deemed were the best works of fiction and poetry on a given year. The essays came with a “Roll of Honor,” a “Yearbook Index,” and a “Criminal Record.” From these essays can be gleaned how Villa evaluates literature using as criterion the harmony of substance and form. Notably, “The Best Filipino Short Stories of 1937” gives an account of Villa’s controversial position with regard to the question of “proletarian literature.”

The second section, “Critical Essays,” puts together Villa’s lesser-known critical essays, which throw a longer view at literary production in the Philippines and, at the same time, are more focused on assessing the state of Philippine fiction, poetry, and criticism at the time of their writing.

In the essays “Fifteen Literary Landmarks,” “Fifteen Finest Filipino Short Stories, 1925-1936,” and “The Contemporary Short Story,” Villa specifies the qualities of a great story. In “Writing Short Stories in the Philippines,” “Our Intellectuals and Artists,” and “The Rise of the Short Story in the Philippines,” he enumerates the merits and deficiencies of Philippine literature. “Poems for an Unhumble One,” the two installments of “The Status of Philippine Poetry,” and “The Condition of Philippine Verse” articulate and exemplify Villa’s poetics. In “Literary Criticism in the Philippines,” he explains why Filipino critics are more capable of commenting on stories rather than on poems.

The book appends six letters by Villa, five of which were published in different magazines: “Villa Raps Faigao for Poetry Selections,” “G-r-and Passion,” “Villa on Wilson’s ‘Amphisbaenic Endings,’” “Villa on Rafael Zulueta da Costa,” “Villa on Philippine Poetry,” and “Villa’s Letter of Defense,” which is his reply to the charge that he has “poisoned public morals” with his early poems “Man-Songs.”

The Critical Villa is the product of the scholarship of Jonathan Chua, who not only recovered, compiled, edited, and annotated the essays by and the bibliography of Villa but also provides an insightful introduction that contextualizes Villa’s work as critic and that plots the various critiques and re-readings of Villa through the decades.  Written by Patrick Campos
