article_title: Culture and History: Occasional Notes on the Process of Philippine Becoming
text:
Published 1988. Author, Nick Joaquin. Metro Manila: Solar Publishing Corporation. Reprinted, Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 2004.

This collection by poet, playwright, short story writer, essayist, biographer, and novelist Nick Joaquin is composed of 15 essays on culture “written at different moments over a wide period arranged to form a more or less coherent reflection of Philippine chronology … with the intent … to ask … pesky questions … about our history and culture.” The works thus differ in intent from the journalistic essays signed “Quijano de Manila.”

The lead essay, “Culture as History,” is the best known and has roused some controversy. Its thesis is that epochs of history bring in new tools “or novelties in media, or advances in technique,” which alter the culture or “the way of life being impressed on a community by its technics.” Cultural change is thus history. As major evidence Joaquin cites the changes in Philippine culture brought about by Spanish colonization. Where others may see this as intervention in what is Filipino, he calls this “the process of Filipino becoming,” which brought in economic transformation “from a subsistence culture to ‘the first world economy of modern times,’” changes in technology and art—so that “our training in common in new media was what forged the identity we now term Filipino.” He sees the Filipino as having been created “in the 16th and 17th centuries by a tool-forged fusion of Luzon tribes, Visayan tribes, Mindanao tribes, Spanish mestizos, Chinese mestizos, etc.” Later, Americanization brought about “the start of a Philippine industrial culture, Americanized only so far as the Americanization served our destiny and helped to bring the points of native genius that this particular change could bring out.” The period of Hispanization, he asserts, was also “the period of the Filipino’s emergence in Asia,” and therefore this colonial period was not “the corruption of our Asian soul” but a simultaneous “Westernization” and “Asianizing.” Thus, Christian culture does not make the Filipino a “freak” in Asia but a “singular self” shaped by culture and history.

The book’s middle essay, “History as Culture,” and the final one, “Culture and History,” underscore this. In the latter, Joaquin lists “the twelve greatest events in Philippine history”: the first, the introduction of the wheel; the last, that of the guisado, part of the Spanish heritage that converted “a mix of cabbages and kings” into a nation-in-the-making called the Philippines and an identity-in-progress called Filipino.

The rest are on other aspects of culture: “Footnotes to Yesterday” on artifacts; “Our Heart’s in the Highlands?” on Mountain Province culture; “Culture Hero: The Santo Niño de Cebu”; “Ikon, Friar and Conquistador”; “Bulls (Papal) and Geography”; “The Beatas of 17th-Century Manila”; “Apocalypse and the Revolution”; “The American Interlude”; “Expression in the Philippines” on literature; “A Heritage of Smallness” on the tingi or retail syndrome; and “Junking the Heritage” on the impending revolution.

The collection is Nick Joaquin’s exposition, discussion, and assertion of his theory on culture as history and history as culture.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

article_title: Ang Dapat Mabatid ng Mga Tagalog
text:
(What the Tagalog Should Know). Published 1896. Author, Andres Bonifacio. Kalayaan, 18 Jan 1896. English translation, “What the Filipinos Should Know” by Gregorio Nieva, in The Revolutionists: Aguinaldo, Bonifacio, Jacinto, edited with an introduction and notes by Teodoro A. Agoncillo. Manila: National Historical Commission, 1973, from the Spanish translation of “Andres Bonifacio” by Epifanio de los Santos, in Revista Filipina, Nov 1917.

“Ang Dapat Mabatid ng mga Tagalog” is Bonifacio’s manifesto urging revolt against Spanish rule. Although addressed to the “Katagalugan” or inhabitants of the Tagalog area, the manifesto is often taken to apply to the Filipinos in general.

Bonifacio begins by describing the Philippines before the arrival of the Spaniards. It was prosperous and independent, enjoying trade with its neighbors. The people, including women and children, were literate and well-to-do. This prosperity vanished upon the arrival of the Spaniards. Promising enlightenment, the Spaniards succeeded in winning the natives’ confidence, only to enslave them.

The result of this contact was less than gratifying. In a series of vivid images, Bonifacio forcefully brings across the wretchedness of the Philippines under Spanish rule: the sighs and cries of widows and orphans, the mother’s tears flowing for her murdered children, “each tear like a drop of molten lead that lacerates our suffering wounded heart.”

To this, the only recourse is clear—overthrow the oppressor. Bonifacio compares the sun to reason, by the light of which the Filipinos can dispel the mist that blinds them and see the mire they are in. This, then, is what the Filipinos must know: they can expect neither comfort from the Spaniards nor assistance from others. They must rely on themselves to change their lot. The manifesto ends with a call to arms.

The manifesto gains persuasive power from the simplicity of its logic, which appeals to one’s sense of basic retribution: since Spain failed to fulfill her promise, it is right that she be punished. Bonifacio’s direct prose style recalls another revolutionist tract, Emilio Jacinto’s “Liwanag at Dilim” (Light and Darkness). These two pieces were largely responsible for raising the Filipinos’ consciousness of the Spanish yoke and for gaining support for the Katipunan, the secret society against Spain.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Dasalan at Tocsohan
text:
(Prayers and Temptations/Jokes). Written 1888. Author, Marcelo H. del Pilar. Broadside leaflet. Included in Magno Gatmaitan, The Life and Works of Marcelo H. del Pilar, 1965.

This is a parody of the prayers and catechism that are prescribed by the Spanish friars. It was printed anonymously and enjoyed a wide, if clandestine, circulation. It was so popular that Arch Bernardino Nozaleda issued a strong denunciation against it and similar works. Parodies of the prayers are the sign of the cross, “Ang Tanda ng Cara-i-cruz” (The Sign of the Heads-or-Tails); the Act of Contrition, “Panginoon Kong Fraile” (My Lord the Friar); the Our Father, “Amain Namin” (Our Uncle); and the Hail Mary, “Aba Guinoong Barya” (Hail Our Lord the Coin). Punishment, virtue, and atonement are concepts given a satirical twist. The title essay, “Tocsohan” (question-and-answer) caricatures the question-answer practice of catechism instruction. “Ang mga Utos nang Fraile” (The Friar’s Commandments) is a parody of the Ten Commandments. “Apat ang mga Kaholiholihang Darating sa Fraile” (The Friar’s Four Fates) talks of death, judgment, heaven, and hell. “Ako Raw Ay Makasalanan” (I Am Called a Sinner) takes off from the declaration of faith by the newly baptized. “Ang mga Biyaya ng Fraile” (The Friar’s Privileges) satirizes the catechism of the “four benefits” derived from regular attendance at the ceremony of the mass.

Works like this contributed to the erosion of the “friarcracy” and led to the 1896 Revolution. It is a historical example of satirical humor used as a propaganda weapon and as an important tool for the Filipino seeking psychological equilibrium in an oppressive society.  Written by Rene Javellana

article_title: Davao: Reconstructing History From Text and Memory
text:
Published 2005. Author, Macario D. Tiu. With a preface by Patricio N. Abinales. Davao City: Ateneo de Davao, University Research and Publication Office. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for history, 2006. Revised edition, with an introduction and notes by the author, 2013.

This book offers a broad account of Davao history, covering events from early Islamic rule, the Spanish colonization, the American occupation, World War II, the Marcos regime, and the early 21st century. In the preface, Abinales commends Tiu’s effort to rely on local sources. Tiu states in his introduction that he is more wary of documents written by colonizers than he is of indigenous folklore, from which he finds valuable clues to the gaps and mysteries left by standard historical sources. Thus, Tiu engages with the work of foreign historians, the Muslim tarsila (genealogical narratives of the royalty), and the oral tradition of the Davao tribes to present an ethnography and genealogy of Davao’s lumad (indigenous peoples), to portray the lives of settlers and local heroes, and to map out the story of how Davao came to be.

The book is divided into five chapters. The first chapter reveals historical highlights, discussing the archaeological finds in Talikud Island and Davao del Sur, and the early foreign presence in the Davao Gulf. article_title: The Davao We Know
text:
Published 2011. Editor, Lolita R. Lacuesta. With an introduction and preface by the editor. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for anthology in English, 2012.

The 19 essays depict in personal terms the history of Davao City, from its being billed by the national government as the Land of Promise to encourage migration there, to its being the bloodiest arena in the country during World War II, to its being witness, during martial law, to “salvaging,” a colloquial term for the summary execution of leftists, who were often accused of treason at that time. According to the preface, these essays aim to express the Davao experience “in as varied a manner as possible.” Their authors are either the builders of Davao or their descendants and are either “home-grown” or migrants.

The introduction presents an overview of the phenomenon of Davao migration. Davao is depicted in popular culture as a place for one to start anew. This depiction has turned Davao into a self-sustaining community of migrants and a Philippine melting pot of languages and cultures.

In Tita Lacambra-Ayala’s essay, aptly titled “Davao,” the author begins with an arrival, describing her first impressions of the young city as she gets off the airplane and is transported to the banana plantation in Tagum, where her husband, the writer Jose V. Ayala, has been assigned. This piece about their life in this coastal town climaxes in another arrival, in the form of an enormous whale beached about 50 meters away from their seaside house. By nightfall, the whale is consumed by the townspeople. Pribhu Dhalamal Balchand remembers the great fire that razed the main thoroughfares of Davao in 1964. Arch Renato S. Basa’s “Building Davao” recounts the pioneering architectural work of his father, Ramon Domingo Basa, who designed some of Davao’s famous landmarks, including San Pedro Cathedral.

In Aida Rivera-Ford’s “Martial Memories,” promising students of Ateneo de Davao die in encounters with military forces. In “Torture,” Macario D. Tiu looks back on the days that he went underground and on his capture for “tactical interrogation” by the military.

Essays reflecting on the relationship between the settlers and the lumad (indigenous peoples) and attesting to the mutual acculturation of the two groups are Lolita R. Lacuesta’s “Ag Saka,” which is from the lumad point of view; and Cynthia Nograles-Lumbera’s “This Settlement Town,” which is from that of the Visayan settler. Of bagani (warrior chieftain) lineage, Lacuesta recounts growing up as a mestiza-Mansaka and remarks on how the family continues to observe their people’s healing practices, despite the strong objections of her father, a Christian migrant from Zamboanga.

In “Memories of World War II,” Patricia Garcia Montemayor writes about growing up during the Japanese occupation and later with the American presence during the restoration. Michael L. Tan’s “Chay Ko” (literally, “vegetarian woman” but referring to a very devout, but lay, Buddhist) is about the author’s grandmother, a Chinese immigrant who administered a renowned Buddhist temple. Although born and based in Manila, Tan regularly visits Davao, especially the temple, to remember his grandmother who had refused to convert to Christianity.

The other essays in the book are “Writing the News for a Cause” by Jo Bacani Angeles; “Peace Time” by Nenita Belda Azarcon; “Hostages at Gatungan” by Jose F. Campo; “The Liberation of Davao” by Ernesto I. Corcino; “My Patch of Green” by Fe del Rosario Dacudao; “Claustrophobic in a City under Siege” by Karl M. Gaspar, CSsR; “When Buildings Were Made of Wood, and Sidewalks, Too” by Margarita Marfori; “Farm Seven” by Marcelino E. Payumo; “My Bangkerohan Bridge” by Ting Tiongco; and “Growing Up in Paradise” by Josie C. Tionko.

The collection responds to the changes the city constantly faces. By writing their memories down, the authors map out its history and provide future residents a guide to understanding their identity.   Written by Julian dela Cerna

article_title: Discovering New Horizons: Anthology of Chinese Filipino Literature in English
text:
Published 1989. Editors, Andrew K. Arriola, Grace C. Pe. Manila: World News.

The brainchild of editors Andrew K. Arriola and Grace C. Pe, the anthology features short stories, poems, and essays by Chinese Filipino writers that explore a variety of issues regarding the Chinese Filipino experience. The anthology is divided into three sections: “The Self,” “Relationships,” and “Society.”

A prominent theme that runs through the collection is the alienation experienced by Chinese Filipinos. Jane Que Tiu’s “Life in This Country: Through a Pair of Chinky Eyes” narrates the author’s personal experiences of stereotyping and isolation and her resolve nonetheless to show her gratitude to the country that has fostered her ancestors. Tiu reasserts this resolve in her short story “Double Happiness,” which tells the intermarriage between a Chinese woman and a Filipino man.

Transplantation and the construction of ethnic identity also figure prominently in the anthology. Lao Bi Eng’s vignette “Soliloquy of a Gardener” uses the roots of a tree as a metaphor for how established the Chinese identity is within the Filipino social landscape. Returning to China as the motherland is also expressed in Eddie Choa’s poem “Home.”

A number of works in the anthology portray family issues. Caroline S. Hau’s “New Year’s Day” tells the story of a young girl’s discovery of her older sister’s marital problems; R. Kwan Laurel’s “Father” narrates the strained relationship between father and son; Andrew Arriola’s “Conflict” tells the story of a father’s thwarted dream of having his son continue the family business; and Grace C. Pe’s “Of Sons and Heirs” comments on the preference for sons over daughters among the Chinese.

The short stories cover diverse themes and types. Aileen June Wang’s “Nightmare on Victual Street” and Alice Bernice S. Ty’s “The Most Powerful Spell” present tales of fantasy with underlying lessons on morality. Grace C. Pe’s “Last Laugh” tells the story of ace high school students being outwitted by the school. Caroline S. Hau’s “Grief” follows the endurance of a mother in the face of her husband’s abduction by Japanese troops, and Maningning Miclat’s “Monitor” narrates a day in a life of a studious and introspective schoolgirl. Finally, Serene Yu’s “On Johanna’s Birthday” and “On His Way Home” offer short impressionistic tales of childhood.

The poems are equally diverse. Vangie Sy’s poems “A Street Scene” and “All Along I Thought,” Aileen June Wang’s poem “Thoughts on a Rainy Day,” and Genevieve Go Khoe’s poem “Christmas Will Never Be the Same Again” depict yearning for love to come and grief over lost love.

Grace Hsieh Hsing’s “Bayanihan” (Cooperation), translated by John Shih, and Miclat’s “Burucracia” (Bureaucracy) and “Saling-Wika” (Translation) depict positive and negative traits of Filipino culture and way of life; Grace C. Pe’s “Behold Thy Son” tells of a mother’s inability to rectify her son; Lelly Go Tiu’s “Holding On” and Genevieve Go Khoe’s “Ordinary People” express continuing faith in the face of difficulties. Finally, other poems by Mario Miclat and Wang depict moments of introspection on the nature of life and existence.

The essays focus on the relationship between the Chinese Filipino community and the broader ethnic Filipino society as well as on the development of Filipino and Chinese Filipino literature. Mario Miclat’s “China Impressions and Other Stories” discusses the extensive history and the richly diverse culture of China, which in turn yields a wealth of impressions about the country. Albert Lim’s “Filipino-Chinese: Are We or Are We Not?” points out that the alienation of Chinese Filipinos is due to the differences, misunderstandings, and the mutual distrust between the two groups. In “Cradle of a Long Discord,” Lim traces the history of the rift between Chinese Filipinos and Filipinos to Spain’s attempt to divide the country and preserve supremacy. In both essays, Lim encourages unity and the observance of statesmanship.

Wilson Lee Flores’s “An Overview of Contemporary Philippine Literature” discusses the emergence of writers, organizations, and award-giving bodies as part of the maturation of Philippine literature. Flores also identifies pursuit of national identity and social justice as the definitive themes of contemporary Philippine literature. James T. C. Na’s “Facts on Philippine Chinese Literature,” translated by Linda Lim, traces the development of Chinese Filipino literature, which began during the prewar decades and flowered following the fall of the Marcos regime, while lamenting the decline of literacy in Chinese.  Written by Jeffrey Yap

article_title: Doctrina Christiana en Lengua Espaola y Tagala
text:
(Christian Doctrine in the Spanish and Tagalog Languages). Published 1593. Manila.

The first book published in Tagalog, the Doctrina Christiana was a handbook that taught the native Tagalog the rudiments of the Catholic faith. The suggestion to issue a standard doctrina (doctrine) for the Tagalog was first broached during the Synod of Manila, 1582. In response to the synod’s mandate, a Tagalog translation of the doctrina was made by Fr Juan de Plasencia, OFM—deemed the most competent scholar of Tagalog—in collaboration with Miguel de Talavera. The draft was revised by Fr Juan de Oliver in keeping with criticisms of the work.

Because there was no press with movable metal types available, the text was printed with carved woodblocks, which were inked and impressed on fragile rice paper. This manner of printing, the xylographic method, was known to the Chinese in Manila who probably printed the text, as they did the Shih-lu (The Testimony of the True Religion), 1593, a text in Chinese expounding on the rudiments of Catholicism. The Doctrina Christiana was printed in the Dominican church of San Gabriel in Binondo. It was sold at two reales, a price considered expensive compared to books printed in Spain.

Copies of the Doctrina are extremely rare, as they were printed on fragile material and were probably printed as a limited edition. The Rosenwald collection acquired one such rare copy from a Paris bookseller, and the text was subsequently donated to the Library of Congress in Washington, DC, which published a facsimile edition in 1947.

The text begins with the Roman alphabet, then a syllabary, where different combinations of consonants and vowels are set side by side as a practice exercise for reading. The Our Father, the Hail Mary, the Creed, and Salve Regina—the most common Catholic prayers—are presented in Spanish and Tagalog, appearing both in Romanized transcriptions and the ancient Tagalog script. The articles of faith, the Decalogue, the commandments of the Church, the seven sacraments and the seven capital sins, the 14 works of mercy, and the Confiteor are also presented in Spanish and Tagalog. The Doctrina Christiana concludes with a short catechism on the most important teachings of the Catholic faith.

Aside from being the first book published in the native tongue, the book was also the prototype of other doctrines and of what later came to be known as caton. It gives us a glimpse of the old Tagalog script but, more importantly, it shows how Western ideas were introduced. The Doctrina Christiana also marks the beginning of the obsolescence of the old Tagalog script as Roman letters were used to take its place.   Written by Rene Javellana

 

Source

Quirino, Carlos, ed. 1973. Doctrina Christiana: The First Book Printed in the Philippines 1593. Manila: National Historical Commission.

article_title: Efemerides Filipinas
text:
(Philippine Almanac). Published 1911-12. Editors, Jaime de Veyra and Mariano Ponce. Serialized in El Ideal, 16 Mar 1911–15 Mar 1912. Reprinted, with a prologue by Epifanio de los Santos, Manila: Imprenta y Libreria de I. R. Morales, 1914. These articles were translated into Filipino by Edgardo M. Tiamson, Teresita A. Alcantara, and Edwin L. Bautista, annotated by Ma. Luisa T. Camagay, and published by the University of the Philippines Diliman’s Office of Research Coordination in 1998 using the original title.

Efemerides Filipinas is a series of articles on historical events with social or patriotic interest. A brainchild of Jaime de Veyra, the articles were published daily in the newspaper El Ideal. De Veyra had toyed with the idea of a society and its monthly magazine that would promote folklore. When this failed, he decided to undertake this monumental project.

For the project, de Veyra sought the help of many scholars, writers, and educators. However, except for Mariano Ponce who had written on Bulacan folklore, they did not share de Veyra’s enthusiasm. Nevertheless, Rafael Palma, Arsenio Luz, Rafael Corpus, and Epifanio de los Santos did contribute one article each; Leoncio Gonzalez Liquete, three. Writing alternately, de Veyra and Ponce provided the daily articles. De Veyra’s style was literary, whereas Ponce wrote in the clipped journalistic style of the press.

The first article, appearing on 16 Mar 1911, focused on the discovery of the Philippines by Fernando Magallanes in 1521. The last article, dated 15 Mar 1912, was a summons to folklorism. Generally, the topics revolved around history, folklore, customs and traditions, literature, and achievements of Filipinos, the goal of which was to counteract Americanization. Births and deaths of prominent Filipinos were recorded, as were the publication of new books, art-related affairs, commemorative and historical celebrations, official and social gatherings, and even volcanic eruptions.

Although El Ideal had no issues on Sundays or on holidays, the articles corresponding to those days were dutifully prepared in anticipation of its publication in book form. Reprinted, with a prologue by Epifanio de los Santos, Manila: Imprenta y Libreria de I. R. Morales, 1914. These articles were translated into Filipino by Edgardo M. Tiamson, Teresita A. Alcantara, and Edwin L. Bautista, annotated by Ma. Luisa T. Camagay, and published by the University of the Philippines Diliman’s Office of Research Coordination in 1998 using the original title.

Efemerides Filipinas is a series of articles on historical events with social or patriotic interest. A brainchild of Jaime de Veyra, the articles were published daily in the newspaper El Ideal. article_title: The Epistolary Criticism of Manuel A. Viray: In Memoriam
text:
Published 1998. Editor, L. M. Grow. Quezon City: Giraffe Books.

According to the book’s editor, literary criticism in the Philippines is “scarce”; there is a need for one to secure it wherever it is found, “even in unpublished documents.” Thus was born the book, a collection of “epistolary criticism” by poet Manuel A. Viray.

Grow excerpts from Viray’s letters, written between the 1950s and the 1990s, to Bienvenido Santos and to himself. The excerpts come with notes by Grow, mostly identifying the literary personalities that Viray mentions. The book also contains Viray’s poems that have not been previously published in any collection of Viray’s and which are alluded to in the letters.

One finds Viray’s views on N. V. M. Gonzalez, Ricaredo Demetillo, and Gregorio Brillantes, among other Filipino writers. Alejandrino G. Hufana’s Sickle Season, 1959, is the subject of what is virtually a full essay. Because they are meant to be private, the comments that one finds in the letters are more candid than they otherwise would be in a published work.

Grow’s notes amplify Viray’s comments by providing the supporting data, but in some cases, Grow takes exception to Viray’s view. The letters also tell readers what Viray had been reading.

The excerpts from the letters are too few and too random for one to arrive at a unified poetica, but one notes the recurrence of certain themes: the need for unity in a literary work, literature as an “illumination of human experience,” the artist’s “rage for order,” the problem of matching the matter with the manner, avoiding sentimentality and the baroque.

Viray’s letters to Santos have the extra interest of shedding light on Santos’s craft. For instance, in two letters, Viray takes up Santos’s story “The Day the Dancers Came.” He praises it (“a very good story”) but suggests a change in the story’s opening, observing that, while the story’s focus is Fil, its first sentence is about Fil and Tony. Apparently, Santos heeded Viray’s advice, and the story as it has come to be published starts with Fil. The process is mutual, for in several letters Viray asks Santos for his opinion on his (Viray’s) works. He also remarks on his own poetry, including the revision process.

Viray’s letters to Grow, written in the late 1980s and 1990s, inform readers about the later career of Viray as a poet and his opinions of his own work.

Because Viray was himself a writer, the letters were beautifully written, and he elaborates on ideas in literary fashion.

Viray wrote numerous essays in literary criticism in the 1950s, but these have yet to be collected. While those remain scattered in magazines and journals, one has at least Viray’s epistolary criticism, arguably only a small but illuminating fraction of his work.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: The Essential Arcellana
text:
Published 2002. Author, Francisco Arcellana. Editor, Alberto S. Florentino. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

In this posthumous collection, Alberto S. Florentino gathers together 2 poems, 10 essays and articles, and 9 short stories of the late National Artist Francisco Arcellana. These are accompanied by a reproduction of a holograph by Arcellana, a script on his life written by his son Juaniyo, and a review by Leonard Casper of The Francisco Arcellana Sampler, 1990, an earlier collection of Arcellana’s works, long out of print.

The two poems are presented as part of the book’s preliminaries, perhaps because Arcellana did not think highly of his own poetry. “Before Tertullian, After Him,” a reflection on the relationship between body and soul, and “Salon, Shalom,” a pastiche of passages from Shakespeare, T. S. Eliot, Jose Garcia Villa, and other writers.

The essays reveal Arcellana’s engagement in various literary questions, some of which continue to assert themselves, as the role of the artist in national politics or the distinction between prose and poetic discourses. Florentino’s selections, however, come from the 1950s onward, and thus skip over Arcellana’s contributions in the so-called Villa-Lopez controversy of the 1930s. But in essays like “MEA,” Arcellana’s tribute to Manuel Arguilla, and “The Filipino Writer and Political Action,” one can infer Arcellana’s stance in the debate, apparently one he continued taking after World War II. In the latter essay, one reads, “It is likely that it is the highest possible good to be useful: it is certain that it is less than good to be used or to allow oneself, wittingly or unwittingly, to be used.”

“Filipino Writing in English” and “American Influence in Philippine Literature” are Arcellana’s apologia for Philippine literature in English. The other essays are historical accounts of early Philippine literature in English. “Period of Emergence: The Short Story,” is a litany of significant writers and their works from the 1920s and 1930s. “The Carabao with Wings: A Study of Filipino Poetry in English” is both a critique of Thom Gunn’s critique of Jose Garcia Villa and a survey of Philippine poetry from the 1920s to the 1950s.

It is the short story, however, that is Arcellana’s métier. The selections, from the 1930s to the 1940s, show Arcellana’s profound understanding of love and death—his twin thematic obsessions—expressed in a distinct prose style, which is variously childlike, lyrical, and oracular. Two of the best stories explore the experience of grief in all its stark inexorability. In “The Mats,” a father brings home mats as presents for each of his children, but he brings three more with him, one for each of his dead children. The memento mori theme is repeated in “Flowers of May,” written 13 years later, where the festive backdrop of the May festival serves to heighten the sense of a family’s loss. As the children come home from picking flowers and the mother arranges them, the father shatters the mood by suddenly saying, “The flowers of May are gone. I saw that Victoria did not want to die. There was nothing I could do. There was nothing one could do.”

The other stories in the collection are “Trilogy of Turtles,” the earliest story in the collection, a lyrical account of a death; “The Yellow Shawl,” a harrowing recollection of World War II; “Divide by Two,” a subtle study of denial and projection, the tensions simmering beneath surfaces conveyed almost entirely through dialogue; and “Christmas Gift,” a specimen of the early Arcellana story featuring inarticulate, tremulous protagonists on the verge of a terrible insight.

Arcellana’s output may not be as voluminous as that of other writers, but neither is it less compelling. Until the Sampler and this book, his works in newspapers and magazines had been uncollected. Through The Essential Arcellana, Florentino ensures that another generation of Filipino readers can sample his art and see its merits.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: [Filipina]
text:
FILIPINA 1

Published 1984. Editors, Mila Astorga-Garcia, Marra PL. Lanot, and Lilia Quindoza-Santiago. With a foreword by Nick Joaquin and an introduction by Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

FILIPINA 2

Published 1985. Editors, Mila Astorga-Garcia, Marra PL. Lanot, and Lilia Quindoza-Santiago. With a foreword by Nick Joaquin and an introduction by Doreen G. Fernandez. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

These books are the first all-women anthologies of poetry, drama, essays, and short stories in Philippine book publishing history, fittingly launched during the International Decade of Women. The women writers represented in the anthologies belong to the Women Writers in Media Now or WOMEN, an organization formed in 1981 dedicated to supporting women writers by providing avenues for their works.

In the first volume, the writers include poets Denise Chou Allas, Marra PL. Lanot, Anna Leah de Leon, Babeth Lolarga, Migen L. Osorio, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, Aida F. Santos; playwright Sol Juvida; and fictionists Estrella Alfon, Lualhati Bautista, Joy T. Dayrit, Gilda Cordero-Fernando, Fanny A. Garcia, and Norma L. Japitana. Tarrosa-Subido notes in her introduction that their writings, most of which were produced in the 1970s, reveal concerns hitherto unmanifested in writings by women. These concerns are feminism, the problem of repatriates, ethnic connection, cohabitation, and social inequities. The free verse in the collection demonstrates that the poets are not concerned with the imperatives of rhyme and rhythm.

The second book is a collection of essays that have appeared in periodicals but have never been published in books. The writers included in this anthology are Mila Astorga-Garcia, Leonor J. Aureus, Arlene Babst, Sheila S. Coronel, Marites Danguilan-Vitug, Ma. Ceres P. Doyo, Sybilla Green-Dorros, Letty Jimenez-Magsanoc, Lorna Kalaw-Tirol, Jo-Ann Q. Maglipon, Sylvia L. Mayuga, Gemma Nemenzo-Almendral, Aida Sevilla-Mendoza, Cynthia Nograles-Lumbera, Fe L. Panaligan, Neni Sta. Romana-Cruz, Paulyn Sicam, Rochit I. Tañedo, Domini Torrevillas-Suarez, and Wilma D. Vitug. The essays deal with such topics as nuclear bombs, ancestral lands, sexism, myths about women, press freedom, and other current events.  Written by Neni Sta. Romana-Cruz

article_title: Filipinas dentro de Cien Aos
text:
(The Philippines within a Century). Published 1889-90. Author, Jose Rizal. Serialized in La Solidaridad, 30 Sep 1989–1 Feb 1890. Reprinted, Manila: Libreria Manila Filatelica, 1922. Filipino translation, Filipinas sa Loob ng Isang Daang Taon by Iñigo Ed. Regalado. Manila: Limbagan ng La Vanguardia, 1911. English translation, “The Philippines a Century Hence” by Charles Derbyshire, in Rizal’s Political Writings, edited by Austin Craig. Manila: Oriental Commercial Co., 1933; “The Philippines a Century Hence” by Guadalupe Fores-Ganzon in La Solidaridad, 2 volumes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1967.

Often mistranslated as “The Philippines a Century Hence,” the essay was originally run in four installments. With references to past historians like Antonio de Morga, Rizal’s essay contends that the Philippines was outgrowing its mother country Spain and that certain reforms were necessary if Spain was to keep her hold on the Philippines.

The essay begins with a rendering of history, emphasizing Spain’s colonial intrusion and the resulting destruction of native culture and values. Noting the sociopolitical developments in the Philippines and in the other Spanish colonies in Latin America, Rizal concludes that the Philippines will remain under Spanish dominion only if Filipinos are granted at least a measure of democratic rights. Otherwise, the Philippines will wrench herself away with much bloodshed. These rights are press freedom and representation in the Spanish Cortez. Rizal then claims that while Filipinos have things to be grateful to Spain for, they cannot be asked to forsake their aspirations for independence and, thereby, to be exiles in their own land.

Rizal refutes arguments against the granting of reforms in the colony with lucidity, embellishing his logic with touches of sardonic wit. For instance, to the objection raised by Salamanca, a Spanish reactionary, that Filipinos have an igorrote smell and thus should not be part of the Spanish parliament, Rizal replies with irony that Filipinos can give up their habit of bathing daily. To the other objection—the physiognomy and complexion of Filipinos—Rizal answers that beauty is relative. The Chinese, for example, generally regard Europeans as ugly. He adds, “El derecho no tiene piel; ni la razon narices” (Law has no skin nor reason nostrils).

In this essay, Rizal’s reformist cast of mind surfaces when he warns the Spanish authorities that change coming from below will be violent, but that change from above will be peaceful. Written by Ambeth R. Ocampo

article_title: The Filipinos in the Philippines and Other Essays
text:
Published 1966. Author, Renato Constantino. With an introduction by Lorenzo Tañada. Quezon City: Filipino Signatures.

This collection of eight essays, written between 1957 and 1966, suggests that the ills plaguing Philippine society—more particularly those that have to do with the consciousness that maintains the political and economic enslavement of the Filipinos—may be effectively remedied only through a nationalist reawakening.

The lead essay, “The Filipinos in the Philippines,” is a satirical account of the life of “the largest minority group in the Philippines”: the Filipinos. Its companion piece, “The Society Page,” notes the numerous deceits found in the society pages of newspapers. Both essays are highly perceptive, and they powerfully present through irony the insanity that informs the daily lives of Filipinos.

The most influential essay in the collection, “The Miseducation of the Filipino,” traces the historical roots of the Filipino colonial consciousness. “With American textbooks,” Constantino writes, “Filipinos started learning not only a new language but also a new way of life, alien to their traditions and yet a caricature of their model…. [It] was the beginning of their mis-education.” The companion essay is “Our Captive Minds,” which pursues the consequences of miseducation, the most important one of these being Filipino acquiescence in American conquest.

“The Corrupt Society” is concerned with Philippine backwardness. Constantino points out that corruption, which has always been associated with government, permeates every facet of national life. Both “The Filipino Politician” and “The Phony Society” deal with the ramifications of this general thesis. The corrupt politician not only is one who steals from government coffers, but also is one who has forgotten or refuses to acknowledge that the real political issue is that of economic independence.

The last essay of the collection, “Our Task: To Make Rizal Obsolete,” advances the already famous thesis that the conditions to which Rizal refers must be altered, so that his ideas will no longer have validity for our time.  Written by Luis Teodoro

article_title: El Folk-Lore Filipino
text:
(Philippine Folklore). Published 1994. Author, Isabelo de los Reyes. Translators, Salud C. Dizon and Maria Elinora P. Imson. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Gintong Aklat Award for social science.

El Folk-Lore Filipino is a two-volume work of folklore materials that Isabelo de los Reyes compiled, retold, amplified, wrote, and originally published in Manila in 1889 and 1890. According to the translators of this edition, de los Reyes set out to collect folklore to prove that the natives were already civilized even before the Spanish colonizers came to their shores. His book groups folklore materials from the provinces of Ilocos Sur, Zambales, and Malabon.

In his introduction, de los Reyes explains the need for gathering accurate information; he then provides an overview of the scientific bases of folklore. He asserts that the work of collecting popular knowledge is a patriotic duty. In the short note that follows, “Folklore Terminology,” he problematizes the Western scholars’ use of the term “folklore” and makes two important statements that shed light on his own stance as a scholar: First, he calls himself a “brother of the forest dwellers,” or the Filipino peoples that have not been totally reached by Spanish rule. Second, he asserts that such a project that he is undertaking should “limit the use of foreign words” and the “tendency to overuse them.” Hence, his work uses native terms extensively and leaves them untranslated.

article_title: Fray Botod
text:
(Friar Potbelly). Published 1891. Author, Graciano Lopez Jaena. Included in Discursos y Articulos Varios (Discourses and Various Articles), Barcelona: Imprenta Iberica de Francisco Fossas. Reprinted, Manila: Bureau of Printing, 1951. English translation, “Fray Botod” by Encarnacion Alzona in Graciano Lopez Jaena: Speeches, Articles and Letters, edited and annotated by Teodoro A. Agoncillo, Manila: National Historical Commission, 1974.

This is Lopez Jaena’s best-known satirical work. Written as a dialogue between a newcomer to the Philippines and someone, presumably the author, who has lived long in the isles, the satirical intent is seen in the text’s subtitle, “Estudios al Natural” (Studies of Nature), a parody of pseudo-ethnographic sketches of the indio or native, beginning with the unflattering image of Fray Gaspar de San Agustin.

Fray Botod, the fictional villain, is an embodiment of the corrupt friar. He is said to be an Augustinian monk, born of unknown parents from Aragon, who joined the Augustinian convent at Valladolid, to be able to live a rich man’s life in the Philippines. In Iloilo, Botod lives out the life of a corrupt potentate. His every need, including the carnal, is served by helpless young girls who have been sent by their poor parents to live in his convento (parish house). Besides being a glutton and a drunkard, he is a gambler addicted to monte, a card game, and cockfighting. He interferes in local politics, recruits free labor to repair his parish, punishes barbarously, lends at usurious rates through a method called alili, and treats his Filipino coadjutor, Padre Marcelino, as a pariah, forbidding him from entering the convento. Botod charges atrocious stole fees and neglects the sick. He leaves much of his parish work to Padre Marcelino. However, when a function brings in much money, Botod is quick to volunteer.

The tract takes on a pseudoscientific air when Lopez Jaena quotes extensively from Jacolliot’s Viaje al Pais de las Bayaderas (Journey to the Land of the Bayaderes), in which is described the life of the bayaderes, young maidens committed to dance in the temples of India, under the sway of the Brahmins. Lopez Jaena draws parallels between the Brahmins’ sexually abusive treatment of the bayaderes and Fray Botod’s treatment of the young maidens he calls his canding canding, goat kids. Padre Marcelino, the coadjutor, receives scant praise from Lopez Jaena, as he too is prone to drinking gin and tuba, the result of Fray Botod’s bad example.

Lopez Jaena has created a character out of what Marcelo H. del Pilar and other propagandists merely described. The caricature he creates of the corrupt friar is reflected in subsequent generations’ picture of the villainous man-of-the-cloth.  Written by Rene Javellana

article_title: Hagkus: Twentieth-Century Bikol Women Writers
text:
(Girdle: Twentieth-Century Bikol Women Writers). Published 2003. Author, Paz Verdades M. Santos. With a foreword by Teresita Erestain. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

Hagkus is an anthology of fiction, poetry, drama, literary essays, and biographies by over three generations of Bikol women, whether they write in Bikol, English, or Filipino. Santos analyzes the texts within a feminist framework and in the context of the Bikol cultural tradition. As a “literary herstory,” it preserves an important part of Bikol literary tradition.

Santos uses a traditional postpartum girdle called hagkus in Bicol as a metaphor for the “Bikol woman writer’s evolving consciousness through the different literary periods of the twentieth century.” She notes that the first two generations of women writing in the early years of the 20th century were babaying nagtatangis (weeping women), tightly bound by the hagkus of colonialism and patriarchy, although those writing in the 1950s were beginning to question its necessity.

Nationalist, democratic, and feminist ideals helped Bikol women writers in the 1970s to free themselves and then use the hagkus to bind themselves to one another in solidarity. The emergent writers expanded it to include new concerns.

Hagkus is a pioneering anthology that presents future research directions for Bikol literature. Among the questions Santos poses is whether “Ina,” or mother, which Bikolanos call the regional patroness Virgin of Peñafrancia, figures more in the writing of Bikol men than in those of Bikol women.

Nominated for the National Book Award in literary history in 2004, Hagkus is an invaluable contribution to Bikol studies in that it is the first book to focus on women writing from the Bicol region. Little-known texts written by women are now made accessible to scholars and students of Bikol and Philippine literature.   Written by M. A. Margate Jr

article_title: Himalay: Kalipunan ng Mga Pag-aaral Kay Balagtas
text:
(Gleanings: Anthology of Studies on Balagtas). Published 1988. Editors, Patricia Melendrez-Cruz and Apolonio Bayani Chua. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Himalay is an anthology that gathers together for the first time the most significant studies on Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar, acknowledged to be the major influence on Philippine literature in the local languages. Arranged chronologically, the critical texts, originally published in journals or as parts of books, show the different ways in which Balagtas and his writings have been approached by various Filipino scholars and critics from the early 1900s to the 1960s.

The 11 essays in the anthology may be classified into two categories: the traditional and the modern. The essays belonging to the first category are the pioneering Kun Sino ang Kumatha ng “Florante” (On Who Authored Florante) by Hermenegildo Cruz, which was the first attempt to explain Balagtas by dealing with the poet’s biography and the historical context of the poem; “Balagtas y su Florante” (Balagtas and His Florante) by Epifanio de los Santos, which speculates on how the poet and his poem could have been perceived by their original readers and listeners; “Ang Apat na Himagsik ni Francisco Balagtas” (The Four Revolts of Francisco Balagtas), which analyzes the historical forces that could have conditioned Balagtas’s poem; “Sa Isang Madilim: Si Balagtas sa Kanyang Panahon” (In Obscurity: Balagtas in His Times) by Teodoro A. Agoncillo, which is a political interpretation of the poem; and “Matayutay ang Florante” (Figurative Language Abounds in Florante) by Fernando B. Monleon, which is a textual study, following traditional methods to describe the poet’s various metaphors.

Where the above-mentioned essays generally lack some kind of framework through which the text is seen, the modern essays seem to exhibit more rigor insofar as conceptualization of key issues is concerned. Bienvenido Lumbera’s “Florante at Laura: The Formalization of Tradition” is a formalist analysis of Balagtas’s poem. Epifanio San Juan’s “Balagtas: Art and Revolution” and Lucila Hosillos’s “Florante at Laura: A Transcendence of Romance and Allegory”—interpretations rooted in a more sociological-historical perspective—are a counterpoint to Lumbera’s analysis. Buenaventura Medina Jr’s “Balagtas: The Passion Defined” shows the critic’s indebtedness to sociological and psychological approaches. Patricia Melendrez-Cruz’s “Mga Tapyas ng Brilyanteng FloranteatLaura” (Facets of Florante and Laura the Diamond) presents three ways of analyzing the poem: aesthetic, archetypal, and ideological.

Himalay also includes an essay on “Kay Celia” (To Celia), a poem Balagtas prefaced to Florante at Laura, called “What Is Balagtas’ ‘To Celia’ All About? An Experiment in Interpretation” by E. San Juan Jr. A bibliography of the different editions of Florante at Laura, translations of the poem into various languages, and the different studies made on it is appended to the book.

To date, it remains the most comprehensive index to the literary theories that Filipino critics and scholars used in the first half of the 20th century to tackle what is often considered the major secular narrative poem of the 19th century.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Himalay: Kalipunan ng Mga Pag-aaral Kay Jose Rizal
text:
(Gleanings: Anthology of Studies on Jose Rizal). Published 1991. Editors, Patricia Melendrez-Cruz and Apolonio Bayani Chua. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

This second volume in a series called Himalay is in celebration of the centennial of Jose Rizal’s second novel, El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891, and that of the decade of Filipino nationalism, 1890-1900.

Among Filipino authors, Rizal has generated the greatest number of critical works, especially on his two novels, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, and Fili. Arranged chronologically, the 32 works in the anthology give the reader a historical perspective of the various ways in which Rizal’s two novels have been read from 1887 to 1991.

The first article is a letter from Rizal presumably to Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, in which he enumerates his aims in writing the Noli: to expose the hypocrisies of the members of the Church and the corruption of government officials, and to criticize his own fellow citizens for their own cowardice and folly. An exchange of letters between him and friends Antonio Regidor, Evaristo Aguirre, Eduardo de Lete, and Ferdinand Blumentritt reveals the critical concerns of the period: realism as defined by the reader’s familiarity with character types and situations in the novel; aesthetic effect, such as that produced by language proper to character and setting while at the same time avoiding triteness, crudeness, or vulgarity; and the ideas expressed in the novel. Using the criterion of truthfulness, articles written by Marcelo H. del Pilar and Ferdinand Blumentritt and an open letter by V. Caraig (pseud. of Vicente Garcia) defend the novel against charges that it is heretical and subversive.

Other readings either find the novel wanting in the fulfillment of the reader’s expectations or bring to light the many layers of the novel’s meaning. Graciano Lopez Jaena’s letter to Rizal, in which he faults the Fili for its despairing conclusion, suggests that a revolutionary or radical view would have been more desirable. On the other hand, Spanish philosopher and fictionist Miguel de Unamuno interweaves intertextual, philosophical, psychological, biographical, and political readings. The historical perspective is used by Claro M. Recto and Renato Constantino to compare Rizal’s and Andres Bonifacio’s heroism, and by Teodoro A. Agoncillo to analyze Rizal’s attitude toward the impending Philippine revolution. Rafael Palma compares the novels’ characters with Filipino stereotypes. Cesar A. Majul uses political philosophy to define the concept of “national sentiment” through the novels.

Criticism on Rizal’s works in the past 30 years has been guided by a variety of approaches: sociological, anthropological, psychological, and political as well as formalist. Alfredo T. Morales focuses on the imagery of the two novels; Ante Radaic identifies their romantic and realist elements; Petronilo Bn. Daroy explicates characterization with the use of ideas culled from various fields; Jose Ma. Sison focuses on the novels’ subversive quality and applies it to present-day reality. Buenaventura S. Medina Jr surveys the various works of Rizal and sheds some light on Rizal’s third novel, the Tagalog Makamisa. Resil B. Mojares demonstrates how Rizal’s works were products of both native and European literary traditions. Prospero Covar and Reynaldo C. Ileto focus on the effect of Rizal on the masses—the former, by studying the Rizal millenarian movement, and the latter, by analyzing the masses’ interpretation of Rizal as their mythical savior or Tagalog king. Close readings of texts are done by Epifanio San Juan Jr and Lucila Hosillos, whereas Vivencio Jose locates the Noli as a historical novel within the Philippine narrative tradition. The last critical essay, by Albina Pecson Fernandez, uses the critical method of materialist criticism as defined by British theorist Terry Eagleton.

This anthology is significant for bringing together the range of perspectives and critical approaches used in the study of Rizal and his works. Also useful is the “Selected Rizaliana Bibliography,” divided into three parts: Rizal’s original works and their translations; studies on Rizal and his works; and related works, consisting of anthologies, travelogues, and transmutations.   Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Homenaje a Luna
text:
(Homage to Luna). Delivered as a speech, 1887. Author, Graciano Lopez Jaena. Included in Discursos y Articulos Varios (Discourses and Various Articles). Barcelona: Imprenta de Iberia de Francisco Fossas. Reprinted, Manila: Bureau of Printing, 1951. English translation, “Homage to Luna” by Encarnacion Alzona in Graciano Lopez Jaena: Speeches, Articles and Letters, edited and annotated by Teodoro A. Agoncillo. Manila: National Historical Commission, 1974.

This speech was delivered during the launching of Juan Luna’s painting, La Batalla de Lepanto (The Battle of Lepanto). The painting depicts the Spanish victory over the far more numerous Turks in Lepanto in 1571. The naval engagement involved 447 galleys and the death of 30,000 Turks. The painting was commissioned by Spanish government, and it adorns the wall of the main stairway of the Senate building in Madrid.

The speech commences with references to Spain and to the painter Rosales. As Lopez Jaena speaks about Luna’s genius, he also speaks up against Spanish contempt for Filipino ability. He recalls how Filipinos have been called “pigmeos, de poco acumen intelectual, ineptos para el progreso, como incapaces para las ciencias” (pygmies of little acumen, unfit for progress, for sciences); and retorts, “Los individuos pigmeos, señores, no crecen; los pueblos pigmeos, en cambio con el tiempo se hacen gigantes” (Individuals who are pygmies, gentlemen, do not grow; on the other hand, pygmy nations in time become giants). He then cites Luna as proof. The problem is that Filipinos are at the mercy “de la teocracia opresora y de la burocracia explotadora” (of an oppressive theocracy and an exploitative bureaucracy). What Filipinos need in their stead is representation in the Spanish Cortez, freedom of press and worship, commerce and industry. The speech reaches a climax when Lopez Jaena says of Luna: “No pidais en las obras de Luna bellezas (permitidme la expression) afeminadas; Luna no ha nacido para eso: pedid a su pincel lo cruel, lo terrible, lo horroroso” (Do not look for the effeminate [pardon the expression] beauties in the works of Luna; Luna was not born for that; rather look for the cruel, the terrible, the horrifying).  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

article.value: (Homage to Luna). Delivered as a speech, 1887. Author, Graciano Lopez Jaena. Included in Discursos y Articulos Varios (Discourses and Various Articles). Barcelona: Imprenta de Iberia de Francisco Fossas. Reprinted, Manila: Bureau of Printing, 1951. English translation, “Homage to Luna” by Encarnacion Alzona in Graciano Lopez Jaena: Speeches, Articles and Letters, edited and annotated by Teodoro A. Agoncillo. Manila: National Historical Commission, 1974.

This speech was delivered during the launching of Juan Luna’s painting, La Batalla de Lepanto (The Battle of Lepanto). The painting depicts the Spanish victory over the far more numerous Turks in Lepanto in 1571. The naval engagement involved 447 galleys and the death of 30,000 Turks. The painting was commissioned by Spanish government, and it adorns the wall of the main stairway of the Senate building in Madrid.

The speech commences with references to Spain and to the painter Rosales. As Lopez Jaena speaks about Luna’s genius, he also speaks up against Spanish contempt for Filipino ability. He recalls how Filipinos have been called “pigmeos, de poco acumen intelectual, ineptos para el progreso, como incapaces para las ciencias” (pygmies of little acumen, unfit for progress, for sciences); and retorts, “Los individuos pigmeos, señores, no crecen; los pueblos pigmeos, en cambio con el tiempo se hacen gigantes” (Individuals who are pygmies, gentlemen, do not grow; on the other hand, pygmy nations in time become giants). He then cites Luna as proof. The problem is that Filipinos are at the mercy “de la teocracia opresora y de la burocracia explotadora” (of an oppressive theocracy and an exploitative bureaucracy). What Filipinos need in their stead is representation in the Spanish Cortez, freedom of press and worship, commerce and industry. The speech reaches a climax when Lopez Jaena says of Luna: “No pidais en las obras de Luna bellezas (permitidme la expression) afeminadas; Luna no ha nacido para eso: pedid a su pincel lo cruel, lo terrible, lo horroroso” (Do not look for the effeminate [pardon the expression] beauties in the works of Luna; Luna was not born for that; rather look for the cruel, the terrible, the horrifying).  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

article_title: House of Memory
text:
Published 1997. Author, Resil B. Mojares. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This is a collection of Mojares’s essays, most of which first saw print in his column "Footnotes to an Absent Text" in 1989-96. The pieces are thematically grouped according to parts of a house: “Door,” “Foyer,” “Grand Hall,” “Corners and Corridors,” “Gallery,” “Refectory,” “Study,” “Anterooms,” and “Private Rooms.”

The sole essay in “Door” states that the book “is not a house built according to plan.” It explains the makeshift structure of the book, indicating that its purpose, like that of a house, is to create meaning out of the space that its materials enclose. Herein, too, lies its craft.

“Foyer” presents the author’s creative process and articulates his reason for keeping a column (“Writing a Column”)—that articulating a thought is laying claim to it (“Casting Stones into the Sea”), despite the elusive nature of memory—as a way of “keeping what time (and, worse, inattention) erodes.”

“Grand Hall” contains sprawling narratives commonly stricken out of textbooks, such as the powerful role that pre-Hispanic women played in matters of sex (“Visayan Erotica”) and the validation of the human body by our ancestors before anything that is flesh was reconditioned as “evil.” Mojares reconsiders history from the point of view of the native’s system of beliefs instead of the colonizer's. An example is the animist concept of souls versus the Christian concept of the singular spirit in search of its union with God. In the same section, Mojares unearths lost native traditions, like the ways time was measured sans the calendar and clock; musical instruments that now exist only in old texts; and the art of navigation.

The section “Corners and Corridors” unravels the layered meanings of words and names. “The Weightlessness of Words” explores the alternatives to the alphabet, concluding that the weight of words lies not in the objects they represent but in their correct usage. This tenet is expounded in the section’s succeeding essays on loosely associated topics, like the names parents give their children and the terms employed for marking harvest and for drawing new territories.

The section “Gallery” has commentaries on sociopolitical affairs, mostly those in Cebu. “The Art of the Insult” is a parodic enumeration of the ways by which the city mayor and the governor could better sling mud at each other. “The Art of the Exposé,” a piece spurred by then-senator Ernesto Maceda being dubbed as Mr Exposé, is a tongue-in-cheek exposition of whistleblowing as a democratic act.

The two essays in “Refectory” are anthropological meditations on our dietary and drinking habits. “Study” contains sundry essays, such as the author’s account of his fellowship at the Rockefeller Center and his advice to young writers at the Faigao Writers Workshop in 1995.

“Anteroom” is the writer’s diary. He chronicles his years growing up in a public school and the impact of Jose Rizal on his family’s life, especially on his parents who were high school teachers. The essays are also snapshots of his pet-keeping and child-rearing. The author turns confessional in “Private Rooms,” relating his grief over his parents’ death and writing postscripts to his eulogy for them.

House of Memory delivers what the title promises: by remembering the past and recollecting discarded thoughts about it, Mojares builds a sense of home.  Written by Julian dela Cerna

article_title: In Another Light: Poems and Essays
text:
Published 1978. Author, Gemino Abad. With an introduction by Francisco Arcellana. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This collection of poems and critical essays is the first to offer a fully worked-out poetics and to attempt to use the Chicago neo-Aristotelian method of literary criticism in analyzing Philippine poetry. Abad in his preface reveals two primal sources of his poetry and poetics: Wallace Stevens as a poet and Elder Olson as a critic. In Stevens, Abad sees a “gaiety of language, as the finest form of the joy of living, as the finest form also of the art of perception.” In Olsen, Abad appreciates the critic’s “attempt to see the poem (any literary work) by its own light.”

The first part of the book is devoted to poems, which include some of his well-known works: “Islander in the Yard,” “The Moon and the Prisoner,” “Impressions of a Guitarist,” “Baby, Cradle and All,” “A Study of River Politics,” “Ariel Must Be Green,” “Three Poems for My Father,” and “The Archipelago of Our Words.” A brief essay prefaces this section, which explains his poetry, his approach to the writing of it, and his theory of how to read and appreciate a poem. His primary concern is to capture “the-poem-of-it” in any material—whether it be an idea, event, or another piece of writing—that he transforms into a poem. He cannot, however, define what poetry is, “because, in the light of any possible subject, there is always one more possible poem-of-it.” There is an explicit caveat against doctrinal rigidity in literary criticism: we “quickly forget, in our enthusiasm or commitment to a particular disclosure of poetry, that there are other disclosures.” If one were to demand some politics in Abad’s aesthetics, it would be expressed in this way: “No artist is free or can grow in depth or stature without … appreciation and respect for other orientations of mind, other realms of sensibility, other politics, other mysticisms.”

The second part consists of 11 critical essays. Although Abad rejects the notion that he is setting up a theory of poetry, he does not fail to set up the framework through which he means to analyze the text. Abad asserts that “the Aristotelian idea of imitation or mimesis … remains a valid and fruitful concept.” Furthermore, no reading of any work can ever be complete without some account taken of its genre or its “form,” its “specific literary kind,” its “poetic species.” Criticism on the lyric poem can focus on what it imitates (its object), how it imitates (its manner and means), and what it achieves (its effect). Abad gives a useful short example of his approach in the introduction to the essay on two poems of Carlos Angeles.

In excellent studies of American and British poems, such as Robert Frost’s “Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening,” Ezra Pound’s “In a Station of the Metro,” T. S. Eliot’s “Aunt Helen,” Emily Dickinson’s “The Last Night That She Lived,” W. H. Auden’s “Musee des Beaux Artes,” Richard Eberhart’s “The Groundhog,” and others, Abad shows that “formal” criticism of this kind does yield invaluable insights into structure and meaning.  Written by Isagani R. Cruz and Soledad Reyes

article_title: Intertext
text:
Published 1990. Author, Edel E. Garcellano. With an introduction by Nemesio E. Prudente. Manila: Kalikasan Press.

This book is a collection of eight critical and theoretical essays on writers, critics, and theoreticians in the Philippines and in Europe. The concluding paragraph of Garcellano’s first essay, “A Way of Reading for the ’80s,” expresses the thesis of this book: “All readings must therefore lead to constant re-reading of all texts, the subversion thereby of the Great Books canon.” In this same essay, Garcellano focuses on Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat’s “Tata Selo” (Old Man Selo) to demonstrate the way of reading that he suggests. He summarizes the critiques made by Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Bienvenido L. Lumbera, and Edilberto Alegre on “Tata Selo.” Daroy observes that the naturalistic stories of such Tagalog short story writers as Rogelio Sikat, Edgar Reyes, and others, though representing the reality of the lower class, were actually mere “pseudo-revolts,” because they did not “define an anti-colonial text.” Garcellano describes Lumbera’s reading of the story as being based on formalist aesthetics, while Alegre uses linguistic analysis of the class conflict portrayed in the story.

Garcellano observes that the general hermeneutic code of the story makes Tata Selo seem the model of agrarian injustice, with land as the object of conflict. As such, he is popularly viewed as a victim and underdog. However, Garcellano points out that the story is actually a portrait of feudal relations that are basically patriarchal/phallogocentric. In the same essay, Garcellano describes Gabriel Garcia-Marquez’s One Hundred Years of Solitude as a novel “whose politics complements First World predilection for exotica, mystification, erasure, neo-colonization.”

In another essay, Garcellano posits that a writer’s discourse is determined by neither metaphysical nor neutral interests but by class, race, and gender. “Post-EDSA Literature and Marxist Discourse” refutes some critics’ view that Benigno Aquino Jr’s assassination marked “a new epoch in Philippine literature” or “a dialectical political shift” for such writers as Cirilo Bautista, Gemino Abad, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, and others. On the contrary, the works of writers “who worked with the masses,” such as Levy Balgos dela Cruz, Tomas Agulto, Jason Montana, Kris Montañez, and others are “consciously silent” on the valorization of Aquino as “Christian savior.”

The other essays include metacriticisms of Mila Aguilar’s critique of an anthology of grassroots literature, Kalipunan ng mga Akda ng Anak-Pawis (Anthology of the Works of the Working Class), and of Virgilio Almario’s review of an anthology of works titled Gatilyo (Trigger) by the members of Galian sa Arte at Tula. “The Filipino as Critic in a Time of War” concludes with some reminders for the critic, foremost of which is “that ours is a society under siege, whose text Washington DC writes and rewrites.”  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Intsik: An Anthology of Chinese-Filipino Writing
text:
Published 2000. Editor, Caroline S. Hau. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

The stories, poems, essays, and teleplay in this anthology are a testimony of Chinese Filipino writers’ perspectives, learnings, and experiences as Chinese living in the Philippines. The struggles of these Chinese Filipino writers are strongly evident in this collection as their knowledge, traditions, beliefs, and principles are constantly challenged even by their compatriots.

The family is the axis around which many of the stories turn. In Benito Lim’s “The Burial,” the return of Hsin to attend his grandfather’s funeral reveals a long-standing family problem of living with undesirable relatives. In Charlson Ong’s “Mismanagement of Grief,” the wake becomes a venue for the family to wash their dirty linen in public as they express their own grudges against one another. In Grace Pe-Bacani’s “Starting Over” and Gad S. Lim’s “Sunday Dinner,” family members defy tradition in the process of dealing with pressure and indifference to each other. Paul Stephen Lim’s “Taking Flight” is also about being oppressed by the rules and expectations of one’s family. Wing, the narrator, studies abroad in the hope of getting away from his parents’ watchful eyes.

Two stories dramatize opposite views on the relations among Chinese Filipinos. In Ricardo Lee’s “Huwag! Huwag Mong Kukuwentuhan ang Batang si Wei-Fung!” (Don’t! Don’t Tell Stories to a Child like Wei-Fung!), Wei-Fung is deceived by his own adopted son Beng-Hua—a departure from the usual theme of a Chinese being deceived by a Filipino. On the other hand, Tian-Huay Q. Tan’s “Spring Wind Blows Immensely at the Nipa Hut” recounts the cooperation among the Filipino Chinese during World War II as they helped each other escape the atrocities of the Japanese Imperial Army.

In Jaime An Lim’s “The Homing Mandarin, or After the First Death There Are Others,” a patriarch leaves his second family in the Philippines to return to his first wife and family in China. Chinese males like him migrated from China to seek refuge from the political turmoil, but they return to their homeland because of alienation and homesickness.

The theme of alienation is also evident in the poems. In “Upon My Father’s Calligraphy” by Ma. Fatima V. Lim, “A Late Afternoon Visit to Manila’s Chinese Cemetery” by Wilson Lee Flores, “Grandmother” by Alice M. Sun-Cua, “Tatlong Tula ng Tsinoy” (Three Poems of a Chinese Filipino) by Joaquin Sy, and “Much Later” by Lilia N. Lopez-Chua, the personae are outsiders struggling to preserve their Chinese heritage. They are plagued by self-doubt, insecurity, and fear of the unknown.

“The Calligrapher” by Fran Ng, “Not Only Knives” by Bliss Cua Lim, and “Irreconcilable Differences” by Roel Hoang Manipon give contrary responses to the duality experienced by Chinese Filipinos. The personae in the first two poems immerse themselves in their Chinese beliefs and customs in order to feel more grounded despite living in a foreign land. In Manipon’s poem, the Chinese Filipino desires to break free from the dictates of tradition.

The essays replay the themes of displacement and struggling to find one’s place: “Growing Up Chinese in the Philippines” by Jacqueline Co, “Where I Came From” by Doreen Yu, and “W.A.S.P.” by Jonathan Chua. “Both Sides Now” by Michael L. Tan raises two problems: being a Chinese Filipino at the height of political turmoil and being a gay Chinese Filipino in the Philippines.

The teleplay Pula (Red) by Jun Lana and Pete Ong Lim also elaborates on the issue of homosexuality in the Chinese Filipino community. A patriarch copes with the knowledge of his deceased gay son’s past.

The anthology stresses the difficulties of being a Filipino of Chinese descent: the need to always remember one’s roots, integrate with the present, and adjust to a foreign land. It illustrates the persistence of Sinophobic myths and attitudes. The anthology reclaims the label“Intsik” and strips it of its demeaning connotations.  Written by Jeffrey Yap

article_title: Isabelo's Archive
text:
Published 2013. Author, Resil B. Mojares. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This book is a mixed collection of “essays, vignettes, extracts, and notes on Philippine history and culture.” Some of the essays were originally read at conferences and seminars or were previously published.

In the title essay, “Isabelo’s Archive,” Mojares asserts that Isabelo de los Reyes’s El Folk-Lore Filipino (Philippine Folklore), 1889, was a key moment in the collection of knowledge about the Philippines and in the birth of “Philippine studies.” It was in content a “hodge-podge of miscellaneous items” and in form open-ended. By these very qualities, however, did the book make available heretofore inaccessible and incomplete materials—the lore of the people instead of official knowledge—and so move toward its goals of “understanding and reconstructing scientifically the history and culture of a people.”

Taking off from de los Reyes, Mojares exhumes interesting precolonial and colonial tales, such as those about head-hunting and notions of shame; and about the writings of Jose Rizal, Mariano Ponce, and Gabriel Beato Francisco.

The transformation of the social, political, economic, cultural, and spiritual lives of Filipinos under colonial rule is a dominant theme of the collection. In “Maidens Shrouded in Darkness” and “A Woman Named Virgin Mary,” Mojares sketches the transformation of native women, from being lively epic chanters to being meek and mournful copies of the Virgin Mary, from being a “binukot” in a secluded space to being a nun in the cloister. Similarly, essays like “Densities of Time,” “Remembering the Body,” “The Arithmetica of Rufino Baltazar,” and “The Traveling Filipino” all show the effects of colonialism on, respectively, the local sense of time and space, the body and dance, counting, and travel.

Mojares shows, however, that the transformation wrought by colonialism cuts both ways. “Isabelo’s Almanac,” “Ilocanizing Verdi,” and “Notes for the Production of a Brechtian Komedya” explain how the European forms like the almanac can be localized and made to speak on the native’s behalf, as a means of social and political criticism.

The collection also reveals Mojares’s interest in the “unwritten, unfinished, fantastical, fictitious, and apocryphal” stories and events of Philippine history and culture. These stories, lost from the collective memory of the people, are generative of new knowledge and ideas. “Tales of Manilamen” digs up accounts of Filipino seafarers, like Vicente B. Macanaya, whose career as aide-de-camp of the American buccaneer Frederick Townsend Ward is nothing short of “cinematic.” In “Musica Moralia,” Mojares recounts the touching story of a Filipino band performing loud and vigorous music for fellow Filipinos throughout the Spanish attack in Lian, Batangas. “A Poem of All the Names of the Rivers” depicts the struggles of the Subanens (or the “river people” inhabiting the Zamboanga peninsula) against deforestation, land-grabbing, and the incursions of outsiders and the state.

The most intriguing piece in the collection is “The Book That Did Not Exist.” The Augustinian botanist Manuel Blanco is said to have holed himself up in his cell to write on the history and character of the indio (native). When Blanco died, the book that he was supposedly laboring on was found to contain nothing but blank pages. Mojares proposes several interpretations: the blank pages may suggest that the natives are a tabula rasa, or that there was so much about the natives that the Spaniards did not know. They may also imply that this country remains underwritten and under-theorized.

Mojares’s collection creates the archive on which one may draw in order to fill the gaps in the Philippine precolonial and colonial history. The product of copious research that is presented in a light-handed but elegant and literary style, Isabelo’s Archive is a valuable and rich source not only for researchers, scholars, academicians, and students in Philippine studies but also for creative writers and general readers.  Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos

article.value: Published 2013. Author, Resil B. Mojares. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This book is a mixed collection of “essays, vignettes, extracts, and notes on Philippine history and culture.” Some of the essays were originally read at conferences and seminars or were previously published.

In the title essay, “Isabelo’s Archive,” Mojares asserts that Isabelo de los Reyes’s El Folk-Lore Filipino (Philippine Folklore), 1889, was a key moment in the collection of knowledge about the Philippines and in the birth of “Philippine studies.” It was in content a “hodge-podge of miscellaneous items” and in form open-ended. By these very qualities, however, did the book make available heretofore inaccessible and incomplete materials—the lore of the people instead of official knowledge—and so move toward its goals of “understanding and reconstructing scientifically the history and culture of a people.”

Taking off from de los Reyes, Mojares exhumes interesting precolonial and colonial tales, such as those about head-hunting and notions of shame; and about the writings of Jose Rizal, Mariano Ponce, and Gabriel Beato Francisco.

The transformation of the social, political, economic, cultural, and spiritual lives of Filipinos under colonial rule is a dominant theme of the collection. In “Maidens Shrouded in Darkness” and “A Woman Named Virgin Mary,” Mojares sketches the transformation of native women, from being lively epic chanters to being meek and mournful copies of the Virgin Mary, from being a “binukot” in a secluded space to being a nun in the cloister. Similarly, essays like “Densities of Time,” “Remembering the Body,” “The Arithmetica of Rufino Baltazar,” and “The Traveling Filipino” all show the effects of colonialism on, respectively, the local sense of time and space, the body and dance, counting, and travel.

article_title: Ka Amado
text:
(Comrade Amado). Published 2012. Author, Jun Cruz Reyes. With a foreword by Ramon Guillermo. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This book is a reconstruction of the life and times of Amado V. Hernandez, a subject that Reyes considers fitting for a new Tagalog epic. In his foreword, Guillermo describes the biography as a necessary work that reintroduces the legendary writer to the masses to whom he had devoted his life and art.

At the core of this reintroduction is the biographer’s interrogation of who controls the discourse on the life of Hernandez. Reyes’s introductory essay, “Ang Pangangapa” (Groping), recounts how he faced the discursive and political complexities of biographical representation, particularly because he wanted to contextualize the writer’s life and relate it to the issues of nationalism, history, and literature.

The book is divided into three parts. The first part, “Ang Paghahanap” (The Search) recounts the biographer’s foray into the genealogical, geographical, ethnological, and literary jungles. Beginning with his search for the lost bust of Hernandez in his hometown Hagonoy, Reyes traces the writer’s lineage to the first poet of the clan, Lakandula, and to nationalist writers from Bulacan like Marcelo H. del Pilar and Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar. The affinities among them are furthered strengthened in his discussion of the poetics of wit and sorrow in Hernandez and the tradition of grief and satire in local literature. Reyes claims Hernandez as a son of his hometown Hagonoy. He intercuts this genealogical discovery with an account of his own plight as a writer haunted by the specter of state terrorism.

The second part, “Ang Pagsusulat sa Nahanap” (Writing the Discovered), is a multilayered narration of Hernandez’s life, from his birth in Tondo in 1903 to his death in 1970. Reyes chronicles Hernandez’s engagement with the political upheavals of his time from Hernandez’s beginnings as a young writer enamored of provincial life and the idea of the barrio lass as ideal woman to his eventual transformation as the poet of the working class. The narrative recounts the writer’s early pacifist and pragmatist leanings, his participation as a spy for the American forces during World War II, his radicalization in the labor movement, his imprisonment and eventual canonization by the state, and his engagement with the younger revolutionaries of the First Quarter Storm era. Against the historical backdrop of Hernandez’s political awakening, Reyes paints a passionate portrait of the writer’s marriage with Honorata “Atang” de la Rama, who supported him in his political activities.

In the last part, “Ang Pagbasa sa Naisulat” (Reading the Written), Reyes returns to his search for the lost monument. Discovering that the man himself is the monument, he ruminates on the need for one to situate Hernandez’s life within the project of imagining the nation and to write more biographies as an antidote to historical amnesia. Toward the end of the biography, Reyes succeeds not only in finding the lost bust but also in reconstructing the monument upon the very platform on which Hernandez’s heroism is built, which is, after all, literature.  Written by Laurence Marvin Castillo
