article_title: The King's Phrase: Some Philippine Literary and Cultural Perspectives
text:
Published 1998. Author, Miguel A. Bernad, SJ. Quezon City: Office of Research and Publications, Ateneo de Manila University.

Until his death in 2009, Miguel A. Bernad, SJ, wrote prolifically on Philippine literature and culture. The King’s Phrase collects 22 of his essays, reviews, lectures, and addresses, dating from the 1950s to the 1990s, some previously published, many revised and augmented for this collection. These writings are grouped into four sections: Philippine literature in English (divided into “General Perspectives” and “Particular Perspectives”), Philippine vernacular language and literature, Old Manila, and Philippine bibliography.

The book opens with his by now classic, though perhaps also disproved, observation, made in 1958: that Philippine literature lacks a “theological dimension,” in that it is not “one that raises questions dealing with the ultimate meaning of human existence.” Bernad is quick to state that he is stating a fact and not finding fault. Though this view may now be considered quaint, his next essay, on the sociological aspects of Philippine literature in English, is still instructive. Bernad presents the facts that make up the conditions of production and consumption of Philippine literature in English, and predicts an attenuated future for it. Given its diminishing readership relative to Tagalog literature, Bernard concludes that, having “started as the venture of a small minority; it may be heading back in that same direction.”

The bulk of the book consists of Bernad’s reviews, some of them expanded or adapted. Bernad is direct both in his praise and in his criticism. Of Nick Joaquin’s Cave and Shadows, 1983, Bernad comments that it is proof that Nick Joaquin is “one of the best Filipino writers in English” and that Joaquin also tended toward theatrical, if not histrionic, writing.

Bernad is perhaps most engaging when he is commenting on Filipino writers in English like Gregorio Brillantes (“a writer with depth”), Carlos Bulosan (“to put it bluntly, he told lies”), N. V. M. Gonzalez (“as good a critic as he is a storyteller”), and Edilberto Tiempo (“Another of his virtues was fearlessness”). When he steps outside the province of Philippine literature in English, he champions literature in the local languages in his reviews of Sugbuanong Balak / Cebuano Poetry, 1988; Epics of the Philippines, 1983; and Awit and Corrido, 1987.

In “To Borrow the King’s Phrase: The Philippines as a Multilingual Society,” one finds the source of the book’s title. In an address to the Royal Academy of the Spanish Language, the king of Spain praises the efforts of the academy in preserving Castillan, but he also calls for the development of other languages of Spain. Similarly, Bernad urges scholars to turn their attention to the Philippine languages. In line with that vision, the book includes his reviews of Visayan dictionaries and a book on Manobo culture, and his notes on the “dignity and beauty in the vernacular languages.”

In his essays on Manila before World War II, Bernad crams historical trivia, rumors, literary quotation, and word pictures taken from his mental archive. The last essays in the book are on the Filipiniana collections of Morton Netzorg and of the Compañia General de Tabacos de Filipinas or the Tabacalera.

In all of his writings, Bernad’s erudition is evident, but equally plain is his amateurism, in the best sense of the word. Bernad’s essays are the works of an amateur (amtor, lover), written not out of professional obligation but out of love for the labor of reading and writing itself. Bernad eschews jargon, but his criticism is informed by classical principles (for example, in his analysis of Bulosan’s “authenticity,” he is drawing on Aristotle), appeals to common sense, and exudes a disarming honesty. For instance, in his review of a biography of Gregorio Aglipay, he refers to Alfrredo Navarro Salanga’s piece, “which I confess I do not understand.”

The King’s Phrase is testament to and summation of Bernad’s lifelong engagement with Philippine literature beyond Bamboo and the Greenwood Tree, 1961.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Knife's Edge: Selected Essays
text:
Published 2001. Author, Edel E. Garcellano. With an introduction by Caroline S. Hau. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

A collection of 17 contrarian and partisan essays culled mainly from three previous collections—First Person Plural, 1987; Intertext, 1990; and Interventions, 1998—this book intends to demonstrate how Philippine literature is intertwined with politics and economics. Garcellano proffers a polemical and theoretically nuanced Marxist critique. In each of the book’s three sections, Garcellano demonstrates the interrelatedness of literary studies, Philippine Marxism, and popular nationalism. At the same time, he problematizes Marxism, in light of the “crisis within the Philippine Left.”

The essays in the first section, “Critique,” are concerned with the structures and contexts of literary production and critical practice in the Philippines. “Post-EDSA Literature and Marxist Discourse” critiques the triumphalist and, for Garcellano, misguided politicization in Philippine literature centered on the so-called EDSA revolution and the figure and assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr. “Reportage on the State of Class War and Philippine Poetry” analyzes the complexities of “committed writing,” with a view to distinguishing it from formalism, nihilism, adventurism, nativism, and non-dialectic and ahistorical writing.

Acknowledging that “the Left today is under siege,” Garcellano theorizes in “Reading the Revolution, Reading the Masses” on the notions of “revolution” and “masses.” “Philippine Hermeneutics and the Kingpins of the Hill” critiques the “depoliticization of mainstream literary discourse” and the institutional networks that perpetuate such a state. Criticized are writers who negate nationalism and the class war through their “metaphysizing” of language and identity. “Marxism, Feminism and Literary Text: ‘The Difference of View, the Difference of Standard’” theorizes on the relationship between Marxism and feminism.

The second section of the book, “(Re)Reading,” is focused on specific literary productions. “A Way of Reading for the ’80s” reads Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat’s “Tata Selo” (Old Man Selo) against Jose Rizal’s and Gabriel Garcia Marquez’s novels. “Bamboo in the Wind and the Strategy of Containment” problematizes the subject position of novelist Azucena Grajo Uranza and the realism of her novel, which, for Garcellano, “romances” the elite and “contains” the masses, a fact that ultimately negates the novel’s purported revolutionary politics.

Garcellano reads the unrealized political project of Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan or PAKSA, organized in the 1970s, in “A Reductive Letter to Imaginary Warriors: Or, Minor Subversion for Our Times.” In the essays “Speaking from the Margin of Margins” and “Partisan Poetry: A Metacriticism,” he analyzes works by feminist writers and “warrior-poets,” respectively. “Gera and Its Readers: Or, the Cadre versus the Academic” evaluates the reading strategies and various reading positions that draw meaning out of Red fighter Ruth Firmeza’s novel, Gera (War), 1991.

The last section, “Criticism,” consists of short pieces that deal with cultural events, historiography, and critical writings. “The EDSA Drama as Literary Text: A Possible Reading” reconsiders the EDSA event as a literary text that “has given rise to the middle-class myths.” In “A Choice of Film Review (Or, Reviewing the Reviewer),” Garcellano argues that the filmmaker, though informed by his or her social class, can strive to exceed the roles assigned to him or her by the industry and society. In “The Fiction of History,” Garcellano assesses the treatment of the events from 1896 to 1906 by various historians. In “The Arrogance of Imaginary Power,” he critiques the critical writings of Virgilio S. Almario. “Of Theorizing Anti-Theorists, Nativists and Literary Shitheads” contends that nativism, in its refusal to engage with “foreign” theory, is a kind of anti-intellectualism. Finally, “The Filipino as Critic in a Time of War” reiterates what Garcellano thinks is the task of criticism: to “partake of the urgency of partisan deployment.”

Taken together, the essays are, as Garcellano puts it, a “metacritique of current discursive practices of the idols of the marketplace who have long steered the public toward the so-called neutral, non-ideological and pure positions.”  Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: Kung Sino ang Kumatha Kina Bagongbanta, Ossorio, Herrera, Aquino de Belen, Balagtas, Atbp: Mga Imbestigasyon sa Panitikan ng Kolonyalismo
text:
(On Who Authored Bagongbanta, Ossorio, Herrera, Aquino de Belen, Balagtas, and Others: Investigations into the Literature of Colonialism). Published 1992. Author, Virgilio S. Almario. Metro Manila: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

In this collection of essays, Almario simultaneously does well-informed analyses of colonial literature, specifically the Tagalog texts written during the Spanish period, and puts into question presuppositions regarding the relationship between literature and history. Unlike books that present broad surveys of trends and movements in order to situate authors and their works against history, Almario focuses on specific texts and studies the circumstances under which they were produced and received.

The book’s 10 chapters were previously published elsewhere or presented in lectures. Almario asserts that any attempt to understand colonial literature must be premised on the idea that literature is not transparent but a complicated discursive activity subject to the processes of production, dissemination, and consumption within the larger system of discursive practices. Almario examines certain accepted ways of viewing the works of Gaspar Aquino de Belen, F. Blancas de San Jose, or the ladino poets, to name a few.

Almario refers repeatedly to the pioneering works of earlier critics such as Epifanio de los Santos, Julian Cruz Balmaseda, Lope K. Santos, Bienvenido L. Lumbera, and Buenaventura Medina Jr, among others. But constituting the critical apparatus are concepts from contemporary Western theorists, like Althusser, Foucault, Bakhtin, Kristeva, and Lacan, who have investigated the nature of language from poststructuralist perspectives. Using their theories, Almario comes up with startling insights. Thus, missionary poems, generally criticized as unpoetic, emerge in his exegesis as texts that possess vigor and dynamism. Poems by the indio or native are found to contain elements with which to subvert the existing order.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Literature and Politics: The Colonial Experience in Nine Philippine Novels
text:
Published 1993. Author, Jaime An Lim. With a foreword by Leonard Casper. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

The experience of colonialism under Spain, the United States, and Japan has had an indelible impact on Philippine literature; yet as Jaime An Lim asserts in his introduction, studies on the Philippine novel have tended to treat literary form and colonial experience separately. To address this gap, Lim offers a critique of nine Philippine novels organized around variations on the theme of colonial experience. Accordingly, Lim categorizes the novels according to the demarcations of Philippine colonial history. The three key chapters are titled “In the Shadow of the Cross and the Sword: The Spanish Regime, 1565-1898,” “The Changing of the Guard: The American Period, 1899-1946,” and “Hour of the Rising Sun: The Japanese Occupation, 1941-1945.”

In the first chapter, Lim reads Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887; Linda Ty-Casper’s The Three-Cornered Sun, 1979; and F. Sionil Jose’s Po-on, 1984. Being written in the thick of the Spanish regime by an author who was at the time struggling to imagine the future of the nation, Noli, asserts Lim, was guarded and unwilling to dismiss the competing possibilities of response for and against Spain, favoring instead the embodiment in novel form of the dialectics of opposites and strategies. Ty-Casper, in contrast, can afford, given her distance from the events she recounts, to flesh out the dramatic motivations of the “common people” of the revolution against Spain, people who cry out against oppression but who are also tempted into tyrannies. Jose’s novel, set at the juncture between the Spanish and American colonial periods, narrates the genesis of national consciousness, which was merely incipient at the time that Rizal was writing his novel.

In the second chapter, Lim focuses on Maximo M. Kalaw’s The Filipino Rebel, 1930; Juan C. Laya’s His Native Soil, 1941; and Bienvenido N. Santos’s The Man Who (Thought He) Looked like Robert Taylor, 1983. Lim thinks that each of the novels represents a response to American colonization. Kalaw’s chronicles the tension between the co-optation of Filipino revolutionaries—what they call “collaborative compromise”—and the continued resistance of the “faithful.” Laya’s speculates on the viability of American institutions on Philippine soil, in the process reaffirming native tradition. And Santos’s depicts, through recounting the experience of migrant Filipinos, the “cultural dysfunction” wrought by the “loss of a sense of self and home.”

In the third chapter, Lim analyzes Stevan Javellana’s Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947; Edilberto K. Tiempo’s More Than Conquerors, 1964, rev. 1981; and Wilfrido Nolledo’s But for the Lovers, 1970—all of which picture the horrors of war. Javellana dramatizes life in a provincial village before, during, and after the coming of the Japanese; Tiempo delves into the pains and politics of collaboration and torture; Nolledo entwines the chaos of a historic war with the mysteries of mythology.

Lim’s approach allows him to read the novels “as an integrated account of the historical evolution of the Philippines with maximum continuity and coherence.” More than explicating the novelists’ political generalizations and their representations of the colonizers and colonized, however, Lim also illustrates how the permutations of the colonial experience are translated into literary strategies, rhetoric, and artistic integrity.  Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: Literature and Society: Essays on Life and Letters
text:
Published 1940. Author, Salvador P. Lopez. Manila: Philippine Book Guild. Reprinted, Manila: University Book Supply, 1941; Manila: University Publishing Co., 1952.

This book won first prize in the 1940 Commonwealth Literary Contests, essay category. The first part is a collection of critical essays on Philippine literature, on which Lopez’s reputation as the proponent of socially conscious literature rests.

In the title essay, for which Lopez is best known, he deplores writers who use words “purely as an instrument of fancy,” calling them “decadent aesthetes.” He challenges all writers to “become socially conscious and [to] take part in the political struggle.” However, he emphatically distinguishes between propaganda and literature with “social content.” Another important essay in the book is “Proletarian Literature: A Definition.” Here, he defines proletarian literature as “the interpretation of the experience of the working class in a world that has been rendered doubly dynamic by its struggles.” It has four characteristics. It is “a literature of hope and growth”; it is revolutionary, being premised on the necessity of revolution in the historical process; it is functional because it is “an instrument of social influence”; and lastly, it realistically portrays life and interprets its significance for readers, so that they will see the unity in its diversity and contradictions.

This highly influential book articulated the social consciousness of the Philippine Writers League, organized in 1939. It also offered a position opposing Jose Garcia Villa’s “art for art’s sake” philosophy. Among the first-generation writers identified with Lopez’s critical orientation are Manuel Arguilla, Arturo B. Rotor, and Amado V. Hernandez.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and David Jonathan Bayot

 

Source

Alegre, Edilberto, and Doreen G. Fernandez. 1984. The Writer and His Milieu. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

article_title: Liwanag at Dilim
text:
(Light and Darkness). Published 1896. Author, Emilio Jacinto. Kalayaan, 18 Jan 1896. Included in Buhay at mga Sinulat ni Emilio Jacinto by Jose P. Santos. Manila, 1935. English translation, Light and Darkness by Gregorio Nieva in The Revolutionists: Aguinaldo, Bonifacio, Jacinto, edited and with an introduction and notes by Teodoro A. Agoncillo. Manila: National Historical Commission, 1973, from the Spanish translation of “Emilio Jacinto” by Epifanio de los Santos in Revista Filipina, Jun 1918.

This collection of essays in Tagalog consists of the following: “Sa Anak ng Bayan” (To the Sons and Daughters of the People), “Ang Ningning at ang Liwanag” (The Glitter and the Light), “Ako’y Umaasa” (I Hope), “Kalayaan” (Liberty), “Ang Tao’y Magkakapantay” (All People Are Equal), “Ang Pag-ibig” (Love), “Ang Bayan at ang mga (Gobyerno) Pinuno” (People and Government), “Ang Maling Pagsampalataya” (False Belief), and “Ang Gumawa” (The Creator).

The essays are aphoristic, with bursts of lyricism, so that critic Virgilio Almario has described them as prose poems. “Ang Ningning at ang Liwanag” asserts that appearances are deceiving, for we tend to mistake wealthy people for honest people, and working people for thieves. “Kalayaan” is an extended definition of the concept of liberty, which Jacinto sees as a natural attribute of the human being. “Ang Tao’y Magkakapantay” reminds the wealthy and ruling class that, like the poor whom they now oppress, they would feel the same way were they to be tyrannized, for all human beings have the same feelings. Those who till the soil, he says, are more deserving of homage, because they “make the soil produce by their labor.”

Each essay is connected thematically with all the others, for they all spring from certain common premises, notably Jacinto’s belief in the equality of people.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Luluak ti Ibuyogko
text:
(My Tears to Shed). Published 1972. Author, Placido R. Real Jr. Quezon City: Earl Publishing House.

The book contains a short biography of Leona Florentino with a collection of 16 of her poems and a brief critical essay by Ilocano scholar Marcelino A. Foronda Jr on Florentino’s poetry. According to the author’s preface, the biography, which was serialized in Bannawag from Jun to Sep 1960, was based on scant data gathered from library research, and chiefly from interviews with Leona Florentino’s grandson Monsignor Isabelo de los Reyes Jr, then highest bishop of the Iglesia Filipina Independiente; Buenaventura Bello, then president of Northern Colleges; and poet Leon C. Pichay.

The biography, written originally for a popular magazine, lacks scientific attribution to sources and therefore makes verification difficult. What is clear is that the biographer is awed by his subject, constantly reminding the reader that Florentino is the Philippines’ Sappho. In asserting Leona Florentino’s greatness, he goes on to compare her writing with George Sand’s, Elizabeth Barrett Browning’s, and Amy Lowell’s, and traces her roots to those of Pedro Bucaneg and Jose Rizal.

Despite its limitations, the biography offers a wealth of materials for a moving narrative on the life of an internationally renowned Ilocano/Filipino poet in the 19th century. In flowery Ilocano, Real presents interesting details on the education of Leona—the rudiments from her parents, especially her mother Doña Isabel; Spanish and Latin from Fr Evaristo Abaya; and a year’s secondary schooling at the Colegio de Santa Isabel in Manila. Other biographical data include the occasion for writing her poem “Emilia”; her temper over admirers, especially a captain of the guardia civil; her marriage to Elias de los Reyes; and her being a mother to Isabelo. In providing a milieu to Leona’s life story, Real culls notes from history, particularly the Malong Revolt of Pangasinan, the Silang Revolt, the Ambaristo Revolt, the ouster of Gov Carlos Maria de la Torre, and the execution of the three priests Gomez, Zamora, and Burgos, the last being Leona’s neighbor in Ciudad Fernandina.

The author maintains that these historical events could have passed unnoticed in the mind and writing of Leona. But the extant writings of Leona are few and hardly reflect her body of works, from poetry to sarsuwela and komedya, which in the estimation of Foronda, should reach no fewer than 10 volumes.  Written by Herminio Beltran Jr

article_title: Ang Magandang Babae sa Sta. Elena
text:
(The Beautiful Woman of Sta. Elena). Published 1989. Author, Tomas F. Agulto. With a foreword by June L. Rodriguez and an introduction by Romulo A. Sandoval. Gapas Foundation Inc.

This book is a multi-genre collection divided into three sections of 5 essays, 24 poems, and 5 stories. The works depict the lives of the fisherfolk, whose working conditions, according to Sandoval in his introduction, cannot be comprehended in economic terms alone but must be seen in the context of the power relations between classes.

The first section consists of travel essays, though these are a far cry from mere accounts of sightseeing adventures in exotic places. With a poet’s eye for color and detail, and a storyteller’s knack for characterization and structure, the author shares with the reader the life stories of fisherfolk in Palawan, Marinduque, Tawi-Tawi, Batanes, and his hometown Hagonoy, Bulacan. In each essay, the history of the region and the culture of its people are interwoven with the narrative, so that their dignity and humanity shine through in their struggle for survival. Himself a fisherman, Agulto has the ability to make the fine distinctions between the different fishing methods and equipment used in these regions, and the precise vocabulary for describing them.

“Buhay-Piskador” (A Fisher’s Life) summarizes the history of muro-ami, a Japanese fishing method brought into the Philippines in pre-World War II years. It follows the life of a muro-ami diver who, at age 13, is recruited in Cebu and taken to Palawan. His harrowing life at sea ends only because the loss of his arm in a boat accident sets him free to return to Cebu. “Sa Bulubunduking Pulo ng mga Mangingisda” (In the Mountainous Islands of Fisherfolk) captures the contradictions of Marinduque island, where a family of fisherfolk live on a mountaintop and young fishermen hope for employment at the Marcopper Mining Corporation, while the elders unrelentingly lodge protests against the same corporation for the pollution and damage it has caused. “Ang mga Badjao ng Tungkalang” (The Badjaos of Tungkalang) focuses on a specific community to present a tapestry of Badjao mytho-history and traditions. Specific circumstances, like military operations and Tausug raids on their village, compel them to live an itinerant life. “Ivatan” begins with the description of illegal fishing practices by the Taiwanese in the Batanes seas. Ivatan culture is portrayed through the life stories of the doggedly hardworking Lolo Magno and the exuberantly garrulous Mr Gabotero. Agulto’s fifth, and last, essay is “Kariton at Kabayanihan” (Cart and Courage), which is a montage of testimonials about Ka Sonny and the victims of the Mendiola Massacre. The images evoked by their survivors’ narratives counter the celebratory images of the post-martial law government of Corazon Aquino.

The next section consists of personal and political poems, a number of which evoke nostalgia even as they poke fun at the inefficiency of the education system. We read about naughty elementary kids who smell like the sea, evading the efforts of their elders to discipline them.

While the struggles of the fisherfolk are sketched in the poems, they are elaborated on in the stories. In “Sa Bakuran ng Komprador” (At the Comprador’s Backyard), young Abe must choose between joining the fisherfolk association led by his Ninong Julio and joining the vigilante group to be set up by Konsehal Galida, who wants to maintain his political clout. The story illustrates that the cultural complicates the political. Abe “owes” Galida not money but a debt of gratitude, or utang na loob. In “Putot” (Shorty), old Tata Ilyong is caught in a similar dilemma—in his case between joining the New People’s Army and joining the government’s military forces. Both stories force young Abe and old Ilyong to choose between fence-sitting and affiliating with the party that they find just.

The collection’s title story ends the book. Nana Lagring, a devotee of Sta. Elena, hears rumors that her missing son is an informant. A wandering woman resembling Sta. Elena and named Ka Elena (Comrade Elena) invites her to a revolutionary camp. The visit strengthens her faith both in the mercy of Sta. Elena and the justness of the ongoing revolution.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and Arbeen Acuña

article_title: Maybe: Incidentally; The Satire of Federico Mangahas
text:
Published 1998. Author, Federico Mangahas. Editor, Ruby K. Mangahas. With a foreword by Francisco Arcellana. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This book is a selection of 409 of Mangahas’s essays, which originally appeared under his columns Maybe, in the Tribune in 1928-40, and Incidentally, in the Philippines Herald in 1940-41. The pieces are but a small serving of Mangahas’s work, given that the years 1935-39 are not represented.

As column entries they are reflective of the pressures of the times. These include the independence question, public education, female emancipation, political rivalries, the war then raging in Europe, and the practice blackouts in Manila. Political personalities parade the pages: Camilio Osias, Jorge Vargas, Teodoro M. Kalaw, Leon Guinto, Jorge Bocobo, Claro M. Recto, Manuel Roxas, Carlos P. Romulo, Sergio Osmeña, all of whom Mangahas by turns attacks and applauds. Alongside these figures appear the ordinary folk, whose letters Mangahas quotes from, reproduces in toto, or responds to. To read the essays, then, is to see Philippine history during the American colonial period unfolding.

At the same time, the subject of Mangahas’s columns—and the object of his satire—can be as familiar to the modern-day reader as they were to his. In “Tragic Temperament,” written in Feb 1930, Mangahas decries the arguments that the Americans were using to extend colonial rule, arguments, he wrote, that were channeled through secondary education. He thus anticipates Renato Constantino’s critique in the 1960s of American colonial education. In “A Psalm of Thanks,” Mangahas enumerates the “blessings” which “afflicted” the country in 1928, including “the abdication of leadership and intelligence in favor of cunning and the pork-barrel, which is another shining evidence of our political maturity.”

Literary matters figure in a number of the essays. A concrete poem by Christian Morgenstern, sent by a reader, provokes reactions, including one from A. V. H. Hartendorp, on “new poetry.” Mangahas himself is coy about his position. Other essays remark on writers (“Doveglion [Jose Garcia Villa] does not think in terms of arrival, least of all affluence under degrading conditions”), books (“If it’s wrong to be a human being, a Filipino at that, Da Costa’s LIKE THE MOLAVE assuredly misses its mark”), and aspects of literary production and consumption, like translation, publishing, and contests. From the essays under “Incidentally,” one also gets glimpses of the Philippine Writers League and the Commonwealth Literary Contests.

Mangahas’s arsenal as satirist is formidable. Irony, hyperbole, understatement, reductio ad absurdum, and the occasional ad hominem attack are used to cut down to size giants, such as presidents Emilio Aguinaldo and Manuel Quezon: “We should take pride in the moral versatility of our public officials.” For added punch, Mangahas wittily turns popular and literary phrases around, including those from Scripture: “While they [reformers] are the salt of the earth, we are not always aware of their ability to improve the savor of things.”

American “benevolence” is a myth Mangahas enjoys exploding. He welcomes an American statesman’s proposal that American communists be deported to an island in the archipelago, as it would make the Philippines “a happy dumping place for intellectual and social pariahs.” To an American senator’s suggestion that the Philippines be sold to Germany, he remarks, “We have been sold so many times I don’t see why we should raise any objections to being sold again…. America should succeed: she is the greatest salesgirl in the world.”

Behind the writings a personality emerges—urbane, informed, perceptive, critical of vanity, ignorance, hypocrisy, and self-importance, but not blind to its own foibles. However, readers may miss many of Mangahas’s references because of the topical nature of columns and the absence of annotations. Still, the essays offer today’s readers evidence of why his columns were much admired in his time and give today’s columnists a standard against which to measure what they churn out.  Written by Jonathan Chua

These include the independence question, public education, female emancipation, political rivalries, the war then raging in Europe, and the practice blackouts in Manila. Political personalities parade the pages: Camilio Osias, Jorge Vargas, Teodoro M. Kalaw, Leon Guinto, Jorge Bocobo, Claro M. Recto, Manuel Roxas, Carlos P. Romulo, Sergio Osmeña, all of whom Mangahas by turns attacks and applauds. Alongside these figures appear the ordinary folk, whose letters Mangahas quotes from, reproduces in toto, or responds to. To read the essays, then, is to see Philippine history during the American colonial period unfolding.

At the same time, the subject of Mangahas’s columns—and the object of his satire—can be as familiar to the modern-day reader as they were to his. In “Tragic Temperament,” written in Feb 1930, Mangahas decries the arguments that the Americans were using to extend colonial rule, arguments, he wrote, that were channeled through secondary education. He thus anticipates Renato Constantino’s critique in the 1960s of American colonial education. In “A Psalm of Thanks,” Mangahas enumerates the “blessings” which “afflicted” the country in 1928, including “the abdication of leadership and intelligence in favor of cunning and the pork-barrel, which is another shining evidence of our political maturity.”

Literary matters figure in a number of the essays. A concrete poem by Christian Morgenstern, sent by a reader, provokes reactions, including one from A. V. H. Hartendorp, on “new poetry.” Mangahas himself is coy about his position. Other essays remark on writers (“Doveglion [Jose Garcia Villa] does not think in terms of arrival, least of all affluence under degrading conditions”), books (“If it’s wrong to be a human being, a Filipino at that, Da Costa’s LIKE THE MOLAVE assuredly misses its mark”), and aspects of literary production and consumption, like translation, publishing, and contests. From the essays under “Incidentally,” one also gets glimpses of the Philippine Writers League and the Commonwealth Literary Contests.

Mangahas’s arsenal as satirist is formidable. Irony, hyperbole, understatement, reductio ad absurdum, and the occasional ad hominem attack are used to cut down to size giants, such as presidents Emilio Aguinaldo and Manuel Quezon: “We should take pride in the moral versatility of our public officials.” For added punch, Mangahas wittily turns popular and literary phrases around, including those from Scripture: “While they [reformers] are the salt of the earth, we are not always aware of their ability to improve the savor of things.”

American “benevolence” is a myth Mangahas enjoys exploding. He welcomes an American statesman’s proposal that American communists be deported to an island in the archipelago, as it would make the Philippines “a happy dumping place for intellectual and social pariahs.” To an American senator’s suggestion that the Philippines be sold to Germany, he remarks, “We have been sold so many times I don’t see why we should raise any objections to being sold again…. America should succeed: she is the greatest salesgirl in the world.”

Behind the writings a personality emerges—urbane, informed, perceptive, critical of vanity, ignorance, hypocrisy, and self-importance, but not blind to its own foibles. However, readers may miss many of Mangahas’s references because of the topical nature of columns and the absence of annotations. Still, the essays offer today’s readers evidence of why his columns were much admired in his time and give today’s columnists a standard against which to measure what they churn out.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Memory's Fictions: A Personal History
text:
Published 1993. Author, Bienvenido N. Santos. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

Begun just before he turned 80 and published three years before his death, Memory’s Fictions is the first volume in a series of autobiographical books: Postscript to a Saintly Life, 1994; Letters: Book 1, 1995; and Letters: Book 2, 1996.

The book narrates stages of Santos’s life: his birth to illiterate parents, his childhood in Tondo, his dream of becoming a boxer, his turn to teaching, his starting a family in Albay, his sojourns in various cities in the Philippines, and his studies and experiences overseas. The work is organized around two ideas: the ironic self-deprecation of an accomplished writer, who is “alarmed” at the thought of writing his life, and the constant reflection on the various outworking of individual and social memory. Always on the foreground is Santos, an “ordinary man” of humble beginnings, short, dark, homely, never blasé.

Through his self-portrayal of homeliness, Santos demonstrates that hard work pays—the “unlikely” Filipino writer partying with T. S. Eliot or being admired by Flannery O’Connor. However, he also reveals prejudices that make these images appear “unlikely,” as when he recounts how an American professor mocked his accent, a slight that pushed him to best his American peers, or when his age and his worn-out clothes invited contempt from rich Filipinos in San Francisco who did not know who he was.

As “a personal history,” the book provides insights into Santos’s formation as an artist and teacher and into the genesis of some of his literary works, while also affording readers glimpses of national history filtered through Santos’s eyes. His story is not told as a chronicle, but it is subject to the whims of memory. Thus, Memory’s Fictions proceeds by digressions and is colored by anecdotes, ellipses, and imagined details and dialogues. In the end, Santos confesses that “there are still so many things to write about. Memory should be the last to go in spite of signs of it withering here and there.”  Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: Mula sa Parolang Ginto: Mga Panunuring Pampanitikan
text:
(From the Golden Lighthouse: Literary Criticism). Published 1969. Author, Clodualdo del Mundo Sr. With an introduction by Celso Al. Carunungan. Manila: Liwayway Publishing Inc.

This is the first compilation of essays of literary criticism in Tagalog. Till the publication of the book, literary criticism had been confined to the pages of some magazines, such as Liwayway and Malaya, to the pamphlets published by the then Institute of National Language (later called Surian ng Wikang Pambansa), and occasionally, to some anthologies edited, for example, by Teodoro A. Agoncillo and Alejandro C. Abadilla. Contextualized against the existing body of critical texts, the book was an ambitious project: it studied the different aspects of Philippine literature and popular culture.

Del Mundo’s studies on poetry exemplify a critical tendency shaped by a romantic view of literature, as manifested in the initial work, “Tatag ng Kahapon, Dahas ng Ngayon, Pangako ng Bukas” (Sturdiness of the Past, Violence of the Present, Promise of the Future). The two essays on Abadilla encapsulate the terms of the debate between him and the latter over the poem “Ako ang Daigdig” (I Am the World), which del Mundo claims is not a poem. Del Mundo offers glimpses not only of the personalities of artists but also of different movements. His studies on the significance of the Panitikan movement remain crucial to a fuller understanding of it. As important as his essays on literature are the pieces on various aspects of popular culture—film, radio, komiks. Del Mundo draws on his experiences as a writer for the komiks and radio and as a popular novelist, whose works were eventually made into successful films. His analysis of Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass) directed by Lamberto V. Avellana is illustrative of the method and scope of del Mundo’s essays.

He faces no difficulty looking at these artifacts as parts of literature; in this sense, his work is pioneering, for it affirms the connections among different types of texts.

Mula sa Parolang Ginto is important for its pioneering attempt to prove that indeed literary criticism in Filipino is alive and that there are critics like him who can be the source of insight and knowledge into the complex development of various cultural types.   Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Muog: Ang Naratibo ng Kanayunan sa Matagalang Digmang Bayan sa Pilipinas
text:
(Fortress: The Narrative of the Countryside in the Protracted People’s War in the Philippines). Published 1998. Author, Institute for People’s Literature and Art. With a foreword by Jose Maria Sison and an introduction by Gelacio Guillermo. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This anthology gathers 67 narratives about the protracted armed struggle waged by the national democratic movement in the countryside. The authors, who are members of the Communist Party of the Philippines, New People’s Army (NPA) cadres, peasants, and allied cultural workers and activists, are either named, anonymous, or carrying pseudonyms. Arranged chronologically from 1972 to 1997, the narratives consist of letters, testimonials, diary entries, reportage, interviews, eulogies, fables, short fiction, and excerpts from novels. They are in Filipino and English, although some are translations from regional languages, including Boholano, Waray, Hiligaynon, and Ilocano.

Blending social realism and romanticism, the narratives explore peasant and guerrilla life in the countryside. Edgar Arbozo’s “Bukatot” (Hoop Net), Arnel J. Ligahon’s “Sakada, Saang Lupalop Ka Nagmula?” (Worker, Where on Earth Have You Come From?), and Simplicio Madlangbayan’s “May Layak sa Sinapupunan ng Kalikasan” (There Are Dried Leaves in Nature’s Womb) tell how the oppressive acts of landlords and elite businessmen have goaded farmers into joining the armed struggle. In the darkly humorous trickster fable “Ang Magkaibigang Alamid at Matsing at ang Masibang si Ahang” (The Friends, Cat and Monkey, and the Greedy, Arrogant One), the parasitic relationship between the ruling and peasant classes is violently overturned.

There are several narratives highlighting the role of the revolutionary movement in the defense of the rights of the masses. In Ricardo Lee’s reportage, “Balita buhat sa Bikol” (News from Bicol), the farmers deem NPA cadres as their protectors against the abusive military in the region. In Abdul Ulap’s “Taking of Sadanga,” townspeople suffering from the abuses of their former mayor welcome an NPA raid. In “Sa Kabisayaan: Si Ka Luming, ang Rebolusyong Agraryo, at ang Armadong Pakikibaka” (In the Visayas: Ka Luming, the Agrarian Revolution, and the Armed Struggle), the parag-umas (farming folk) of three Visayan barrios are empowered by cadres to demand sufficient wages.

The heroism of NPA cadres in guerrilla fronts is extolled in the eulogy “Karaniwang Tao ang Nagiging Kawal” (It Is Ordinary People Who Become Soldiers), and in stories like Ricardo Rojo’s “In the Face of Death” and Felipe Granrojo’s “Sky Rose.” The grief and longing of revolutionaries away from their loved ones find expression in Victoria Manalo’s “Romance in the Hills” and Lorena Barros’s letter, “Mahal Kong Ina at Kasama” (My Dear Mother and Comrade). Aspects of guerrilla life outside the battlefield are depicted, like the success of an NPA medical team in Lualhati Gregorio’s “Caring for the People,” as is the significance of the arts in advancing the armed struggle in Ka Luis’s “Isa Ring Hukbong Pangkultura ang Bagong Hukbong Bayan” (The New People’s Army Is Also a Cultural Group).

In sum, the collection affirms how cultural work is significant in documenting the growth and strength of the revolutionary movement.  Written by Laurence Marvin Castillo

article_title: Necessary Fictions: Philippine Literature and the Nation, 1946-1980
text:
Published 2000. Author, Caroline S. Hau. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Caroline Hau’s book argues for the continued significance of critical and interpretative practice, especially with regard to explicating the nation. More specifically, the book looks into the relationship between literature and nationalist discourse, especially the various roles they play in the production of one another, through a critical reading of canonical texts against the backdrop of the conflicts of their particular historical situations.

Hau’s method involves locating certain “excesses,” or what she describes as “the heterogenous elements … that inform, but also exceed, nationalist attempts to grasp, intellectually and politically, the complex realities at work in Philippine society.” She makes it clear that these excesses are irreducible by-products of the nationalist project, and so the response to their identification should not be a poststructuralist abandonment of the nation, but rather a collective effort toward more sophisticated analyses of nationhood.

In “The Problem of Consciousness,” Hau discusses how Philippine nationalism has been premised on the idea that the discovery of truth is a prerequisite to action. Education, of which literature plays an important part, creates the proper conditions for the formation of a nationalist character. However, Hau eventually questions this binary between truth and action, and shows how the latter also brings access to the former in a dialectical process.

In “The Fiction of a Knowable Community,” Hau uses Jose Rizal’s attempt to make Filipino society “knowable” in his novels to show how any construction of a Filipino community will always fail to capture the heterogeneous elements of the people. Rizal’s position as being both inside and outside the nation gave him an advantage over previous European critics of the Philippines. However, his position also made it even more difficult to inscribe the complexities of the various populations and groups that comprise the nation.

In “Literature and History,” Hau shows how Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino and Ileto’s Pasyon and Revolution, 1979, oppose rigid dichotomies of “foreign” and “native” in their constructions of syncretic and dynamic conceptions of key players in Philippine history—a Hispanicized bourgeoisie in Joaquin’s case and a mass-based folk Christian millenarianism in Ileto’s. While “foreign” elements are the excesses of more nativist narratives of Philippine history, however, both Joaquin and Ileto have their own excesses—the masses and the quotidian excess of certain millenarian rituals, respectively—that destabilize their own constructions of Philippine history.

In “Alien Nation,” Hau argues that the Chinese are displaced from Philippine history in that the contradictions of the Filipino nation-state—formal political equality and enormous economic inequality—are systematically displaced onto the Chinese. Through a critical reading of various representations of the Chinese, including Edgardo M. Reyes’s Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (In the Claws of Light), 1967, she shows how Filipino nationalism constructs Filipinos as a unity—where divisions of class, gender, and so forth are de-emphasized—in opposition to an alien and alienating Chinese Other, whose alienness is characterized by differing citizenships and the closeness to capital. The necessary reexamination of the place of the Chinese in the Philippines thus becomes a reexamination of Filipino nationalism itself.

“Authorizing the Personal and the Political” attacks dominant forms of criticism in Philippine Literature in English, especially biographical criticism, epitomized in the readings of Kerima Polotan’s The Hand of the Enemy, 1962. This form of reading privileges an unproductive either-or tendency that declares an author (and so her work) either “clean” (“good”) or “dirty” (“bad”). In contrast, Hau argues for a “theory of ethical practice” that would simultaneously look for the symmetry between an author’s life and her texts while avoiding using the author as a source of deep (and total) meaning. The author is used as one of many structuring principles through which a text is determined, along with its social, political, historical, and ideological conditions.

In “The Unfinished Revolution,” Hau looks into Apolinario Mabini’s memoirs and Carlos Bulosan’s novels to show how any grand theory or construction of Philippine history necessarily runs aground when faced with the quotidian histories and excesses of everyday people. This makes it impossible to use history to predict the future. On the other hand, the necessity of projecting the nation into the future—for nationalists as a whole, but especially for Marxists and leftists, who imagine a revolution—is the very condition for the existence of both nations. Thus, the inability to completely and accurately predict the future is important because it emphasizes the reality that one cannot be completely sure of any prediction, and so necessitates more careful attentiveness in planning and action.

“The Politics of Criticism” analyzes how the issues of error and criticism have been central to the formation, development, and survival/strength of the Communist Party of the Philippines, as seen in its changing strategies and policies. The practice of self-criticism is also seen in their method of producing literature, as seen in the creation of Mano de Verdades Posadas’s Hulagpos (Breaking Free). From this, Hau argues, firstly, that the inevitability of error is not a reason for defeatism but is rather the necessary condition of struggle; it merely necessitates further and better criticism. Secondly, she argues that the collaborative process in creating Hulagpos shows how literature always works within a complex field of production involving audience, critic, writer, and so forth. Thus, literature is neither “history” (extraliterary propaganda) nor purely “self-expression” but is rather something that is worked through collectively. This emphasizes a different understanding of “intellectuals,” as well as the “people,” as being always in a state of transformation.  Written by Dominic Sy

article_title: Ang Nobelang Tagalog (1905-1975): Tradisyon at Modernismo
text:
(The Tagalog Novel [1905-1975]: Tradition and Modernism). Published 1982. Author, Soledad S. Reyes. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This book surveys the Tagalog novel from its origins in the early decades of the present century to the martial law years. Drawing from the works of Iñigo Ed. Regalado and Mona P. Highley, Reyes discusses the dominant trends and movements of the genre.

Chapter one traces the roots of the Tagalog novel to the protonovels of the 19th century, such as the conduct book Urbana at Feliza (Urbana and Feliza), 1864. Besides the didactic and the religious tradition, Reyes notes two other wellsprings of the Tagalog novel: the realist tradition, exemplified by the novels of Jose Rizal, and the romantic tradition, exemplified by Pedro Paterno’s Ninay, 1885.

In the next two sections, Reyes examines works by the first-generation Tagalog novelists, whose works range from the domestic, generally didactic and romantic, such as Nena at Neneng (Nena and Neneng), 1903, and Pusong Walang Pag-ibig (Heart without Love), 1910, to the more historical and socially conscious, such as Pinaglahuan (Eclipsed), 1907. The didactic/romantic tradition, as seen in the works of Jose Sevilla and Rosauro Almario, with their allegorical tendencies and ahistorical settings, entertained and instructed, following many of the conventions of the metrical romances. On the other hand, the works of socially conscious writers like Lope K. Santos and Juan Arsciwals attempt not only at a faithful reconstruction of contemporary society but also at an examination of the sociopolitical problems and their effects on the individual. They thus began the protest tradition in the Tagalog novel. The years before and during World War II saw the same two tendencies at work. Reyes explains the popularity of serialized novels, as well as the effects of commercialism, the rise of the short story, and cinema on the genre. She notes the predominance of romantic novels or novels dealing with personal relationships over more socially conscious works.

The next section discusses the emergence of modernism in the Tagalog novel during the 1940s and 1950s. This book surveys the Tagalog novel from its origins in the early decades of the present century to the martial law years. Drawing from the works of Iñigo Ed. Regalado and Mona P. Highley, Reyes discusses the dominant trends and movements of the genre.

Chapter one traces the roots of the Tagalog novel to the protonovels of the 19th century, such as the conduct book Urbana at Feliza (Urbana and Feliza), 1864. Besides the didactic and the religious tradition, Reyes notes two other wellsprings of the Tagalog novel: the realist tradition, exemplified by the novels of Jose Rizal, and the romantic tradition, exemplified by Pedro Paterno’s Ninay, 1885.

In the next two sections, Reyes examines works by the first-generation Tagalog novelists, whose works range from the domestic, generally didactic and romantic, such as Nena at Neneng (Nena and Neneng), 1903, and Pusong Walang Pag-ibig (Heart without Love), 1910, to the more historical and socially conscious, such as Pinaglahuan (Eclipsed), 1907. Santos and Juan Arsciwals attempt not only at a faithful reconstruction of contemporary society but also at an examination of the sociopolitical problems and their effects on the individual. They thus began the protest tradition in the Tagalog novel. The years before and during World War II saw the same two tendencies at work. She notes the predominance of romantic novels or novels dealing with personal relationships over more socially conscious works.

article_title: The Novel of Justice: Selected Essays 1968-1994
text:
Published 1996. Author, N. V. M. Gonzalez. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

Written mainly in the mode of reflection rather than criticism, the essays herein are concerned with the “difficult days” that have stifled the Filipino imagination under centuries of colonial rule and the “marginality” that continues to mark Filipino creativity in postcolonial times. The book is divided into two sections, following these two prongs of reflection.

The first section, “The Story Friday Can’t Possibly Tell,” consists of seven essays. “The Novel of Justice” ruminates on how the novel has been informed by and has had to contend with the colonial experience. “The Filipino and the Novel” provides an overview of novels written since the introduction of English in the Philippines, with Gonzalez noting that “the relevance of history to fiction” and the necessity of “clearing the ground for social action” are the hallmarks of the Filipino novelist’s vision. “The Literature of Emerging Nations” proffers a theory of literature that relates the specific historical experiences of First, Second, and Third Worlds with literary production. Since “disequilibrium is the essential quality of life in emerging nations,” then comedy, which is “essentially contingent, episodic, and ethnic,” is favorable to tragedy for Third World nations.

In “Whistling Up the Wind,” Gonzalez calls for a reconsideration of the paradigmatic structures of myth as a basis for “a fresh reading of Philippine experience.” In “Drumming for the Captain,” Gonzalez laments the tendency of Filipinos to solicit foreign, especially American, approval and to lay claim to being the first at something—what he calls the “Jones Law Syndrome” and the “Magellan Complex”—which has resulted in the alienation of the Filipino writer. The eruption of Mount Pinatubo occasions “Even as the Mountain Speaks,” in which Gonzalez takes the many volcanoes and islands of the Philippines as a metaphor for the nations and cultures that make up one country. He likens lahar to “colonial history and imperialism” above which the Filipino rises. The “log” referred to in “The Log across the Trail” is the empire and the narrative of empire that coincided, according to Gonzalez, with the beginning of the Filipino’s literary creativity; the “trail,” to “the cautions and travail of decolonization,” which also is the writer’s trail.

The second section, “Among the Wounded,” consists of six essays. “With Mt. Pinatubo to the Rescue” returns to the lahar as a metaphor for imperialism. Here, however, Gonzalez considers the eruption of a volcano “asleep” for 611 years as an end of an era, a call to let “Imagination” be “the Mother of Languages,” so that national literatures in various languages could flourish anew. In “Among the Wounded,” Gonzalez reflects on literary prizes, in particular the Nobel Prize. In “Dogeaters, ’Di Ba?” (Dogeaters, Right?) Gonzalez considers the achievement of Jessica Hagedorn’s novel Dogeaters, 1991.

Surveying Asian, particularly Chinese, writers in “Up and About a Cultural Wake,” Gonzalez distinguishes between “a literacy that imperial powers require” and a literacy that democratizes language as “a tool for progress.” This latter literacy can help Filipinos see life afresh. “The Chosen” is a response to Purita Kalaw-Ledesma’s memoirs, And Life Goes On, 1994. Gonzalez reminisces about his own youth and expresses his admiration for the work of Kalaw-Ledesma’s father, Teodoro M. Kalaw. Finally, in “Among Dancers, Jesters and Nuns,” occasioned by the publication of The Complete Poems of Angela Manalang-Gloria, 1993, and Edna Zapanta-Manalapaz’s Angela Manalang Gloria: A Literary Biography, 1993, Gonzalez discusses Manalang-Gloria’s place in the changing tides of Philippine literature.    Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: Originality as Vengeance in Philippine Literature
text:
Published 1984. Author, Lucila Hosillos. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

Winner of the CCP Grand Prize in Literary Criticism in English, 1979, this book is a collection of 10 theoretical and critical essays written in English.

Part 1, consisting of four chapters, explains the author’s theoretical framework. Although upholding the text’s primacy, Hosillos nonetheless insists that the critic must study how historical forces, economic structures, and institutions have entered the work’s artistic configurations. The aesthetic-historical approach requires a methodology called concentric comparativism, imaged in terms of a concentric sphere. This image is explained as a continuum composed of the author continuum, tradition continuum, language continuum, national continuum, and regional continuum. All these facts must be considered in any attempt to understand the literary text.

Hosillos demonstrates an application of this critical theory in part 2, which consists of critiques on early Ilonggo poetry, Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), the Philippine short story in English, and PETA Kalinangan Ensemble’s production of Domingo Landicho’s Dupluhang Bayan (People’s Poetic Joust), 1976.

Part three reaffirms Hosillos’s thesis that “Filipino writers … transmuted foreign influence into literary achievement of originality … [for] they assimilated foreign influences to serve their own purposes.” She further stresses the inadequacy of New Criticism and formalism in the analysis of Philippine literary works. These violate the works and discourage especially the “young writers who are still trying to find their own voices.” Hosillos adds that “relevance to social consciousness and [to] the development of nationalism” is an important criterion in evaluating Filipino achievement in literature.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Origins and Rise of The Filipino Novel: A Generic Study of the Novel until 1940
text:
Published 1983, reprinted 1998. Author, Resil B. Mojares. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This book traces the origins of the Filipino novel back to the precolonial epics, with which the country’s narrative tradition began. In the study, Mojares shows how a common narrative tradition persists despite the powerful influence of the Western novel. This local tradition comes from the epics, ballads, folktales, the pasyon, lives of saints, korido, and the moral and social tracts.

Mojares’s analyses of the novels take into account their intrinsic elements and devices as well as their historical, biographical, and cultural context. These diachronic (or historical) and synchronic (or generic) levels of analyses reveal the two types of impulses that inform the Filipino novel: on the one hand is the didactic, romantic, and aesthetic impulse, and on the other is the fictional, realistic, and empirical impulse. Mojares first discusses the different indigenous narrative forms, focusing on the epic. He then notes how the epic was transmuted with the influx of Spanish colonialism. The next section deals with the different narrative forms derived from Spain, such as the pasyon, which replaced the epic, the metrical romances called awit and korido, and the conduct books. He concludes that the impulse behind these different forms was didacticism, in line with the Spanish mission to Christianize the Philippines. However, he notes that there was also a growing tendency toward empiricism. Mojares then discusses the emergence of the novel in the propaganda movement during the late 19th century. The works of Isabelo de los Reyes, Pedro Paterno, M. H. del Pilar, and Jose Rizal are examined, the empirical impulse in them highlighted. Mojares links the rise of empiricism to several sociopolitical developments; among them were increased cultural contact with Europe and the rise of an educated class, of which Rizal was a member. The succeeding sections deal with the novel in the local languages. Mojares explains its flourishing as a result of the populace’s increased national consciousness, the rise of secularism and more free thought, the removal of publishing restrictions and a growing reading public, and the fact that English was still foreign to most Filipinos while Spanish was declining. Having discussed works by the first novelists of the twentieth century, such as Gabriel Beato Francisco, Lope K. Santos, Valeriano Hernandez Peña, and Faustino Aguilar, Mojares enumerates some features of the novel in the local languages—namely, the affinity for other narrative forms like the historical tract and verse romance, didacticism, and “the stress on the affective values of the plot,” side by side with social consciousness.

The decline of such novels during the period from 1920 to 1940 is discussed in the next section. It is attributed largely to commercialism, which encouraged improvisory writing. Turned into a “market commodity,” these novels suffered from repetition and formlessness. After discussing the works of writers like Fausto J. Galauran, Sulpicio Osorio, and Flaviano P. Boquecosa, Mojares moves to the first novels in English and observes the problems in that area.

The book concludes with a tentative theory of the Filipino novel, which begins with a description of its general features. First, it is characterized by polygenesis; that is, it is the synthesis of literary and extraliterary factors. Second, it has a syncretic form; that is, it is the descendant and, therefore, a mixture of many literary forms that came before it. Third, it is the result of the dialectical relations between literature and sociohistorical realities.

This book is a valuable source for literary scholars because of its scope and depth. It is the result of a study of some 170 primary texts; Mojares focuses on novels written in Spanish, Tagalog, and Cebuano, as well as a few texts in Ilonggo and Ilocano.  Written by Jonathan Chua and David Jonathan Bayot

article_title: Our Scene So Fair: Filipino Poetry in English, 1905-1955
text:
Published 2008. Author, Gemino H. Abad. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

A collection of eight essays, previously published in various journals and books, and an epilogue on the first 50 years of Philippine poetry in English, the book takes for its title a phrase from Fernando Maramag’s poem “Moonlight on Manila Bay,” 1912. Abad uses the phrase to refer to the native ground, whose fairness colonization has dimmed. His central thesis is that Filipino poets at first wrote in English, imprisoned in its ideological assumptions, but later wrought from English, using it to imagine and recover “our scene so fair.”

This thesis informs all the essays but is especially elaborated on in “Our Scene So Fair: An Overview of Filipino English Poetry, 1905-2006” and “‘The Language of My Blood’: Filipino Poetry from English.” For Abad, language is not a neutral medium, and literature is the result of the writer’s struggle with the linguistic medium, whether this be native or foreign. The poet tills foreign soil to make “a native clearing.” Thus, the Filipino poet writing in English is indeed Filipino, though the medium is a colonial language.

In “Amador T. Daguio: A Turning Point in Filipino Poetry from English” Abad points to Amador Daguio’s “Man of Earth,” 1932, as a high water mark in the shift from writing in English to writing from English: the persona in Daguio’s poem asserts his power to define who he is (“I am man of earth”), in defiance of what “they say” he is (“I might have been the bamboo”). “Inang Bayan Our Muse: Early Filipino Poets in English, 1905-1924” surveys early Philippine patriotic and socially committed verse in English. “‘That Mighty Eagle’: America in Filipino Verses in English, 1905-1945” provides one explanation for the current ambivalence toward America. In the poems of the period, American atrocities during the Philippine-American War are glossed over, and the kinship between America and the Philippines during World War II affirmed. However, the meanings that “America” assumed in the imagination of Filipino poets—“Freedom and Democracy, Progress and Justice, Fair Play and World Peace”—have ironically also created a space for a criticism of America as a nation that falls short of its promise and promises.

In two essays, “The Filipino Romantic: Moral and Religious, Melancholic, Sentimental, Fantastic, and Descriptive Verse” and “The Filipino Romantic: Amorous and Erotic Verse,” Abad notes how Filipino poets adopted English Romantic poetry and gave it a Filipino stamp.

“Fernando M. Maramag, Poet and Critic” is an overview of Maramag’s work as a site where matter and medium struggle, the poet aware of his own pursuit of a space within English in which to forge his own thoughts. The epilogue, “A Sense of Country: Our Body Poetic,” argues that the sense of country is a “yearning for form” and a product of “imagination in and through language upon our own ground”; thus, it is poets, having mastered language, whether native or colonial, who “create our sense of country.” Moreover, a Filipino reader “will always read into the text by a Filipino author his own experience as a Filipino.”

Our Scene So Fair is intended as a companion to Abad’s anthologies of Philippine poetry in English, from which he draws copious examples and extensive quotations. In a way, it is Abad’s apologia for a literature written in a colonial language. If what matters is what the poet does with language and not the language per se, then, Philippine writing in English (or Spanish) is as much Filipino as writings in the native languages. In fact, Abad argues, using an adopted language may be a more critical act of forging a native clearing than writing in a native language where the writer may be lulled into assuming the “innocence” of native words. On the other hand, Abad is aware that such an approach to poetry in English is partly an effect of reading: Maramag’s poem, for instance, was originally intended as a celebration of Dewey’s victory, but it lends itself to an ironic interpretation when it is read in light of present experience and present understanding of Philippine history.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Pagbasa ng Panitikan at Kulturang Popular: Piling Sanaysay, 1976-1996
text:
(Reading Literature and Popular Culture: Selected Essays, 1976-1996). Published 1997. Author, Soledad S. Reyes. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This collection of 28 essays, previously published in various journals, magazines, and books or read at conferences, introduces teachers and students to various approaches to understanding forms of Philippine literature and popular culture. The essays are grouped into four sections: “Teorya at Pagdulog” (Theory and Approach), “Tungkol sa Nobela at Kuwento” (On the Novel and the Short Story), “Indibidwal na Manunulat” (Individual Writers), and “Kulturang Popular” (Popular Culture).

The first section discusses theoretical approaches to literature. The author shows a preference for reader-response theories over New Criticism and its assumptions about literature and literary analysis. Included here are essays on teaching Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1886, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891; Macario Pineda’s “Kasalan sa Malaking Bahay” (Wedding in the Big House); and Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat’s “Tata Selo” (Old Man Selo).

In the second section, Reyes elucidates the influences that prompted the shift from the romantic mode to the realistic mode in Philippine literature, and the dominance of realism in fiction in the first decade of the twentieth century.

The third section contains critical essays that analyze the works of Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar, Macario Pineda, Agustin Fabian, Dominador Mirasol, Genoveva Edroza-Matute, Rosario de Guzman-Lingat, Alejandro Abadilla, and Lamberto Antonio.

The fourth and last section delves into popular culture, the komiks in particular. Included are essays on the komiks strip Kenkoy and on the role of komiks in presenting social realities. Two essays underscore the importance of popular culture in deepening and enhancing the teaching of Philippine literature.

The choice of the essays and their arrangement in the collection reflect the journey the author has taken as a critic, from one schooled in Western thought to one blazing a trail in her analysis of Philippine popular texts. This collection of 28 essays, previously published in various journals, magazines, and books or read at conferences, introduces teachers and students to various approaches to understanding forms of Philippine literature and popular culture. The essays are grouped into four sections: “Teorya at Pagdulog” (Theory and Approach), “Tungkol sa Nobela at Kuwento” (On the Novel and the Short Story), “Indibidwal na Manunulat” (Individual Writers), and “Kulturang Popular” (Popular Culture).

The first section discusses theoretical approaches to literature. The author shows a preference for reader-response theories over New Criticism and its assumptions about literature and literary analysis. article_title: Pagsalunga: Piniling Kuwento at Sanaysay
text:
(Against the Current: Selected Stories and Essays). Published 1992. Author, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat. Manila: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Pagsalunga is a collection of selected works: short stories that deal with political and psychological themes; a chapter from Sikat’s prize-winning novel Dugo sa Bukang-Liwayway (Blood at Daybreak), 1965; literary essays about his craft as a writer; and articles on issues in Philippine literature, language, and culture. It also has an introduction, which is a brief account of a writer’s life and his engagement with the intellectual ferment and social issues of his times.

He explains the use of the word pagsalunga—literally, “going against the tide”—as an apt metaphor for the way his writing, craft, and social consciousness have developed through the years: first as reaction and resistance to traditionalist, sentimentalist, or romantic modes of self-expression; and later as a deliberate critique of Philippine social conditions, particularly in agrarian society with which he is familiar. Specifically, the term defines the orientation of the “Agos” group, whose members, aside from Sikat, were Edgardo M. Reyes, Efren Abueg, Rogelio Ordoñez, Eduardo Bautista Reyes, and Ave Perez Jacob. The “iconoclasm” ascribed to this group came from a desire to bring about a radical change in tone, theme, and trend of Tagalog fiction then current. Sikat describes the popular weekly magazine Liwayway, where he used to work as a very young writer after having been a contributor, as the main purveyor at that time of “traditional” literature, aptly summed up by the magazine’s motto emblazoned round its logo: “aliw ng tahanan”—meaning, family entertainment.

Sikat also mentions the rise of New Criticism in the 1950s. Sikat was convinced that this Western literary doctrine upheld the primacy of craft, obscuring the “national” content of a literary work. He thought that the writer should highlight the Filipino character in writing, and that literature must go back to portraying the Filipino experience. In the same introduction, however, Sikat, in comparing literature in English with literature in Filipino, notes how the former is more modern and progressive.

One of the stories included is “Ama” (Father), in which a governor’s bodyguard, directed to assassinate a peasant leader who has been criticizing the governor as a land-grabber, has a change of heart when he learns he has some things in common with the intended victim—poverty and a very sick child—and decides to go back to working his field. In “Bilangguan” (Jail), a domineering father treats his daughters like prisoners; the elder daughter elopes and the younger one is left alone. In “Lumang Kotse” (Old Car), a son buys creature comforts, including a secondhand car, for his aging father who has put him through college at the cost of the older man’s health, to make his father’s last days on earth the happiest of his life. In “Quentin,” the deformed, unkempt bellringer of San Fernando falls in love with the Blessed Virgin-like belle of the town, but ends up ringing the sonorous bells during her wedding to a rich man. In “Impeng Negro” (Impen the Negro), Impen is a dark-colored GI baby tormented by Ogor, the bully at the artesian well, but he gets back by beating the ogre to submission and savors the victory of an underdog.

“Tata Selo” (Old Man Selo) is Sikat’s most celebrated work. It tells the story of an old tenant who is locked up in the stockade for killing the landowner. Asked by people and authorities for his motive, he says that the victim was evicting him from the land he was leasing. The bigger reason is revealed at the end. The landowner had raped his daughter Saling, who was working as a servant in the landowner’s house. “Tata Selo” was later adapted into a play and a short feature film.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

article_title: Pagsasatubuanan: Poetikang Bikolnon
text:
(Pagsasatubuanan: Bikol Poetics). Published 2008. Author, Jose Jason Chancoco. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Premio Tomas Arejola, 2009.

Pagsasatubuanan is the first book-length study of the rawitdawit or Bikol poetry, and the only major scholarly work on the subject written in Bikol. The book introduces readers to the theoretical elements, roots, and wisdom of the form, and moves from the oral tradition to the written trends.

The first three chapters discuss the basic rhyming elements and patterns, the third focusing specifically on local poetic forms: the tigsik, a toast; ariwaga, or proverbs, which use local elements of work or nature; and patood, or riddles, which have double meanings, usually playful, if not naughty. The third chapter also discusses foreign poetic forms, such as the sonnet, villanelle, and rondelle, written in the Bikol languages.

Chapter 4 focuses on the meter of the rawitdawit. The author shares here his opinion regarding the Spanish influence on the Bikol aesthetic. This chapter acts as a bridge to the next chapters, which mostly revolve around figurative language and content.

The fifth chapter discusses line schemes and the elements of the pasaysay (narrative), paladawan (images/abstractions), and halo (a mixture of both narrative and images).

The sixth chapter illustrates how some contemporary authors have broken away from or satirize the elements of the traditional or Spanish-influenced rawitdawit. The penultimate section takes the readers to the poetics and theories of the author as applied to sample poems by contemporary Bikol writers Frank Peñones and Kristian Cordero of Iriga. This chapter delves into the use of imagery, local idiomatic expressions, and the extrinsic/intrinsic influences on the author in writing the rawitdawit.

The last chapter explores the modern and postmodern forms of Bikol poetry. The author explains the key elements of free verse, its advantages and potential disadvantages, and the reasons for one’s studying the discipline of traditional forms first before delving into the more modern forms.

Pagsasatubuanan is a landmark study of Bikol poetry. It gives the reader a glimpse of its themes and forms and the possible directions that the region’s literary identity may take, although to fully appreciate it, one is required to go back to the early academic anthologies such as Maria Realubit’s Bikols of the Philippines, 1983,and Bikol Literary History, 2000, as well as to Virgilio S. Almario’s study of Tagalog poetry. In addition, the book provides heretofore unavailable terms in Bikol that one may use in writers’ workshops and literary criticism. It challenges young scholars to study and not merely appreciate the most recent incarnations of the rawitdawit written by a new generation of writers.  Written by Jay Salvosa

article_title: Paksa Workbook
text:
Mimeographed 1971. Editor, Maria Lorena Barros. Mimeoscript. Manila: Panulat para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan (PAKSA). Reprinted in limited editions, Manila: Konsehong Tagapag-ugnay ng Rebolusyonaryong Sining, 1971; Manila: Pambansang Unyon ng mga Manunulat, 1992.

A volume of criticism actually titled Panitikan mula sa Masa at tungo sa Masa (Literature from the Masses and to the Masses), this is a compilation of annotations and reviews of the works of art and literature of the national democratic movement during the years 1970 and 1971. Featured in the survey and critiques are plays, short stories, poems, songs, and art works of all the major Manila-based cultural organizations of the national democratic movement. These organizations are the Panday-Sining, Gintong Silahis, Samahang Kamanyang, Tanghalang Bayan, Nagkakaisang Progresibong Artista-Arkitekto, Sining Bayan, and PAKSA.

According to the book’s preface, the motive is “to ensure that literature and art fit well into the revolutionary machine…. that they operate as powerful weapons for uniting and educating the people … and that they help the people fight the enemy with one heart and one mind.” The avowed aims are to popularize mass criticism while helping artists hone their skills.

The scholar of Philippine culture will find in the workbook a veritable wealth of study of the period’s revolutionary and progressive literature and art. This study gives a brief review of the general historical context of the genres and the contending traditions and schools of thought; it presents synopses and descriptions of major works by activists and compares works belonging to either side of the ideological fence. Critical reviews and concrete, specific recommendations to upgrade the works are given. The criticisms and recommendations hew closely to Mao’s ideas expressed in Talks at the Yenan Forum on Art and Literature, which stresses the importance of noting the artists’ and writers’ world outlook, their choice of audience, and their “self-remolding” to become “true artists and writers of, and for, the people.”  Written by Victor Pablo

article_title: Pasyon and Revolution: Popular Movements in the Philippines, 1840-1910
text:
Published 1979, reprinted 1981, 1989, 1997, 2011. Author, Reynaldo Clemeña Ileto. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This book takes the pasyon or narrative of the passion of Christ as the primary source for the study of popular consciousness. Ileto’s thesis is that revolutionary movements in the Philippines from 1840 to 1910 gained large numbers of adherents because these movements shared several characteristics with the ever popular pasyon. Ileto views the movements “from below”—that is, from the point of the view of the masses, the ones who have kept the pasyon alive. Ileto studies movements headed by Apolinario de la Cruz, aka Hermano Pule, Januario Labios, Arsenio de Guzman, and Felipe Salvador. In the course of his discussion, Ileto clarifies the roles of such groups as the Santa Iglesia, the Watawat ng Lahi, the Colorum Society, and the Katipunan.

The bulk of the book is concerned with this last group. Ileto argues that the people who joined the Katipunan saw the revolution primarily in terms of the pasyon. Andres Bonifacio, for instance, patterned his manifesto, titled “Ang Dapat Mabatid ng mga Tagalog” (What the Tagalog Should Know), after the pasyon. The redemption of the country, Bonifacio suggested, was as inevitable as the redemption narrated in this verse narrative; the Tagalog, in short, would successfully revolt against the Spaniards. Moreover, the initiation rites of the Katipunan were filled with pasyon imagery.

Ileto criticizes the elite, not only the ilustrado (educated native) who wrested the leadership of the Philippine Revolution from the hands of Bonifado, but also the modern-day ilustrado or middle class, who interpret Philippine history in order to justify the takeover of Emilio Aguinaldo. Ileto argues that the common people who joined the Katipunan saw Aguinaldo as a betrayer; and that the masses viewed the Malolos Congress and the Philippine Assembly as discontinuous with the struggle for Philippine nationhood.  Written by Isagani R. Cruz
