article_title: Paz Marquez Benitez: One Woman's Life, Letters, and Writings
text:
Published 1996. Author, Virginia Benitez Licuanan. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Paz Marquez Benitez is best remembered as the writer of the short story “Dead Stars” and as the teacher of a generation of Filipino writers. The book Paz Marquez Benitez: One Woman’s Life, Letters, and Writings, written by her daughter, offers glimpses into the private life behind the public figure. Drawing on her mother’s letters, journals, scrapbooks, diaries, “notes scribbled … on scraps of paper, on the backs of old receipts, bills, lists, used envelopes,” as well as from her own store of memories and letters from friends and relatives, Licuanan presents us with the tapestry of Benitez’s colorful life.

The book is divided into three parts. The first two alternate excerpts from Benitez’s letters and Licuanan’s narrative accounts. The third part excerpts from Benitez’s diaries and journals. The book also contains a folio of photographs.

“The Years of Youth, 1894-1929” recounts Benitez’s girlhood in Tayabas, her hometown and her encounter with the culture wrought by Americanization and colonization. The most interesting portion of the first part is her romance with Francisco Benitez, who would be her husband for 38 years. Licuanan describes their married life as a “happy meeting of contrasting but congenial personalities.”

“The Golden Years, 1930-1939” forms the bulk of the book and presents the “high tide” of Benitez’s life as wife, mother, and professional. Her letters to Licuanan, then studying in the United States, recount domestic happenings—birthdays, weddings, parties—but also advert to the burning issues of the period—the national language, Philippine independence, and religious instruction in schools. In this section, one almost eavesdrops on the conversations between Benitez and the major players of Commonwealth-era Philippines:  Sergio Osmeña, Carlos Romulo, Camilo Osias,  Teodoro Kalaw, and especially Quezon. The other half of this section consists of Benitez’s letters to Francisco, mostly about her travels in Europe and the United States.

The troubled times that came after, which would bring on loss—of property, friends, an entire way of life—are the preoccupation of much of the third section, titled “The Years of Change, 1940-1983.” The entries during the war years are short, some only a sentence long. The enormity of the war and the Japanese occupation is conveyed not by images of bloodshed or violence but by observations quietly and briefly noted: “Everybody seems to be baking their own bread these days now that pan de sal costs P5.00 each.”

Licuanan remembers how her mother’s farmer instincts saved the family from starvation. Benitez turned the swimming pool into a fishpond and raised vegetables. Milk for her grandchild (Licuanan’s firstborn) came from the goats that she tended herself.

The years after World War II were to bring another loss: that of Francisco, in 1951. Except for her initial “wild weeping,” Benitez’s grief, Licuanan recounts, was silent. It is in her writings that one senses the extent of her grief. In a note addressed to her dead husband, she writes, “Dear, it is so easy, in a way, to love the dead. They are so silent, so undemanding.” Benitez herself would die 32 years later, in 1983.

This book allows her to come alive again. More than presenting her as “the author of ‘Dead Stars,’” it shows us Benitez as independent thinker, a romantic but also a realist when the times demand swift action, an artist sensitive to life’s beauty and its miseries and always able to give these verbal expression. Readers see her dancing the foxtrot, in a terno posing for the Philippines Herald, playing the classics on an old Steinway, among antiques and paintings, tending a garden of jacarandas, petunias, dahlias, chrysanthemums, and an ancient tamarind tree—all perhaps just trivial information to some people but clues to one remarkable woman’s personality and to an era’s mores.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Personal: Mga Sanaysay sa Lupalop ng Gunita
text:
(Personal: Essays from the Realm of Remembrance). Published 1999. Author, Rene O. Villanueva. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

The collection of 42 short personal essays about childhood and early adulthood is divided into three parts: “Matris ng Memorya” (Womb of Memory), “Lunsaran ng Malay” (Beginnings of Consciousness), and “Lupalop ng Gunita” (Realm of Remembrance). It is a document of both Villanueva’s personal history and of life in Manila in the 1960s and 1970s.

The essays in “Matris ng Memorya” are about his parents: Francisco Villanueva and Vicenta Ocampo Villanueva. In “Lilip” (Border-Stitch), his mother, a seamstress, takes extra jobs even on Christmas and New Year’s Eve. “Pasko ng Pagkabuhay” (Easter Sunday), “Laban ni Tatay” (Father’s Fight), and “Paralisado” (Paralyzed) are about the family’s struggles to survive after the father’s stroke. In “Laban ni Tatay,” the father’s overriding desire to live makes him reject the Sacrament of Extreme Unction. In “Paralisado,” the son conducts the daily ritual of dressing his father. In all these essays, Villanueva reveals the emotional distance between him and his parents that was caused by poverty and daily hardships.

The essays in “Lunsaran ng Malay” are about Villanueva’s childhood experiences. These shaped his psyche and character. In “Bahay” (House), he and his family move from one rented house to another. In “Stereo,” “Sine” (Movies), “TV,” and “Komiks” (Comics), his fascination with popular culture helps him cope with poverty. In “BTS” and “Bomba,” his discovery of pornography leads to his sexual awakening. In “Runner” and “Janitor,” he works as a runner for an illegal gambling operation run by his uncle and a church janitor.

“Lupalop ng Gunita” consists of essays about the places and people that made an impact on Villanueva: in “Blumentritt,” his daily walk to the public market; in “Linda,” a neighbor who is forced by poverty to work as a dancer; and in “Edith,” a lady he suspects to be his father’s mistress.

The book is an exemplar of the memoir. There is much humor, wit, poignancy, and grace beneath the simplicity of Villanueva’s style. He neither romanticizes poverty nor moralizes on it, opting rather to contextualize it within the struggles of ordinary people living in Manila.  Written by Christoper Mitch Cerda

article_title: Philippine Literature: A History and Anthology
text:
Published 1982. Editors, Bienvenido L. Lumbera and Cynthia Nograles Lumbera. Manila: National Book Store. Revised edition, Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 1997.

The book departs from the previously published textbooks in Philippine literature in the country; it makes the “periodization of Philippine literary history follow a political framework.” The editors believe that studying Philippine literature should not be a simple chronology of celebrated authors and literary works but rather an analysis of authors and works in their historical and political contexts. As the preface to the first edition of the book states, “To show the interplay between colonial strategy and Filipino response is to unlock Philippine literature so that it would yield insights into our history, our culture and, perhaps, even our national psyche.”

The book is divided into sections according to historical periods (four in the first edition, and five in the revised). Each section contains an overview of the historical conditions, literary activities, and issues of the period, and an anthology of representative works from various Philippine languages.

The first section, “Oral Lore from Precolonial Times (—1564),” covers riddles, proverbs, songs, myths, folktales, and epics. The language of folk literature was the language of the daily lives and common experiences of the natives. Thus, the authorship of literary works was communal.

The next section, “Literature under Spanish Colonialism (1565-1897),” explains the emergence of a binary created by colonialism between those natives who were heavily influenced by the power of the Church and of the State (the taga-bayan) and those who embraced the indigenous culture by staying in the hinterlands and the mountains (the taga-bukid and the taga-bundok). This distinction inaugurated an important shift in the development of Philippine literature. The taga-bayan became the first wave of published writers and eventually the ilustrado (educated native), the class which aimed at reforming the colonial administration. The taga-bukid/taga-bundok ultimately broke away from reformism to pursue revolution.

In “Literature under US Colonialism (1898-1945),” the editors explain that the dichotomy was sharpened in the next period. The taga-bayan abandoned the taga-bukid/taga-bundok and expressed allegiance to the new colonizer. The Americanization of Philippine society led to the debate between the writers who followed the school of “art for art’s sake” and those who were committed to “socially conscious literature.”

The next section, “Literature under the Republic (1946-1985),” deals with the merging of Euro-Hispanic and American traditions in Philippine literature. This period also saw writers focusing on the quest for self-identity and national self-image, for one, and the increasing militancy against colonial education, feudal institutions, and fascist administration, for another.

In “Literature after EDSA (1896-1995),” the editors identify four developments in contemporary Philippine literature: the emergence of literary theories and approaches, which invited new ways of reading literary works; the increase of university presses and trade publishers; the production of literary works that represent and give critical attention to women, gays, and lesbians; and efforts at constructing a more regionally and linguistically inclusive national literature.

Philippine Literature: A History and Anthology is pioneering work for periodizing Philippine literature as a consequence of colonialism. The book did not rely on foreign theories and discourses in its analysis of the legacies of colonialism. Instead, the analyses are borne out by a long intellectual tradition that can be traced back to the precolonial Philippines.  Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos

article_title: The Philippine Poetic
text:
Published 1976. Author, Ophelia Alcantara Dimalanta. With a foreword by Pompeyo de Mesa, OP. Manila: Colegio de San Juan de Letran.

This book is a guide to the leading Filipino poets in English and a survey of the trends in poetry writing in English from the 1950s to the early 1970s, by way of a critical appraisal of Palanca Award winners. Critiqued are Carlos Angeles’s A Stun of Jewels, 1963; Epifanio San Juan’s God-Kissing Carrion, 1964; Emmanuel Torres’s Angels and Fugitives, 1966; Manuel Viray’s After This Exile, 1965; Edith Tiempo’s Tracks of Babylon, 1966; G. Burce Bunao’s The Quiver and the Fear, 1968; Federico Licsi Espino’s Dark Sutra, 1969, and Counterclockwise, 1969; Hilario Francia’s Selected Poems, 1970; Virginia Moreno’s Batik-Maker and Other Poems, 1972; and Cirilo Bautista’s The Archipelago, 1970, and Telex Moon, 1981. Dimalanta’s own collection, Montage, 1974, is reviewed by Fideliza Noel. These are all first-prize winners, with the exception of After This Exile.

The survey opens with a critical account of the unfolding of styles in Filipino poetry writing, against a backdrop of international English poetry writing, in the 50 years beginning with the 1920s. The final article is a study of current trends and directions, touching on other poets not included in the detailed critiques, and also of poetry writing in Pilipino.

The predominant mode of analysis is textual and formalist, and not moral, psychological, or social. Dimalanta stresses the importance of form, referring to such critic-writers as T. S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, and C. Day Lewis, and contends that the poet must match message with medium, thereby affirming the view that the poem is a unique self-contained artifact. This collection brings to light the aesthetic criteria implicit in the Palanca jury’s choices.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Victor Calizo

article_title: Philippine-American Literary Relations: 1898-1941
text:
Published 1969. Author, Lucila Hosillos. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This book analyzes the social, political, and intellectual factors that informed Philippine literature at the beginning of the American colonial period. It describes the “culture upheaval” that the first generation of Filipino writers in English experienced. For comparative purposes, the book also includes a general sketch of Tagalog writing during that same period.

Hosillos identifies the causes of the culture upheaval to be popular education, the introduction of the English language, and religious reformation. Hence, the Filipino studied the American traditional literary genres, history, and culture as part of the American program of cultural assimilation. It was part of the American political program to send pensionados or scholars to study in the United States. The result of this program was a school of writers who imitated American models. However, much of the imitation, especially of O. Henry’s formula, was “mechanical and artificial.” For example, Bret Harte’s use of local color and his sentimentalism were imitated but at the expense of his “regional realism.” The social message through satire in Mark Twain’s and Ring Lardner’s works was lost to both writer and reader. Imitations of Edna St. Vincent Millay’s and e. e. cummings’s style produced Philippine poetry that was “confused and debilitated.” The introspective tone and psychological depth of Sherwood Anderson were missing.

In turn, the American reception to Philippine literature was lopsided: American writers showed more interest in Philippine politics, and those who did evince an interest in Philippine literature were out merely to find the quaint, the exotic, and the picturesque. American critics dismissed Philippine literature as vacuous. Hosillos argues, however, that this lack of appreciation was because of their ignorance of Philippine local language literary traditions. She describes the sudden outburst of Philippine local language literature during the same period as being the nationalistic reaction of writers to Americanization.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Mga Piling Sanaysay
text:
(Selected Essays). Published 1950. Editor, Alejandro G. Abadilla. Manila: Inang Wika Publishing House.

This is the first compilation of essays in Tagalog. Most of these essays were previously published in Liwayway during the war years. Only two—“Durungawan” (Window) and “Alaala ng Isang Taglagas” (Memories of an Autumn)—had been written before World War II. The rest of the essays were written between 1945 and 1950.

The works comprising the anthology are diverse in topic and style, but can be classified under any of five main themes. “Si Elias sa Nobela ni Rizal” (Elias in Rizal’s Novel) by Teodoro Agoncillo, “Si Rizal ang Sagisag” (Rizal the Symbol) by Eleuterio Fojas, “Ako’y Isang Tinig” (One Voice Am I) by Genoveva Edroza-Matute, and “Diwang Kayumanggi” (Spirit of the Brown Race) by Narciso G. Reyes deal with love of country. “Alaala ng Isang Taglagas” (Memories of One Autumn) by Pedro S. Dandan and “Paggising ng Kalikasan” (When Nature Awakens) by David T. Mamaril are about nature. “Sa Pagsilang ng Isang Buhay” (The Birth of a Life) by Liwayway Arceo, “Pagutusan ang Pangalan Ko” (Pagutusan Is My Name) by Mabini Rey Centeno, “Pag-iisa” (Solitude) by Lina Flor, “Ang Kakambal ng Ligaya” (The Twin of Happiness) by Maria Luna Lopez, “Naunsiyaming Pag-asa” (Dashed Hopes) by Gemiliano Pineda, and “Pangarap ng Kabataan” (The Dream of Youth) by Pablo Gloriano are personal reflections on life. “Ang Panitikan Ay Sinlaya ng Buhay” (Literature Is as Free as Life) by Cornelio Reyes, “Ang ‘Ako ang Daigdig’ ni Abadilla” (Abadilla’s ‘Ako ang Daigdig’) by Clodualdo del Mundo, “Simula ng Bagong Panahon ng Tulang Tagalog” (The New Age of Tagalog Poetry Begins) by Ildefonso Santos, and “Ang Florante sa Ating Panitikan” (The Florante in Our Literature) by Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido deal with literature. The rest of the essays—“Makisindi Nga, Pare Ko” (Give Me a Light, My Friend) by Teo S. Baylen, “Sa Paglilihi” (On Conceiving) by Alfredo S. Enriquez, and “Ang Pagpupulis Trapiko Ay Isang Sining” (Being a Traffic Cop Is an Art) by Epifanio G. Matute—are light observations on ordinary occurrences.

In all, the essays deal with a variety of subjects reflective of enduring concerns and embody genteel observations on life as lived by Filipinos in a time of turbulence and deep historical change. The essays of the wartime period are understandably devoid of sharply critical reflections on social and political conditions, as these were published in a Japanese-controlled outlet. But the prewar and postwar pieces, as selected by anthologist Abadilla, seem to shy away too from tackling the social and ideological themes evident in the other genres and popular during these historical periods.  Written by Vina Paz, Victoria Cao, and Edgardo Maranan

article_title: Poetikang Tagalog: Mga Unang Pagsusuri sa Sining ng Pagtulang Tagalog
text:
(Tagalog Poetics: Early Critical Works on the Art of Tagalog Poetry). Published 1996. Editor, Virgilio S. Almario. With a foreword by Carmen D. Padilla and an introduction by the editor. Tagalog translations by Trinidad O. Regala and the Jose Rizal Centennial Commission. Quezon City: Sentro ng Wikang Filipino.

The book is an anthology of studies—a book excerpt, two books, and a lecture—on Tagalog poetry by Fray Gaspar de San Agustin, Fray Francisco Bencuchillo, Jose P. Rizal, and Lope K. Santos.

“De la Poesia Tagala” (On Tagalog Poetry) is from San Agustin’s Compendio de la Lengua Tagala (Summary of the Tagalog Language), 1703. The excerpt discusses the characteristics of Tagalog syllables, Tagalog meter, and root words with a stretched H sound. San Agustin remarks that Tagalog poetry is not so difficult as it seems, and that, unlike Spanish poetry, it does not have strict rules. He observes that Tagalog poems typically have three to six lines, with seven to eight syllables per line; however, he adds, some lines, like those of the comedia, have 12-14 syllables. He affirms the existence of the early forms of Tagalog poetry—namely, talingdao, soliranin, diona, oyayi, and auit (awit).

Arte Poetico Tagalo (Art of Tagalog Poetry), 1895, by Bencuchillo discusses 37 items, and begins with the statement that Tagalog poetry is neither easy nor difficult. Like San Agustin, Bencuchillo claims that Spanish is the more sophisticated language, possessing harmony and rhythm, which he thinks Tagalog lacks. He affirms San Agustin’s observations on the length of Tagalog poems and Tagalog verse.

The rules of Tagalog poetry are far better explained in Rizal’s Arte Metrica del Tagalog (The Metrical Art of the Tagalog), 1887. Rizal notes that the common number of syllables per line is between 6 and 12, with a break after the sixth or seventh syllable in a 12-syllable line; that the occasional tuldik, or accent marks, on the last syllables do not harm the poem; and that there are 12 kinds of rhymes, including the monorhyme.

Santos’s lecture, “Peculiaridades de la Poesia Tagala” (Characteristics of Tagalog Poetry), 1929, is in part a review of previous studies on Tagalog poetry. Except for the work of Fr Joaquin de Coria, Santos criticizes the efforts of the Spanish friars as being biased. He notes that one of the “peculiarities” of Tagalog poetry is its mournful character, which he traces to the poets’ colonial experience.

Santos considers tugma (rhyme), sukat (meter), talinghaga (metaphor), and kariktan (beauty) as the four elements of Tagalog poetry. The first two comprise the structure; the latter two, the soul of poetry. The lengthiest discussion is devoted to rhyme: every stanza must have monorhyme, which is built on vowels, not consonants. There may be alliteration among words within lines. As for meter, Santos affirms previous findings on line length and the sesura (caesura) at the middle of the line. He adds that later Tagalog poetry uses 14 and 16 syllables per line, with a pause sometimes occurring after every four syllables.

The book makes available to modern readers early attempts to codify Tagalog poetry. Almario balances perspectives, with San Agustin and Bencuchillo representing the efforts of the Spanish missionaries to understand the poetics and language of the Tagalog, and Santos and Rizal representing the nationalist spirit in pointing out the indigenous elements and features of Tagalog poetry.  Written by Rebecca T. Añonuevo

Santos’s lecture, “Peculiaridades de la Poesia Tagala” (Characteristics of Tagalog Poetry), 1929, is in part a review of previous studies on Tagalog poetry. Except for the work of Fr Joaquin de Coria, Santos criticizes the efforts of the Spanish friars as being biased. He notes that one of the “peculiarities” of Tagalog poetry is its mournful character, which he traces to the poets’ colonial experience.

Santos considers tugma (rhyme), sukat (meter), talinghaga (metaphor), and kariktan (beauty) as the four elements of Tagalog poetry. The first two comprise the structure; the latter two, the soul of poetry. The lengthiest discussion is devoted to rhyme: every stanza must have monorhyme, which is built on vowels, not consonants. There may be alliteration among words within lines. As for meter, Santos affirms previous findings on line length and the sesura (caesura) at the middle of the line. He adds that later Tagalog poetry uses 14 and 16 syllables per line, with a pause sometimes occurring after every four syllables.

The book makes available to modern readers early attempts to codify Tagalog poetry. Almario balances perspectives, with San Agustin and Bencuchillo representing the efforts of the Spanish missionaries to understand the poetics and language of the Tagalog, and Santos and Rizal representing the nationalist spirit in pointing out the indigenous elements and features of Tagalog poetry.  Written by Rebecca T. Añonuevo

article_title: Pook at Paninindigan: Kritika ng Pantayong Pananaw
text:
(Site and Stand: A Critique of Pantayong Pananaw). Published 2009. Author, Ramon Guillermo. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Pook at Paninindigan (Site and Stand) is divided into two parts. The first part critiques one of the leading theories in Philippine Studies, Zeus Salazar’s Pantayong Pananaw. The second part then reevaluates the history of socialist and Marxist thought and theory in novels and essays written in Filipino in 1906-69. It also includes two appendices: the first is an analysis of Prospero Covar’s theories and the second is a Filipino translation of Karl Marx’s Thesen über Feuerbach.

Guillermo criticizes Salazar’s dismissive attitude toward ideas and theories adopted from the West, which Salazar lumps together under the label “Pangkaming Pananaw” (The Exclusive Filipino We Perspective). Salazar presupposes that all Western ideas, theories, and perspectives are problematic because these do not spring from the consciousness and experiences of the Filipinos. Intellectuals and academics, then, who use these theories are automatically pigeonholed into discoursing only with Westerners and not with the Filipinos, who are their primary audience.

Guillermo challenges this premise and the basic ideas of “Pantayong Pananaw” (The Filipino You-and-I Perspective). First, Pantayong Pananaw’s preference for the Filipino language excludes the possible contributions of intellectual and academic writing written in a foreign language. Even though both the academe and the masses use Filipino, their diction levels, or language registers, differ: intellectual on one hand, and colloquial on the other. Second, Pantayong Pananaw subsumes the nation under the ethnos or ethnic culture that is rooted in precolonial society. Guillermo argues, however, that the “nation” is a modern concept and not just a precolonial one. Third, cultural and linguistic history dominates empirical and documented history in Pantayong Pananaw, which could lead to contradictions and distortions of historical facts. Fourth, Pantayong Pananaw’s preference for language over materiality dislodges the concepts and ideas of Pantayong Pananaw from the materiality of the world.

In the second part, Guillermo reevaluates the evolution of socialist and Marxist thought in the Philippines as proof that the “translation” and “adaptation” of Western ideas and theories can be useful and even socially transformative. He analyzes literary works published between the years 1906, when the first socialist novel, Lope K. Santos’s Banaag at Sikat (Glimmer and Light), was published, and 1969, when Amado V. Hernandez’s Mga Ibong Mandaragit (Birds of Prey) was published. By analyzing these novels and those of Faustino Aguilar and Lazaro Francisco, the short stories of Brigido Batungbakal and Manuel Arguilla, and the political essays of Crisanto Evangelista, Guillermo maps the development of the workers’ movement from what he calls the “age of searching” in 1906-35 to the growing split within the workers’ movement in 1935-69 between the “conciliatory” groups, who looked for a better relationship with capitalists, and the “confrontational” groups, who stressed irreconcilable class differences.

Guillermo highlights the leading role that literature, especially texts written in Tagalog, played in the development of the discourse of the workers’ struggle. It was in the works of Santos, Aguilar, Batungbakal, Arguilla, Francisco, and Hernandez that the issues of labor relations and exploitation were debated upon and analyzed. It was in these texts that socialist and Marxist ideas were first introduced and adapted into Tagalog. By providing an alternative to formalist criticism and a new historization of socialist and Marxist literature, the book is an important contribution to Filipino social theory and literary criticism.   Written by Christoper Mitch Cerda

article_title: The Primal Passion: Tagalog Literature in the Nineteenth Century
text:
Published 1976. Author, Buenaventura S. Medina Jr. With an introduction by Teodoro Agoncillo. Manila: Centro Escolar University Press.

Medina’s book departs from the many literary histories hitherto published, by having a clear framework for analysis. The book examines how Tagalog literature was fashioned out of the passion for freedom, how a literature was created out of politics. Medina’s method is eclectic; he draws heavily from the sociological, historical, and the psychological approaches.

Medina says that the Tagalog are lovers of pain. Borrowing from the critic Mario Praz, he terms this inclination the “romantic agony.” With this concept of the writer responding to and shaped by both private and social experiences, Medina proceeds to study Tagalog literature. He sees this agony in the folk poet who grappled with his realities and thus constructed myths, like the story of Malakas and Maganda. During the Spanish colonial regime, the agony became fused with the kind of suffering that a Christian had to undergo. Christ was the embodiment of this kind of agony and the image with which the Tagalog identified most closely. Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar, Jose Rizal, Marcelo H. del Pilar, Emilio Jacinto, and Andres Bonifacio continued the tradition. Their audiences were witnesses to the merging of aesthetics and politics, the self-conscious acting out of that fundamental romantic agony which has compelled them to transform their experience into passionate expressions of their commitment to freedom.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Pungsod: Damming the Nation; Region/Nation and The Global Order in Contemporary West Visayan Literature
text:
Published 2009. Author, Isidoro M. Cruz. Iloilo City: University of San Agustin Publishing House. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for literary criticism, 2010.

Pungsod (Nation) analyzes the West Visayan writer’s position in regional, national, and global discourses by an examination of the works of seven writers: Leoncio P. Deriada, John Iremil E. Teodoro, Vicente G. Groyon, Alicia Tan-Gonzales, Isabel D. Sebullen, Genevieve Asenjo, and Alice M. Sun-Cua. Cruz points out that these writers use ethnicity, language, spectacle, gossip, cartography, pornography, and other technologies to disrupt cultural homogenization, which is the handiwork of the nation-state and of the global order.

In Deriada’s story “Dam,” the main character Dumpit tries to save his community from foreign incursion by digging a channel with his bare hands to redirect the course of the river. Cruz interprets this scene as the use of native knowledge and technology against national and global cultural dominance. The dam represents technology that the natives hold some mastery over; thus, it is also a metaphor for West Visayan writers’ attempt to negotiate with and counter the national and global cultural forces.

This resistance comes in various shapes: Groyon’s novel, The Sky over Dimas, 2003, uses gossip, pornography, and cartography. The main character, who is based in Manila, constructs the image of his home island Negros and the Philippines through bits of unreliable information or gossip. Cruz calls this “illegitimate history,” which is simultaneously a unifying and divisive force. On the other hand, the “damming” in Tan-Gonzales’s short story “Esperanza” comes in the form of a “secret message” that has to be torn into pieces and flushed down a toilet as an act of resistance to the Japanese forces during World War II. It is this story from which Cruz takes the word “pungsod,” which literally means “group of the same kind of trees” and which Tan-Gonzales uses to refer to the nation.

Cruz notes that Teodoro privileges the native in the series of place names composing the title of his book Maybato, Iloilo, Taft Avenue, Baguio, Puerto, 2003. “Maybato,” the first word in this title, is a town in Antique. Additionally, Teodoro rejects the traditional but exclusionary construction of the nation as “Appari to Jolo” by using the phrase, “Batanes to Jolo” instead. Finally, Teodoro’s use of “Visayan-laced Filipino,” as espoused by Leoncio Deriada, counters the prevailing assumption that Filipino as the national language is Tagalog based. Thus, Teodoro’s act of rewriting the language and the nation to foreground West Visayas is a blurring of the line between margin and center.

Short stories by Sebullen and Asenjo deconstruct region and nation as binary opposites. In Sebullen’s “Ang mga Birhen sa Masulog” (The Virgins of Masulog), a doctor and National Bureau of Investigation agent returns from Manila to her home barrio to catch a criminal. Triumphant, she promises to build a school there, thus demonstrating that the national capital defines the periphery by its own terms. In contrast, Asenjo’s “taga-uma@manila” shows two characters from the same provincial hometown reconnecting in Makati as neighbors, thus countering the city’s threat to ethnic identity.

In Sun-Cua’s collection, Chartered Prophecies, 2002, the foregrounding of Chinese Filipinos presents the nation as a global entity. In two of her poems, travel is a metaphor for constructing a nation. In “Grandmother (After a Visit to Lunghou, Chingkiang, China),” the persona experiences a sense of dual origins and belonging. In “Neighbor’s Thoughts upon Seeing the Visitor from Lu-Sung,” foot binding becomes a metaphor for the complex weave of commonalities and differences between a young woman and her grandmother.

The West Visayan writings analyzed in Pungsod present a regional construct of a national community. Hence, to refer to the nation as “pungsod” rather than “inang-bayan” (motherland) is, for Cruz, to recognize both the singular and plural character of the Philippine nation. For West Visayan writers to think in these terms is for them to “dam” their native and regional resources and rechannel them toward a more inclusive notion of the nation.  Written by John E. Barrios

article_title: The Radical Tradition in Philippine Literature
text:
Published 1971. Author, EpifanioSanJuanJr. Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co.

This volume is a collection of seven essays and a summative appendix written “in response to various occasions” all “inquiring into the social function of the literary artist.” The essays seek to clarify what San Juan has termed the radical tradition in Philippine literature. The publication of the book was apparently spurred by the national democratic activist phenomenon in the First Quarter Storm of 1970. Most of the essays, however, were written in the 1960s.

San Juan studies the poetics of Amado V. Hernandez and Carlos Bulosan. Other essays study Jose Rizal’s significance in literary history and the socialism of Lope K.Santos and Jose Ma. Sison, as well as the general social crisis gripping the country. The author avers that this crisis is the context of the true Filipino writer. Truth, he says, is a matter of historical and social practice. In each essay, San Juan presents the breadth and depth of the subject writers’ thought as expounded in their works, although in at least three of them he claims tentativeness in his conclusions. By dissecting their “central attitude and outlook,” he lays down the aesthetic pattern starting from Rizal of the Spanish era up to Sison during the US-Marcos regime, to establish the radical tradition in Philippine literary history and aesthetics. Such a tradition “begins with the folklore and the folk art of the prehispanic times, quietly flourishing through the centuries of Spanish tyranny” and then explodes in the works of Francisco "Balagtas" Baltazar, Andres Bonifacio, Apolinario Mabini, and Emilio Jacinto. It forms a continuum with the activist theater of Juan Abad, Severino Reyes, Aurelio V. Tolentino, and others during the early American occupation; and continues to the testing period of the Commonwealth with such writers as Salvador P. Lopez, Arturo B.Rotor, and Angel Baking.

San Juan’s definitions and contentions await a more thorough public discussion. But the author must be acknowledged as one among the earlier Filipino writers to formulate theories on Philippine literature with a clear preference for the Marxist framework. He expounds on the necessity for a partisan aesthetics, indicting those whom he perceives as having betrayed the genuine vocation of the writer, which is to emancipate the masses from ignorance and from the mystifications that have been foisted upon them by the ruling classes.  Written by Victor Pablo

article_title: The Recto Valedictory
text:
Published 1985. Author, Claro M. Recto. Essays originally published in Manila Sunday Chronicle, 1960. English translation by Nick Joaquin. With an introduction by Nick Joaquin and a foreword by Lorenzo M. Tañada. Manila: Claro M. Recto Foundation.

This is a compilation of speeches originally written in Spanish by Claro M. Recto, intended to be delivered in Spain in 1960. However, Recto died before he could deliver them. As a tribute, the Manila Sunday Chronicle published these undelivered speeches. Five of them are about notable Filipinos. “Manuel Luis Quezon” is a paean to the partriotism of Quezon and his efforts at attaining national independence. “Cayetano S. Arellano” eulogizes Arellano’s less fiery, more quiet, but equally genuine patriotism. “Cecilio Apostol” and “Manuel Bernabe” are tributes to the artistry of the two writers in Spanish. Recto notes Cecilio Apostol’s profundity and patriotism, and the precision of his language; he calls Bernabe the heir of the great writers in Spanish. “Rizal y sus ‘Memorias de Estudiante”’ (Rizal and His “Memories of a Student”) presents excerpts from Jose Rizal’s memoirs. Two speeches are about the Spanish language. In both, Recto contends that Spanish is so much a part of Philippine culture that to neglect it is to reduce Philippine culture. In “Por los Fueros de una Herencia” (For the Rights of a Heritage), Recto enumerates the legacies of the Spanish language and includes a poem in praise of the language. “La Cruzada por el Español en Filipinas” (The Crusade for Spanish in the Philippines) describes how Rizal used Spanish to spread his ideals and notes why Spanish failed to take root in the Philippines. The other speeches are on international politics and on the Spanish woman. “Los Convenios sobre Bases Militares entre España y los Estados Unidos y entre Filipinas y los Estados Unidos” (The Military Treaties on Bases between Spain and the United States and between the Philippines and the United States) exposes the imbalance, favoring the United States, in the terms of the military treatise. “El Pacto del Atlantico y el Pacto del Pacifico” (The Atlantic Pact and the Pacific Pact) shows the contradictions in both pacts. “La Mujer Española” (The Spanish Woman) contains a poem by Jesus Balmori in praise of Spain. One speech not included in the book is “La Monarquia Norteamericana” (The North American Monarchy), a political satire.

These speeches demonstrate Recto’s mastery of the Spanish language and his fervid nationalism. His rhetoric is vigorous and poetic, elaborately Castilian but clear.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Revaluation: Essays on Philippine Literature, Cinema and Popular Culture
text:
Published 1984. Author, Bienvenido Lumbera. Index Press. Reprinted, Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House, 1997.

This book is a collection of essays that Lumbera wrote between 1965 and 1981. The objective of the collection, according to the preface, is “to arrive at a new estimation of the value of some important components of Philippine culture; literature, theater, cinema, popular culture … [and] to revalidate the position of the arts in the rapidly changing circumstances of our national life.” Most of the essays have originally appeared elsewhere, as in the books Third World Readings and Book of the Philippines 1976, and the periodicals the Review, Diliman Review, International Pop Culture, Philippine Studies, and Cultural Research Bulletin. One essay, “The Nationalist Literary Tradition,” is a paper that Lumbera presented at a 1980 conference in the United States on Philippine studies.

The book is divided into three parts. The first part contains essays on Philippine literature and theater, the second deals with cinema and popular culture, and the third contains reviews of particular works. The first essay, “Towards a Revised History of Philippine Literature,” presents the historical background and sets the theoretical framework for the study of Philippine literature. The method is dialectical, exploring the development of Philippine literature within the context of the country’s experience of colonialism, war, revolution, and class relationships.

Lumbera’s framework is further elucidated in the other essays in parts 1 and 2, where he discusses and demonstrates its application to more specific areas of Philippine literature and culture, such as literary criticism, local language literature, drama, and film. Lumbera also discusses the political nature of popular culture and the dilemmas of the Filipino writer. In part 3, the essays comment on Linda Ty-Casper’s The Peninsulars, Alejandro G. article.value: Published 1984. Author, Bienvenido Lumbera. Index Press. Reprinted, Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House, 1997.

This book is a collection of essays that Lumbera wrote between 1965 and 1981. The objective of the collection, according to the preface, is “to arrive at a new estimation of the value of some important components of Philippine culture; literature, theater, cinema, popular culture … [and] to revalidate the position of the arts in the rapidly changing circumstances of our national life.” Most of the essays have originally appeared elsewhere, as in the books Third World Readings and Book of the Philippines 1976, and the periodicals the Review, Diliman Review, International Pop Culture, Philippine Studies, and Cultural Research Bulletin. One essay, “The Nationalist Literary Tradition,” is a paper that Lumbera presented at a 1980 conference in the United States on Philippine studies.

article_title: The Romance Mode in Philippine Literature and Other Essays
text:
Published 1988. Author, Soledad S. Reyes. With an introduction by Isagani R. Cruz. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

A collection of essays previously published in journals and books, it surveys Philippine literary history and Philippine literary criticism. The book is divided into four sections: “Theory and Criticism,” “On Individual Writers,” “On Movements/Trends,” and “On Popular Culture.”

“Recent Trends in Literary History and the Study of Philippine Literature” briefly summarizes Western literary theories and criticism that have challenged formalism. “The Romance Mode in Philippine Popular Literature” observes how a large number of Filipino works have been undervalued as a result of the institutionalization of realist criticism. In “Philippine Literary Studies, 1970-1985: Some Preliminary Notes,” Reyes describes some features of literary studies prior to the 1970s, which included the marginalization of regional literatures and, conversely, the valorization of Tagalog or English texts. Reyes cites such critics as Isagani Cruz, Resil B. Mojares, and Epifanio San Juan Jr as among those who have started to employ alternative critical approaches.

Many of the essays deal with literary and cultural forms that are explicitly subversive: “The Literature of the Propaganda Movement (1880-1896),” “Reforms and Revolution,” “The Impact of Rizal’s Noli and Fili on the Tagalog Novel,” “Philippine Literature since 1972: A Discourse on Disorder,” and “Language as Power in a World Turned Upside Down.” But Reyes also notes implicit subversions operating within literary and cultural texts which, in general, support a predominantly conservative ideology. In “The Subversive Role of Female Characters,” for example, she finds in some Tagalog novels a subversive woman’s voice which questions the traditional image of the ideal woman. “The Outlaw and the Prostitute” and “Love and Marriage in the Tagalog Novel” are similar essays.

Reyes also deals with individual writers like Macario Pineda and Ildefonso Santos; and on popular cultural forms like the komiks, local women’s magazines, and popular slogans emerging from the 1986 EDSA “revolution.” On academic curricular programs, Reyes offers “The Interdisciplinary Studies Program” against the trend toward more rigid specialization in academic institutions. She cites the use of the interdisciplinary approach in Philippine studies in the work of Reynaldo C. Ileto, Vicente Marasigan, Isagani R. Cruz, Resil B. Mojares, and Epifanio San Juan Jr.   Written by Thelma E. Arambulo

article_title: Sa Mga Kababayang Dalaga ng Malolos
text:
(To My Young Countrywomen of Malolos). Written 1889. Published 1955. Author, Jose Rizal. Quezon City: R. Martinez and Sons. Included in Ang Liham ni Doctor Jose Rizal sa mga Dalagang Taga-Malolos at ang Kasaysayan sa Likod Nito (Doctor Jose Rizal’s Letter to the Maidens of Malolos and the History behind It) by Antonio B. Valeriano and Jose P. W. Tantoco. Malolos, Bulacan: Del Pilar Foundation Inc, 1982. English translation, “Rizal’s Message to the Young Women of Malolos” by Encarnacion Alzona, in Rizal’s Correspondence with Fellow Reformists. Manila: National Historical Commission, 1963.

This letter was written in London on 22 Feb 1889 upon a request by Marcelo H.del Pilar for Rizal to congratulate del Pilar’s female provincemates, who had succeeded in establishing a Spanish-language night school in Malolos despite the vehement objections of the friars. Barred by the friars from seeing Governor-General Weyler who was in the convent, the women refused to leave unless they were allowed to present their letter of request to Weyler. Weyler finally gave the women an audience and approved their school. With the newly acquired popularity of Rizal who by then had already published his Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, del Pilar hoped to give moral support to these courageous young women with this letter.

Rizal begins his letter by reflecting on Filipino women in general. They are known, he says, to possess a sweet disposition and modest ways, and in this light they oftentimes acquiesce in the abuses and caprices of the friars. But the news from Malolos has demolished whatever doubt he has entertained regarding the courage of Filipino women. Rizal notes that by struggling to free themselves from the servitude of ignorance and superstition, and by standing firm in such a struggle, they have made themselves worthy examples for all Filipinos. Rizal then goes on to attack the spiritual authority of the friars which has brutalized Filipino mothers. Such an influence, he says, has only resulted in sons who are cockfighters and acolytes, servants of the parish priests; and in husbands who, upon falling in love, would throw away learning, honor, and wealth as if a girl could only inspire misfortune. He then makes a comparison between the religious conduct of these parish priests and that of Jesus Christ, whom they are supposed to represent and emulate. He severely indicts, among other things, the gross and profiteering motives of the friars. Rizal alludes to the soldiers of Sparta whose courage was proverbial, noting that their strength was so because their mothers raised them to be warriors.

Rizal then calls upon Filipino women to train their sons to value honor, to be in possession of a clear mind, to act justly, and to respect God not with words but with their rational deeds. With regard to their husbands, Rizal says women should avoid servility and instead collaborate with them, encourage them, lift their spirits, and imbue in them the idea that it is better to die with honor than to live without it. Tyranny is possible only because of the cowardice and negligence of others. Finally, Rizal declares that, in fighting tyranny, Filipino women can exert tremendous influence toward the emancipation of the country.

Nicanor G. Tiongson’s The Women of Malolos, 2004, is an account of the times and lives of the 13 women who wrote the letter. Sari and Kiri Dalena directed a film musical titled Ang Kababaihan ng Malolos (The Women of Malolos), 2014, also written by Tiongson.   Written by Ruby G. Alcantara

article_title: Sa Tungki ng Ilong ng Kaaway: Talambuhay ni Tatang
text:
(On the Tip of the Enemy’s Nose: Diary of Tatang). Published 1988. Author, Cesar Lacara. With a foreword by “Ka Bino” and an introduction by Elias de la Cruz. Metro Manila: Kilusan sa Paglilinang ng Rebolusyonaryong Panitikan at Sining sa Kanayunan.

Labor leader and revolutionary figure Cesar “Tatang” Lacara’s two-part autobiography covers the formation of the first unions in the 1930s to the liberation movements during the Japanese occupation and the founding of the “new” Communist Party of the Philippines in 1968.

The first part, “Hindi Pa Tapos ang Kwento: Mula Bacnotan hanggang Tondo” (The Story Has Not Ended: From Bacnotan to Tondo), recounts Tatang’s difficult life from his youth as a working child to his ascent as a revolutionary leader.

Tatang’s story begins in La Union in northern Luzon. After his five-year-old sister Loreta dies from cholera, their mother takes the family to Central Luzon. Eleven-year-old Cesar takes on different jobs to help put food on the table. When his father’s dead body is brought home from the woods, Cesar gives up hope of finishing school.

He ends up working in Hacienda Carmencita and gets his dose of exploitative labor practices. Tatang has to work 16 hours daily to earn enough to feed his family. The farmworkers eventually organize a union in 1930 to demand higher wages and better working conditions. As one of the leaders, Tatang is offered a bribe by the landlord and his agriculturists, which he rejects. As tensions rise, the hacienda owners seek intervention from the Philippine Constabulary. The union leaders are arrested. Eventually released, they are nonetheless fired from the hacienda.

Witnessing the injustices spurs Tatang to join the Communists and continue to organize workers and peasants. His efforts are interrupted by World War II. After the war, he intensifies his organizing efforts while the state intensifies its own anticommunist campaign.

In one such operation in the early 1950s, Tatang is captured. Released in 1961, he resumes his organizing work, this time in urban Tondo. Frequent clashes with state authorities force Tatang to keep moving, first to Constitutional Hill (now Batasan Hills), then to the Manila-Rizal border, the Cordilleras, Ilocos Sur, and, finally, to eastern Central Luzon. The first part ends with asseverations of his commitment to the struggle for justice.

The second part, “Sari-Saring Sanaysay” (Various Essays), recounts key stages of his journey in the revolutionary movement. In “Ang Cabiao” (Cabiao), Tatang recalls the show of damayan (empathy) among the peasants working in the hacienda of the Buencaminos in Tarlac: when one is deprived of his harvest, all farmers go on strike. “Ang Huk” (The Huk) paints a triumphalist picture of the Hukbalahap, an army organized during World War II against the Japanese, while “Ang CLO” (The CLO) recounts the formation of the Congress of Labor Unions. Among the many prominent personalities featured in the section are Mariano Balgos, Guillermo Capadocia, Amado Hernandez, and Alfredo Saulo. “Ang Bagong Partido” (The New Party) presents the establishment of a new Communist party as a reaction to what he claims was a monopoly of power by the Lava-Taruc leadership in the old one.

The book’s significance lies as much in its appropriation of the memoir form as in the “truth” of its content. The memoir is used here to archive the historic struggles of the peasant movement and inspire more people to join the revolutionaries, instead of immortalizing the private life of a privileged few, as in many contemporary examples.  Written by Arbeen Acuña

article_title: Sagad sa Buto: Hospital Diary at Iba Pang Sanaysay
text:
(Cut to the Bone: Hospital Diary and Other Essays). Published 2010. Author, Romulo P. Baquiran Jr. Manila City: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

This book is a collection of 40 essays written in a hospital as the author was undergoing months of rehabilitation for a fractured foot. There are three general topics under which these pieces may be classified. The first group dwells on the medical details of his recovery. “Operasyon” (Operation) describes the experience of being under the knife. “Wheelchair at Sakong” (Wheelchair and Heel) recounts the author’s travails with the wheelchair. “Cement o AirCast” (Cement or AirCast) argues the merits of the AirCast, a reusable and easy-to-use device that protects a broken leg.

Another group of essays comments on the lamentable state of the country’s health-care system. In “Huwag Lahatin” (Don’t Generalize), Baquiran observes the system’s discrimination against lower-class people and the necessity of personal connections for patients to receive some care. In “Mga Pasyenteng Pasaway” (Delinquent Patients), the great number of impoverished patients unable to pay their bills dramatically exposes the social divide within the health system.

In the third category, Baquiran pays tribute to those who took care of him, and offers sketches of people in his ward who caught his interest. In “Room Mates at Bantay” (Room Mates and Caregivers), Baquiran contrasts the tough love that a stroke victim receives from his wife, and the loving care that a boy with dengue receives from his mother. In “Nelson, the Terminator,” he tells of the favors that he does for his nephew Nelson, a nurse, in exchange for Nelson’s help. “Kaila, the Apo Maker,” is about the tumultuous life of a niece who visited him at the hospital. These pieces are Baquiran’s expressions of gratitude and affection for the people who helped him on the path to recovery.

The last two essays in the book are longer narratives about certain aspects of Baquiran’s life: in “Mga Tahanan, Mga Pagtahan” (Homes and Refuges), he is a bachelor and apartment tenant; in “Minsan Ko Lang Niyakap ang Aking Ama” (Only Once Did I Hug My Father), he is a son estranged from his overbearing father, who had an extramarital affair.

Written in simple prose that effects both humor and poignancy, the essays highlight life’s simple joys without glossing over the social problems and contradictions that ordinary people encounter in their everyday lives.  Written by Christopher Mitch Cerda

article_title: Salimbibig: Philippine Vernacular Literature
text:
(Oral: Philippine Vernacular Literature). Published 1980. Editor, Joseph A. Galdon, SJ. With an introduction by Leonard Casper. Quezon City: The Council for Living Traditions.

Salimbibig is one of the earliest anthologies of critical essays on local language literature in both oral and written forms. By the 1970s, critics and students of Philippine literature understood the pressing need not only to collect different materials from the various local languages but also to construct provisional frameworks for analyzing them. Salimbibig was published to answer this need.

The essays in the first part deal with the numerous forms of oral literature of five language groups in Luzon and Mindanao. Rosario Lorrin’s “Ifugao Literature” is an introduction to the world of the Ifugao in Northern Luzon. Florentino Hornedo’s “lvatan Oral Literature” approaches the rich but hitherto unexplored lore of the inhabitants of Batanes historically and formalistically. Of particular interest is the inclusion of a number of riddles, tales, and songs to illustrate the major issues Hornedo discusses. Perla S. Nelmida’s “Pangasinan Oral Literature” is a guide to the more significant genres in Pangasinan oral tradition seasoned with examples of riddles, songs, and proverbs. The two essays by Nagasura Madale and Gerard Rixon study the literature of the Maranao and the Tausug, respectively.

The second part of the anthology is composed of five essays on the various aspects of the literate tradition. The approach is basically historical-sociological, in which the author shows the intimate relationship among the different processes: production, dissemination, and consumption. The five authors—Teresita Erestain, Teresita G. Maceda, Doreen G. Fernandez, Edna Z. Manlapaz, and Soledad S. Reyes—provide basic information on the different trends and movements which have determined the development of the various literatures in Luzon and in the Visayas—namely, Bikol, Cebuano, Ilonggo, Kapampangan, and Tagalog, respectively.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Sampaksaan ng Nobelistang Tagalog
text:
(A Gathering of Tagalog Novelists). Published 1969. Editor, Mona P. Highley. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Library.

This collection of essays was based on a series of lectures on the Tagalog novel held in 1969 in a forum that gathered together popular and influential novelists and editors of weekly magazines of different generations. The older generation was represented by Engracio Valmonte, while the generation that attracted the attention of Liwayway readers in the 1920s and 1930s was represented by Fausto Galauran and Jose Esperanza Cruz. Agustin C. Fabian represented the less tradition-bound novelists who became popular in the 1950s; and Efren Abueg, the younger generation of writers who began writing in the 1960s.

Especially significant are the essays on the various types of the novel: the novel of mysticism, the novel of mystery, the historical novel, and other types. They show the remarkable versatility of the novel as a popular genre. A centerpiece of the series is Fausto Galauran’s “Mga Paksa ng Nobelang Tagalog” (The Subjects of the Tagalog Novel), which offers interesting insights into the process of production that shaped the works of Galauran. article_title: Sarena's Story: The Loss of a Kingdom
text:
Published 2010. Author, Criselda Yabes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines (UP) Press, 2010. Gawad Likhaan: The UP Centennial Literary Prize for creative nonfiction, 2008.

The book is an account of the twilight years of the sultanate of Sulu, and the contentious coronation of its last sultan. Sarena, the eponymous narrator, is servant to Princess Piandao, who refuses to bow down to the datus in her bid to become sultana. Many decades later, Sarena gives her memoirs to her estranged daughter Taj in the hope that these will bring her back home.

This memoir-within-a-memoir is a series of fragments that nevertheless form a causal and linear narrative. The metafictional technique is evident in the frame narrative of a mother and daughter’s reconciliation, and in short asides in the memoir where Sarena addresses Taj to talk about a shared memory or an unsolved issue in their relationship.

In Sarena’s Story, the oft-marginalized in Philippine society are brought to the forefront. The politics, culture, and court life of the sultanate are vivified, from the rivalry of the Sama and the Tausug, to the delectable wanni mango and chili paste. All of this is done through the eyes of the court women, the princesses and their servants, the last being the group that is the most silenced in traditional historiography. Thus, the influence of women in the public sphere is revealed when—beyond the knowledge of datus, fathers, and husbands—servants gossip and collaborate, daughters strike deals with their fathers’ rivals, and princesses negotiate their—and their husbands’—claims to the throne.

In line with the artistic license of creative nonfiction, Yabes allows real-life historical personalities to speak and dialogue. At the same time, a journalistic sparseness dominates; short sentences and paragraphs populate the book, and the author’s objectivity is held intact from beginning to end. While this makes a few scenes in the memoir too emotionless, it simultaneously imbues others with a poignant and almost haunting quality.  Written by Dominic Sy

article_title: Sarilaysay: Tinig ng 20 Babae sa Sariling Danas Bilang Manunulat
text:
(Self-Narrative: Voice of 20 Women on Their Personal Experience as Writers). Published 2000. Author, Rosario Torres-Yu. With cover art by Maningning Miclat. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

The book is the result of a series of kuwentuhan or sharing/storytelling sessions between Yu and the 20 writers in 1998 for an exploratory study on the woman writer’s consciousness. The writers are Anacleta Villacorta-Agoncillo, Liwayway Arceo, Amelia Lapeña Bonifacio, Gloria Villaraza Guzman, Genoveva Edroza-Matute, Lualhati Bautista, Fanny Garcia, Sol Juvida, Marra PL. Lanot, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, Elynia Mabanglo, Rosalinda Pineda-Ofreneo, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, Aida Santos, Rebecca Añonuevo, Glecy Atienza, Mayette Bayuga, Joi Barrios, Benilda Santos, and Luna Sicat.

The book supplies invaluable data on the life and times of the Filipino women writers from three generations. Each interview covers the writer’s personal life, creative process, comments about her works, views on feminism and gender relations, among many other subjects. The details in themselves are interesting but are illuminating when considered alongside the writers’ works. We learn, for example, about why Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio shifted from English to Filipino, how Rosario Cruz-Lucero got the germ for her story “Demonyo” (Demon), and how Lualhati Bautista got started in writing (by drawing cartoons). For sheer variety of firsthand information, the book is a veritable treasure chest.

The book allows readers to hear the writers speak for themselves and in their own voices—a move that is of more than symbolic significance in the light of feminist theory. Because the book breaks away from the conventional question and answer format, what one reads is less a transcript of an interrogation than a confession heard (or overheard), including the elisions, equivocations, and exclamations that go along with it. In effect, the book gives us monologues—20 personalities verbalized: an indefatigable Liwayway Arceo, an effervescent Joi Barrios, and an earnest Lilia Quindoza-Santiago among them.

The effect can be jaunty, disjointed, and even cliquish—but it can also be immediate, vivid, and impressive. A sarilaysay, after all, is a narrative of self and a self-fashioning. What futher sets the book apart from other oral histories is that it professes to be informed by a feminist perspective. It is interesting, then, that some of what the writers say may, in fact, sound nonfeminist or even antifeminist. A few of them remark that they do not consciously write with a feminist agenda because to do so, they claim, would be putting the proverbial cart before the horse. The writers also speak from different and sometimes conflicting notions of what feminism is or what it does. Some subscribe to a kind of feminism that is grounded on a nationalist framework. Others understand feminism to be personal liberation or a breaking away from traditional expectations. A few see it as the recognition of woman’s genius even, or especially, by men. Still others avoid the label altogether.

The point seems to be that feminism, to be truly liberating, must be specific—to personal history, class position, artistic conventions, and national history. If only for issuing that challenge, the book deserves reading. Sarilaysay should find a space in bibliographies of future, more comprehensive (re)readings of Philippine literature.

A companion volume is Sarilaysay: Danas at Dalumat ng Lalaking Manunulat sa Filipino (Self-Narrative: Experience and Idea of Male Writers in Filipino), 2004.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Sikami'n Lumad: Bagong Panitikan ng Katutubong Mindanaw
text:
(We Are the Indigenous People: New Literature of Indigenous Mindanao). Published 2005. Editors, Mindanawon Initiatives for Cultural Dialogue. With an introduction by Albert E. Alejo, SJ. Davao City: Ateneo de Davao University Research and Publications Office.

This is an anthology of 32 poems and 26 prose works by 28 authors belonging to Mindanao’s indigenous groups: Manobo, Bagobo, Sama, Subanon, Arumanen, Agusanon, Mandaya, Tboli, Ilianon, Blaan, and Umayamnon. Notwithstanding Alejo’s claim in his introduction that all but one of the literary works in this anthology were written in the various indigenous languages of Mindanao, all but two of the works published here are actually in Cebuano, Filipino, and English, the region’s three politically dominant languages. The two exceptions are in Manobo, although Alejo states that the one exception is in English.

The two Manobo pieces are themselves exemplary proof of the continuation of the lumad (indigenous people) poetic tradition. “Tonggapow Kos Kod Ginawa Ku” (Accept My Love) is structured as a dialogue between a garden of flowers (kabulaklakan) and a visitor seeking the truth that the garden bears. Images and metaphors derive from Manobo practices and beliefs, such as honey gathering, fruit picking, the manner in which a guest is welcomed into one’s house, and the belief that nature is gracious if a visitor is of pure heart and intent. The other Manobo piece, “Kanduli tu Bai Ratu” (Ritual Prayer to Bai Ratu), is a plea to the supreme deity, Megbevaya, and to the lesser spirit, Bai Ratu, to protect the crops from harm. As such, it serves as a fitting end to the book.

There are poems affirming the lumad’s self-identity: the dignity of one’s humble stature in “Sayote” (Chayote); the identification with the sea and marine life in “Tribung Sama” (Sama Tribe); and a self-description as being brave, fierce, and noble in “Obo Manobo Ako” (I Am Obo Manobo). On the other hand, “Ako ug ang Akong Kalibotan” (I and the World) compares the lowly self to various weak and powerless objects; and “Naglagot nga Uk-ok” (The Angry Cockroach) concludes that it is greed for money and power that has caused tribal disunity.

In several poems, the violation of nature and her resources, particularly those of Mount Apo Sandawa, is the metaphor for the violation of the lumad. The educational system is held responsible for the erasure of indigenous names and for the lure of the city. The violation on the lumad poetic tradition itself is inadvertently shown by the inclusion of two colonial Tagalog forms in the anthology: a tanaga (four-line, seven-syllable poem) and a balagtasan (poetic joust). Without the Manobo original, the tanaga “Buhangin” (Sand) is de-contextualized and hence conveys a universal, rather than the lumad, experience. A balagtasan, “Hintawa tu Mapuslanon, Kauswagan o Kaguyanganan?” (Who Is More Useful, Progress or Nature?), ends ambivalently, in compliance with the genre’s conventions, thus shirking a resolution to Mindanao’s troubled history. In contrast, the poem “Unsaon Pagtuki?” (How to Analyze?) opens with the lumad belief that every person is born with twin souls, and then proceeds to enumerate a series of conundrums that are metaphors of lumad life.

The section “Alamat” (Legend) includes accounts of the origin of place names, land formations, disabled persons, and the strange behavior of animals. “Ang Kabog” (The Bat) condemns individualistic behavior, and “Sinugdanan sa Unggoy” (The Origin of the Monkey) condemns the mistreatment of animals. Trickster tales show the lowly and the lazy turning the tables on the privileged and powerful.

The section “Ritwal” (Ritual) consists of an enumeration of Manobo deities; a description of an Umayamnon wedding; an explication of the Sama pag-mbo,’ which is an Islamic practice with pre-Islamic origins; a ceremonial cockfight held by the Arumanon-Manobo to foretell their fortune in the coming year; a shaman’s healing rituals; farming rituals, which include dream interpretations (a snake means a bountiful harvest; a carabao or fire means a bad harvest); a Pulangion-Manobo wedding; and the most sacred of all rituals, the D’yandi (peace pact).

“Ilog Pulangi” (Pulangi River), in the section “Kasaysayan” (History), describes the eponymous river as traversing Mindanao from west to east. It enables two brothers, from whom the lumad and the Muslims are descended, to continue exchanging goods with one another though forced to live apart. “Pakigbisog sa mga Manigaon” (The Struggle of the Chieftains) is a powerful personalized account of the forced migrations of a clan, dating from Spanish colonization to present-day logging concessions; the consequent transfer of Manobo land to outsiders; and the dogged resistance waged by the clan patriarchs through the generations. It may well serve as a historical framework for the anthology.

Despite the unfortunate editorial interventions, the literary pieces here are a valuable contribution to contemporary Philippine literature. Indigenous literature is often erroneously assumed to date back to ancient, precolonial times. However, at the time of publication, the authors ranged in age from the early 20s to the 40s, with one in his late 60s. All of them seek to present their own perspectives on their person and place as lumad, instead of having outsiders, such as anthropologists and cultural workers, speak for them.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: La Soberania Monacal en Filipinas
text:
(The Monastic Supremacy in the Philippines). Published 1889. Author, Plaridel (pseud. of Marcelo H. del Pilar). Barcelona. Reprinted, Manila: Imprenta de Don Juan Atayde, 1898. Anthologized in Escritos, edited by Angelita Licuanan de Malones and Jaime J. Manzano. Manila: National Library, 1970. English translation, “Monastic Supremacy in the Philippines” by Encarnacion Alzona. Quezon City: Philippine Historical Commission, 1958.

A condemnation of monastic orders in the Philippines, the pamphlet asserts that monastic orders must be expelled if there is to be progress in the country. Del Pilar laments that Spain has left the Philippines, to the detriment of the Filipinos, in the hands of friars who have turned the islands into a “colonia de explotacion monacal” (colony for monastic exploitation). He then notes the domination of friars in three spheres: political, economic, and religious. The friars’ dominance over political life in the Philippines is manifested in their ability to manipulate elections. They are also in charge of public education. They can easily silence any opposition by deportation.

Economically, their supremacy comes from the many estates they let out. More money is derived from the stolen fees they collect, from contributions during fiestas and novenas, and from the sale of religious artifacts. Their privilege to obtain a part of the cedula tax also generates extra income for them. Lastly, their dominance in the religious sphere is shown in their ability to thwart even the bishop. When Bishop Salazar decided to check on the conditions of the church parishes, the friars, who ran the parishes and were members of religious orders and therefore themselves not under the jurisdiction of the bishop, threatened to abandon their parishes, a move that cowed the bishop. Del Pilar concludes that friars are a detriment to genuine Philippine progress and that there is much resentment against them.

The pamphlet was well received, earning praises from Miguel Morayta and Ferdinand Blumentritt. This work, as have del Pilar’s other attacks on the “friarcracy,” has made an impact; the image of the friar that del Pilar here presents recurs in the literature of subsequent generations.  Written by Rene Javellana

article_title: Sobre la Indolencia de los Filipinos
text:
(On the Indolence of the Filipinos). Published 1890. Author, Jose Rizal. Serialized in La Solidaridad, 15 Jul 1890–15 Sep 1890. Included in Escritos Politicos e Historicos (Political and Historical Writings). Manila: Comision Nacional del Centenario de Jose Rizal, 1961. English translations, “On the Indolence of the Filipinos” by Charles Derbyshire, in Jose Rizal, Life, Works and Writings. Manila: Villanueva Book Store, 1970; and by Guadalupe Fores-Ganzon, La Solidaridad, volume 2. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1973. Filipino translation, “Tungkol sa Katamaran ng mga Pilipino,” in Mga Akdang Pampulitika at Pangkasaysayan (Political and Historical Works). Manila: Pambansang Komisyon ng Ikasandaang Taon ni Jose Rizal, 1962.

This essay was written to refute that most common Spanish accusation that the indolence of the Filipinos is the cause of the wretched and backward situation in colonial Philippines. Rizal begins the essay with an admission that indolence does exist in the country. This is brought about by the hot climate, which makes strenuous physical work unhealthy; the abundance of natural resources, which assures survival without much labor; the piratical attacks, which despoil the people of the fruits of their labor; the depopulation of villages because of Spanish wars or galleon building; and the prohibition of trade with other countries caused by Spain’s fear of competition. Drawing from historians like Antonio de Morga and from contemporary examples, Rizal nonetheless says that compared to the Spaniards and the Chinese, the Filipinos are definitely less indolent.

The Spaniards, however, have brought with them certain conditions that perpetrate and perpetuate indolence. The Spanish administration discourages industry by offering no material incentive to the excellent worker; neither does it help struggling farmers in times of calamities nor look for markets for successful ones. Worse, the Christianity that friars teach stresses poverty as a prerequisite for entry into heaven. The Filipinos’ self-esteem and, ultimately, the desire to work are in no way cultivated. Instead, Filipinos are taught to look down on manual labor and seek the easy way out. The Spaniards have also introduced vices, such as gambling, and expensive celebrations, like the fiesta. Rizal points out defective house training as another factor. Filipino children are taught that they cannot be any better than what they are. They are thus discouraged from thinking. However, Filipinos too should be faulted for the lack of strong nationalist sentiments. Unable to see that they are members of one nation, they fall into unproductive struggles among themselves. This lack of solidarity and, ultimately, sense of accountability further leads to acquiescence in the evils of authorities.

article.value: (On the Indolence of the Filipinos). Published 1890. Author, Jose Rizal. Serialized in La Solidaridad, 15 Jul 1890–15 Sep 1890. Included in Escritos Politicos e Historicos (Political and Historical Writings). Manila: Comision Nacional del Centenario de Jose Rizal, 1961. English translations, “On the Indolence of the Filipinos” by Charles Derbyshire, in Jose Rizal, Life, Works and Writings. Manila: Villanueva Book Store, 1970; and by Guadalupe Fores-Ganzon, La Solidaridad, volume 2. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1973. Filipino translation, “Tungkol sa Katamaran ng mga Pilipino,” in Mga Akdang Pampulitika at Pangkasaysayan (Political and Historical Works). Manila: Pambansang Komisyon ng Ikasandaang Taon ni Jose Rizal, 1962.

This essay was written to refute that most common Spanish accusation that the indolence of the Filipinos is the cause of the wretched and backward situation in colonial Philippines. Rizal begins the essay with an admission that indolence does exist in the country. This is brought about by the hot climate, which makes strenuous physical work unhealthy; the abundance of natural resources, which assures survival without much labor; the piratical attacks, which despoil the people of the fruits of their labor; the depopulation of villages because of Spanish wars or galleon building; and the prohibition of trade with other countries caused by Spain’s fear of competition. Drawing from historians like Antonio de Morga and from contemporary examples, Rizal nonetheless says that compared to the Spaniards and the Chinese, the Filipinos are definitely less indolent.

The Spaniards, however, have brought with them certain conditions that perpetrate and perpetuate indolence. The Spanish administration discourages industry by offering no material incentive to the excellent worker; neither does it help struggling farmers in times of calamities nor look for markets for successful ones. Worse, the Christianity that friars teach stresses poverty as a prerequisite for entry into heaven. The Filipinos’ self-esteem and, ultimately, the desire to work are in no way cultivated. Instead, Filipinos are taught to look down on manual labor and seek the easy way out. The Spaniards have also introduced vices, such as gambling, and expensive celebrations, like the fiesta. Rizal points out defective house training as another factor. Filipino children are taught that they cannot be any better than what they are. They are thus discouraged from thinking. However, Filipinos too should be faulted for the lack of strong nationalist sentiments. Unable to see that they are members of one nation, they fall into unproductive struggles among themselves. article_title: Spy in My Own Country
text:
Published 1981. Author, Sylvia L. Mayuga. Manila: Louie Reyes, et al.

This is a collection of essays written between 1970 and 1981, when Mayuga was working as a freelance journalist, and the Philippines was under martial law. The author seeks to explain the young people of her generation and describes the times they live through. She writes about the discomfort of being young and being a cog in the wheel at the nation’s largest TV network; the compulsive desire to go abroad because of the feeling that no further growing up can take place at home; the search for enlightenment in politics, in grass, in yoga, or in living with one of the opposite sex with neither church rites nor parental blessing; the uneasy thought of college boys and girls converging at Plaza Miranda to shout “Rebolusyon!” (Revolution), of a cousin clubbed to death on one such occasion, or of a brother vanishing soon after. There is the description of the “electric shock” felt when martial law forces literary and visual artists to stop producing and drives them from the city to the countryside. But there are those, too, who stay and hold on to their jobs, and those who soon become recruits to the establishment. Finally, there are the author’s personal resolutions never to leave the country and never to abandon the works of Jose Rizal, Teodoro Agoncillo, and “all those who knew and recorded what the young of my generation wanted to escape from.”

Mayuga’s essays defy journalistic convention by consistently and vigorously using the personal “I” in discussing the concerns of her generation, ranging from the Filipinos’ search for a cultural identity other than that foisted on them by colonization, to their commitment to come to terms with the best and worst aspects of this identity-in-process. Mayuga, the hero, goes through the drama of self-unfolding with the nation’s and the generation’s drama. But Mayuga, the “spy who writes,” freely zooms in or away from herself, at once creating the personal voice of a first-person witness and the equally powerful voice of the active interpreter of history.  Written by Nora Jolipa and Marjorie Evasco
