article_title: Subversions of Desire: Prolegomena to Nick Joaquin
text:
Published 1988. Author, Epifanio San Juan Jr. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

 

Commenting on selected works by Nick Joaquin, Epifanio San Juan Jr shows the contradictions in the relationship between literature and the postcolonial situation in developing countries such as the Philippines.

 

In his preface, San Juan explains that critics have active roles in social transformation. They should “let the text speak the emancipatory message” and show the opposition of the text to orthodox readings “that have exploited Joaquin to maintain and legitimize class rule.” San Juan draws from the theories of Antonio Gramsci and Georg Lukacs, which have helped to forge a socialist cultural politics in the Third World, and the ideas of Friedrich Nietzsche, Martin Heidegger, Sigmund Freud, and the French psychoanalytic school.

 

In the first and seventh chapters, San Juan analyzes how the Virgin in “La Naval de Manila” (The Manila Navy), Caves and Shadows, 1983, and other works represent the utopian and the unconscious. He presents the contradiction in capitalism amid the uneven economic development of the Philippines and in the chronicling of Philippine history according to colonial victories.

 

In the second chapter, San Juan promotes the need to doubt orthodox interpretations of Joaquin’s works. He maintains that Joaquin’s short stories can be used for the radical transformation of Philippine society. “Three Generations,” for example, is usually read as the intermingling of Christian and indigenous values, of the sacred and the profane, of reason and desire. San Juan, however, sees the story as a crisis of patriarchal authority.

 

The next section reveals how Joaquin’s approach to egalitarianism and feudalism is seen in his legends, such as “The Legend of the Virgin’s Jewel” and “The Legend of the Dying Wanton.” San Juan uses Gilles Deleuze and Felix Guattari’s theories as well as Michel Foucault’s notion of power/knowledge to reveal how legends are used as rationalizations to justify inequities.

 

The fourth chapter reads the 19 poems in ProseandPoems, 1952, as responses to the irreconcilable forces during the Cold War era and discusses the relationship of class struggle in critical discourse to the text themselves. The fifth chapter shows the tensions of personal freedom in relation to authoritarian practices and institutions, as seen in “phallocratic” (i.e., male-dominated) relations in Joaquin’s plays Fathers and Sons and Tatarin. The sixth chapter explores the schizophrenia in TheWoman WhoHadTwoNavels, 1961, Joaquin’s first novel.

 

In the last chapter, San Juan brings back the influence of the author in critical discourse to avoid criticism that valorizes the text alone. Contextualizing the text in the light of the author’s life and the body politic, San Juan reveals shrouded truths. Written by Ralph Acuña and Ma. Teresa Pineda Tinio

article_title: Ang Suga nga Magandan-ag sa Nagapuyo sa Cangitngitan sa Sala o Ejercicio Sulod sa Siam ca Adlao
text:
(The Light That Will Shine on Those Who Live in the Darkness of Sin, or Exercises over Nine Days). Published 1879. Author, Blas Cavada de Castro. Reprinted, Manila: Imprenta de Esteban Balbas, 1882; Cebu: Imprenta del Seminario de San Carlos, 1896.

This 304-page book is a compendium of spiritual exercises, readings and meditations, dialogues, and ejemplos, which are short illustrative tales culled from European religious books. Typical of a large number of religious books in Cebuano and other Philippine languages in the 19th century, this is of note mainly for two reasons: its use of Cebuano, the quality of which is an improvement over earlier printed works in this language; and its underlying conception of the “book” as a kind of space into which various thematically related elements—that is, stories, dialogues, prayers—are thrown together. Vicente Sotto’s newspaper Ang Suga, 1901-12, took its title from the book.

Cavada also authored Varios Actos Piadosos para la Semana Santa (Various Pious Acts for Holy Week), 1899, a book of Lenten sermons and meditations in Cebuano. The Imprenta del Seminario de San Carlos issued editions of this book in 1902 and 1908. The Barili Press issued a revised edition in 1929.  Written by Resil Mojares

 

Sources

Mojares, Resil B. 1975. Cebuano Literature: A Survey and Bio- Bibliography. Cebu: San Carlos Publications.

———. 1983. Origins and Rise of the Filipino Novel: A Generic Study of the Novel until 1940. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

article_title: Tabi-Tabi sa Pagsasantabi: Kritikal na Tala ng Mga Lesbiana at Bakla sa Sining, Kultura, at Wika
text:
(Excuse the Slight: Critical Notes by Lesbians and Gays on Art, Culture, and Language). Published 2003. Editors, Eugene Y. Evasco, Roselle V. Pineda, and Rommel B. Rodriguez. With a foreword by M. L. Tan and an introduction by the editors. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This anthology of 17 essays presents the different aspects of Philippine arts and culture from the points of view of gays and lesbians. The book is divided into four sections. The first three provide essays on the representations of homosexuals in Philippine society, and the last section consists of two personal testimonials.

The first section, “Sipat at Siyasat sa Kasaysayan” (Sight and Examinations on History), consists of preliminary analyses on the development of gay and lesbian visual and literary arts in the Philippines; the history and formation of Lesbianarama, which is the first ever group of lesbian artists in the Philippines and in Asia; and discussions of the artistry of three contemporary lesbian visual artists.

In “Teorya at Estetika” (Theory and Aesthetics), the editors explain the need for a theoretical framework that is rooted in the experiences of homosexuals and is particular to the body, space, and literary texts. Minerva Lopez’s “Si Nena, Neneng, at Erlinda: Ang Sex Variant sa Panitikang Pilipino” (Nena, Neneng, and Erlinda: The Sex Variants in Philippine Literature) traces protolesbian consciousness in early Filipino novels even before the emergence of the modern concept of lesbianism. Edson Cabalfin’s “Mala-baklang Espasyo sa Arkitekturang Filipino: Estetika, Morpolohiya, Konteksto” (Queer-Like Space in Philippine Architecture: Aesthetics, Morphology, Context) demonstrates a way of reading queer characteristics into quotidian spaces in the city. The basketball court, overpass, and plaza are considered queer because they embody multifunctional, paradoxical, and “heterotopial” qualities. Roselle Pineda’s “Mula sa Silid, tungo sa Indayog: Paghugot ng Estetikang Lesbiana mula sa Katawan” (From the Room to the Rhythm: Extracting Lesbian Aesthetics from the Body) shows women moving from their traditional space at home to the liberating medium of dance as a body art of eroticism and lesbianism.

The next section, “Pagbasa at Kritika” (Reading and Criticism), critiques the notion of sexuality in Philippine folktales, popular magazines, and mass media. Rolando Tolentino’s “Richard Gomez at ang Mito ng Pagkalalaki” (Richard Gomez and the Myth of Masculinity) deconstructs various cultural texts that perpetuate the ruling establishment and ideologies and trivialize homosexuality and queerness. In “Ang Umuusbong na Panulaan, ang Kilusang Mapagpalaya, at ang Pagpapaunlad ng Wikang Pambansa” (The Emerging Poetry, the Liberation Movement, and the Development of National Language), Eugene Evasco describes how the special use of words in gay poetry contributes to the national language.

The last section, “Testimonyo” (Testimonies), records the stories and reflections of two homosexuals. Irma Lacorte narrates her experiences on her way to becoming a successful “lesbian visual artist.” Oscar Atadero tells of the urgent need for social change and equality in regard to gender, class, and race.

Tabi-tabi sa Pagsasantabi aims for an enlightened, gender-centered criticism that resists discrimination and stereotyping. This anthology brings into the fold areas previously ignored in queer studies, like architecture and performance art.  Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos

article_title: Tagalog Poetry, 1570-1898: Tradition and Influences in Its Development
text:
Published 1986. Author, Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press. Reprinted, 2001. Partially published in Philippine Studies in 1968 and Asia-Philippines Leader in 1971.

Prior to Lumbera’s work, there existed a number of studies on the development of Tagalog poetry, but for sheer scope and magnitude, Tagalog Poetry is undoubtedly a pioneering critical text.

The study examines the different influences that have shaped the development of Tagalog poetry by reconstructing the early history of the genre, from the 17th until the 19th century. The approach chosen—a diachronic perspective—necessitates a definite historical sense, which is what determines the structure of the study. Chapter 1 focuses on the early forms of Tagalog poetry—the riddle, the proverb, and the short poems—and the manner in which these forms could have constituted the folk tradition. Chapter 2 discusses the evolution from oral to written poetry and covers works of the missionary poets, the ladino (bilingual poets), and the Tagalog poets. Chapter 3 shows the assimilation and synthesis of the two dominant traditions—the folk and the missionary influences, as exemplified in the works of Gaspar Aquino de Belen and Felipe de Jesus, among others.

Lumbera contends that the crystallization of tradition took place in the works of Francisco Baltazar, aka Balagtas—specifically, his Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), ca 1838-61. The text is both a positive response to earlier aspects of the folk tradition and an appropriation of some elements of the tradition introduced by the Spanish missionaries. More importantly, Balagtas and his texts would become the source of a number of major influences in the future. Among these are the accordance of prestige on poetry as a medium of serious ideas; the canonization of the courtly love tradition; the emphasis on the emotions; the use of rhetorical devices that run counter to the more spontaneous use of familiar images in folk poetry; and the prevalence of the aphoristic style, which identifies the poet with the sage.

The final chapter deals with the poetry produced during the revolutionary years and the uses these forms were put to. Lumbera argues that although they are not great poetry, the poems of the propagandists and Andres Bonifacio helped create a nation. The appendix contains the English translations of selected poems produced within the last three centuries and thus makes accessible some of the most illustrative poems from the Spanish period.

Lumbera’s study spawned much controversy and led to a vigorous debate regarding the meaning of tradition and the correctness of Lumbera’s formalistic interpretation of Florante at Laura, which in its history had always been approached from the moral and allegorical perspective. Significant critical reactions were made by Epifanio SanJuan Jr and Lucila Hosillos on Lumbera’s interpretation of Florante at Laura, and by E. Arsenio Manuel on Lumbera’s discussion of folkpoetry.

Tagalog Poetry is significant for being the first sustained examination of the different elements that constituted a tradition crystallized in Balagtas and which eventually influenced a host of later writers. Moreover, it reevaluates traditional views on Tagalog poetry. Thus, Lumbera succeeds in problematizing basic issues concerned with Tagalog poetry, literary criticism, and literary history in the 1960s.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Talinghaga ng Gana
text:
(Metaphor of Desire). Published 2003. Author, Rebecca T. Añonuevo. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

The concept of the sacred in 20th-century Filipino poetry is discussed in this book. The first chapter presents a substantial review of literature by Western and Filipino authors who wrote about the sacred in poetry. Añonuevo uses the word gana, normally meaning one’s appetite for food, to refer to the human desire for an active and purposely meaningful life. The book studies the expression of gana in 23 poems by 16 Filipino authors.

In the second chapter, titled “Panata sa Panulat” (Pledge of Allegiance to Writing), Añonuevo presents her personal history and development as an author to further explain the metaphor of desire. The third chapter, titled “Pag Tinablan ang Katawan” (When the Body Gets Affected), discusses selected lyric poems by Ildefonso Santos, Benilda Santos, Ruth Elynia Mabanglo, Rolando S. Tinio, and Albert E. Alejo in terms of the seemingly irreconcilable categories of desire and pain, life and death, as well as separation and intimacy. In all the poems, the body and the soul together experience suffering and redemption.

The fourth chapter, “Panambitan sa Labas” (Lamenting Outside), consists of the poet’s meditations on the involvement of the sacred in human actions. It recounts how the literary group Galian sa Arte at Tula made the poor and the dispossessed the subject of poetry, thereby acting as the social conscience during the oppressive Marcos regime. Añonuevo proposes that God also expresses an interest in the lives of the common people. She intersects this theme with the writings of poets Virgilio Almario, Cirilo F. Bautista, Lamberto E. Antonio, Jose F. Lacaba, Benigno Ramos, and Amado V. Hernandez. In most of the pieces, the writers ask God to address the injustices and cruelty happening all the time in the world. The chapter ends with the author’s poem about Filipino children, who symbolize boundless hope amid the deepest of human sorrows.

The fifth chapter, “Saklot ng Sansaglit” (Gripped by the Moment), is about the peace, awe, disobedience, and surrender poets feel in the presence of the sacred and their poetic description of the experience. The authors in this chapter include Mike L. Bigornia, Manuel Principe Bautista, Virgilio Almario, Benilda Santos, Teo S. Baylen, Alejandro G. Abadilla, Albert E. Alejo, and Rebecca T. Añonuevo. The author believes that when the grace of God is welcomed, as what occurs in some poems, death loses its horror and becomes ordinary like dinner at home or thoughts about friends. Other poems hold dialogue with God as with an equal (Abadilla) or an earthly authority (Alejo). Añonuevo explicates the theme of “pagpapaubaya” (letting go) and the praise of God in the poems.

Chapter 6, “Sagana, Siya Nawa” (Abundance, Amen), recapitulates the ideas discussed in the previous chapters: that gana and the soul are one, and that the selected Tagalog poems show the interaction between God and the human, expressing the concept of the sacred through the metaphor of desire.

Talinghaga ng Gana is a pioneering work that combines personal experience, literary criticism, and philosophy in the interpretation of Tagalog poetry from the 20th century.  Written by Romulo Baquiran Jr

article.value: (Metaphor of Desire). Published 2003. Author, Rebecca T. Añonuevo. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

The concept of the sacred in 20th-century Filipino poetry is discussed in this book. The first chapter presents a substantial review of literature by Western and Filipino authors who wrote about the sacred in poetry. Añonuevo uses the word gana, normally meaning one’s appetite for food, to refer to the human desire for an active and purposely meaningful life. The book studies the expression of gana in 23 poems by 16 Filipino authors.

In the second chapter, titled “Panata sa Panulat” (Pledge of Allegiance to Writing), Añonuevo presents her personal history and development as an author to further explain the metaphor of desire. The third chapter, titled “Pag Tinablan ang Katawan” (When the Body Gets Affected), discusses selected lyric poems by Ildefonso Santos, Benilda Santos, Ruth Elynia Mabanglo, Rolando S. article_title: Ang Tatlong Panahon ng Tulang Tagalog
text:
(The Three Periods of Tagalog Poetry). Published 1938. Author, Julian Cruz Balmaseda. Manila: Institute of National Language.

Originally a lecture delivered on 28 Jul 1938, this has been acclaimed not only as a pioneering study of the history of Tagalog poetry but also as a source of analytical insights into the formal and generic qualities of poetry. It served as the basis for all subsequent studies of all genres in Tagalog literature.

Balmaseda divides the history of Tagalog poetry into three stages. The first is what he considers the period of the dalit, beginning at the dawn of the Spanish colonial regime and ending in the period of Francisco Baltazar, aka Balagtas. Balmaseda discusses the significance of the anonymous Tagalog writers of proverbs and riddles, the contributions of the Spanish friar-poets, and the role of the ladino poets, who wrote in both Tagalog and Spanish. Balmaseda believes that poetry during this period was generally octosyllabic.

The second period is the period of change when writers started to use other forms in writing their poems. This period begins with Jose de la Cruz and Francisco Balagtas and ends with the revolutionary writers. The discussion of the various forms of lyric, narrative, and dramatic poetry is made engaging mainly by Balmaseda’s constant use of examples from actual texts.

Balmaseda also distinguishes between the genero epico that shaped the epic and the pasyon, and the genero dramatico that determined the metrical romances (the awit and korido). For Balmaseda, the period of Balagtas witnessed the resurgence of interest in poetry and the realization of the power of poetry to construct various aspects of the world. The last period is the contemporary period which Balmaseda calls the “time of further growth and development” when Tagalog poetry could compete with the best foreign works for sophistication. He notes the numerous volumes of poetry published at that time and the literary contests sponsored by different organizations, which, for him, were indications that Tagalog poetry had come into its own.

The book is notable for its attempt to theorize on poetry. Balmaseda follows Lope K. Santos when he speaks of the four qualities of poetry: rhyme, meter, metaphor, and beauty. He argues that the way to enrich poetry is not to introduce innovations but to cultivate and enhance what has been handed down by earlier generations of writers. This view seems to have been determined by the desire to repel what was perceived to be disastrous Western literary influences.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Tsapsuy: Mga Sanaysay, Tula, Salin, at Iba Pa
text:
(Chopsuey: Essays, Poems, Translations, and Others). Published 1997. Editor, Joaquin Sy. Manila: Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran Inc.

An anthology of poems and essays written in Tagalog or in Tagalog translation from Chinese, the book was published in celebration of the 10th anniversary of Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran, a Chinese Filipino organization. Most of the works had been previously published in Tulay.

The essays in this anthology portray the Chinese Filipino experience as a constant struggle for acceptance by a society whose “narrow nationalism” subjects other ethnicities to being perennial outsiders.

Joaquin Sy’s essays “Nationalismo, Uso Pa Ba?” (Nationalism, Is It Still Trendy?), “Sanlibo’t Isang Dahilan” (A Thousand and One Reasons), “Sintomas ng Panahong Darating?” (Signs of Things to Come?), and “Tigre Na Tayo?” (Are We Now Tigers?) examine the Chinese Filipinos’ thwarted attempts at integration with the rest of Philippine society and the various experiences of discrimination that they routinely face. In “Ayyy … Nasyonalismo” (Ayyy … Nationalism), Sy emphasizes the need for Chinese Filipinos to assert their cultural identity as a way of securing their place in Philippine society.

Go Bon Juan’s essays “Sapagkat Siya’y Mahal Pa Rin Natin” (Because We Still Love Her), “Sapagkat Ito’y Karapatan Natin” (Because It’s Our Right), and “Mahigpit na Pagkakaugnay” (A Tight Connection) also view the Chinese Filipino’s dual cultural heritage in a positive light, claiming that a Chinese born and raised in the Philippines can be as nationalistic as a “pure” Filipino. The author also sheds light on the pervasive stereotypes about Chinese Filipinos while highlighting the historically close ties between the two groups, including their shared experience of oppression under Spanish rule.

The poems likewise foreground questions of nationalism and ethnicity. James Na’s “Niyebe” (Snow) and “Kalesa” (Horse-Drawn Carriage) are reflections on the search for one’s roots. Lyonel Ty’s “Pader” (Wall) uses the eponymous image to symbolize an impregnable social divide, which can be interpreted as that between the Chinese Filipino and the rest of Philippine society. Sze Man Chi’s “Panunuluyan” (Accommodations) centers on the rootless generation in constant search for acceptance created by migration. Ivan Tsang’s “Istasyon sa Munting Bayan” (A Station in a Small Town) describes the Chinese Filipino’s lingering sense of alienation after the initial struggle with linguistic and cultural differences.

Juan concludes the poetry section with “Patulang Kasaysayan ng mga Tsinoy” (A Poetic History of the Filipino-Chinese), an allegory that compares Chinese and Filipinos to fish and water. He concludes by asserting that the Chinese Filipino’s full integration into Philippine society can only be achieved through mutual study and understanding of the centuries-long cultural exchange between the two groups, which has birthed an altogether new set of cultures, beliefs, and traditions.

While the bulk of book focuses on the Filipino Chinese experience, some of the poems depart from themes of ethnicity to touch on other matters like love (Isuan Lee’s “Pag-ibig sa Tagsibol” [Love in Springtime]) or disillusionment (Lyonel Ty’s “Ang Bulag” [The Blind]).

According to Sy, the anthology is titled Tsapsuy, in reference to a dish of mixed vegetables, because the contents are as varied as the ingredients that go into the making of the dish and because it is symbolic of the Filipino Chinese. They continue to be nurtured by Chinese culture even as they are transformed by and contribute to Filipino culture.  Written by Jeffrey Yap

article_title: The Vicente Rama Reader: An Introduction to Modern Readers
text:
Published 2003. Editor and translator, Fr Rudy Villanueva. With a preface by the editor and introduction by Resil Mojares. Manila: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This book consists of Vicente Rama’s memoir and selected short works of literature and journalism, translated by Villanueva, with the original Cebuano pieces presented as the book’s second section. In the book’s introduction, Mojares states that Cebuanos remember Rama primarily for being the author of the charter that established Cebu as a city but that Rama’s pioneering role in promoting Cebuano literature and journalism is equally important. The book aims to introduce Rama as a writer and patron of Cebuano writing.

The first chapter, “Portrait of a Father,” gives us Rama’s biography, based on the recollections of former mayor of Cebu and Rama’s close friend, Eulogio Borres. The second chapter, “Memories of a Life” / “Mga Handumanan sa Akong Kinabuhi,” is Rama’s memoir. It narrates Cebu’s role in the Philippine Revolution against Spain, his publishing and political career, and his life during World War II. One subchapter recounts Rama’s major contribution to Cebuano letters: the creation of Bag-ong Kusog, a Cebuano-language periodical that published journalism and literary works in 1915-41.

The book’s last chapter “Selected Short Works” / “Mga Pinili nga Sinulat” features Rama’s selected journalistic pieces, essays, a short story, and two novel chapters. “The Man-Eaters of Mindanao” / “Adunay Kahoy sa Mindanaw nga Mokaon ug Tawo?” shows the satirical approach Rama favored in most of his writing. The piece narrates an account of flesh-eating trees of Mindanao, one of many misconceptions that dissuaded workers from settling on the island. Rama refutes the hearsay using scientific facts and irony.

“Advance Payment” / “Ang Bugay” is a short story about Koring and Kolas, former lovers trying to patch things up even though Koring has already agreed to marry another man. A simple tale about a doomed love affair, the story is told in a shifting third-person point of view, with a narrator openly addressing the reader. “Love, Then and Now” / “Gugma Kanhi ug Karon” is an essay in which Rama compares romantic relationships in his period and those in the past. Another nostalgia piece is “The Hard Lot of Manding Kuwaresma” / “Ang mga Mahay ni Manding Kuwaresma,” a piece about how the observance of Lent has lost its solemnity over the years.

“Artemio Aranas” is an example of Rama’s inventive reportage. Written like narrative fiction, with some parts told in scenes, the piece combines humor and sociology in describing the quarrel between a local paper and the Health Bureau over the cause of a cholera outbreak in an unnamed town in Cebu. In the piece’s climactic scene, a boy named Artemio Aranas delivers a speech that exposes the incompetence of so-called journalists who have misinformed the residents about the threat of disease.

The first two chapters of Rama’s novel Ang Silot ni Bathala (Retribution), 1948, introduce Petra, a married woman having an affair with a married man. “Karnabal” (Carnival) opens with a rowdy street fair attended by locals and foreigners. “Mga Takuban ug Anino” (Masks and Shadows) shows Petra among those participating in the carnival. Petra takes the occasion to shed her inhibitions, an attempt to escape the confines of a society that will ultimately punish her.

In “The Sto. Niño of Cebu” / “Ang Santo Ninyo sa Sugbu,” Rama provides an account of the origin of Cebu’s patron. After the Spaniards, led by Gen Miguel Lopez de Legaspi, have driven King Tupas and his villagers into the mountains, they burn a local settlement by the sea. Later, a Spanish soldier named Juan de Camus finds an image of the Sto. Niño among the ruins. Legaspi holds a parade to commemorate the discovery of the effigy, an event known today as the Sinulog Festival.

In this volume of his memoir and selected works, Vicente Rama emerges as a versatile and prolific writer. He combined techniques from journalism and literature to develop a style with both topical currency and flair, thereby enriching Cebuano as a tool for both communication and artistic expression. His combined use of straightforward narration, sociological knowledge, and verbal irony has helped create the template for modern Cebuano writing.  Written by John Bengan

article_title: A Voice from the Hills: Essays on the Culture and World View of the Western Bukidnon Manobo People
text:
Published 1989. Author, Francisco Col-om Polenda. Translated and edited by Richard E. Elkins. Manila: Linguistic Society of the Philippines. Reprinted, special monograph issue, Philippine Journal of Linguistics, no. 29 (2002). Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for essay, 1990.

The book is a collection of essays about the sociocultural system of the Manobo people of Western Bukidnon. Written in village chief Polenda’s native Binukid Manobo language, the essays describe and explain various aspects of Manobo life, such as the Manobo people’s material culture, their perception of their physical and social environments, and their cosmology.

The book is divided into seven sections: “Life Cycle,” “Social Values,” “The Home,” “Livelihood,” “Politics and Peacekeeping,” “Getting Along with Gods and Spirits,” and “Leisure and Beauty.”

The book is replete with notes on propriety concerning different aspects of a person’s life: the second wife has the right to use all of the family possessions whether or not the co-wife or husband permits it; people living in a newly built house should invite others to gather for a house warming, lest something evil occur in that house; men, women, and children may be tattooed for ornamentation. The essay “Social Rules We Follow” presents the Manobo people’s value system, which Polenda explains consists of sets of rules created “to make people aware of what is good and bad.”

The essays are also brimming with metaphors and images explaining abstract ideas. Life on earth is likened to a stopover. Humans die because their breath is actually just wind lent by the supreme being Nengazen. A bottomless lake filled with snakes, crocodiles, and maggots is a crossing for all souls trying to reach the “Golden Home,” or the paradise in the afterlife.

Included are two appendices, which provide a sample linguistic analysis of a Western Bukidnon Manobo text and the complete essays in the original Binukid language. Aside from the content footnotes, which provide historical, cultural, and linguistic information, there is also an introduction that lays down the basic social and cultural premises needed by readers for them to understand and appreciate the book’s material. Religious beliefs, for instance, are discussed, beginning with the various classes of supernatural beings: from the supreme being referred to as Megbevaya (God), Nengazen (Owner), and Nenlimbag (Creator), to lesser deities like Elimegkat and Bulelakew (gods of rivers and streams), to the malevolent spirits called busew and a person’s own gimukud (soul).

The book offers a view of the rich cultural wellspring of the Western Bukidnon Manobo people. Intense acculturation has brought about a different way of life. Thus, the book becomes more valuable for its depiction of a unique worldview that may soon disappear, for sounding a voice which to other Filipino ears might be singing a surprisingly familiar song.  Written by Om Narayan Velasco

article_title: Voices = Mga Tinig: The Best of Tulay
text:
Published 1997. Editors, Teresita Ang See, Caroline S. Hau, and Joaquin Sy. Manila: Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran Inc.

The short stories, poems, and essays in this anthology were originally published in Tulay, the newsletter of Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran, a Chinese Filipino organization. Questions about the nation and identity are raised by the Chinese Filipino writers, who write not from an outsider’s point of view but from that of someone immersed in the Philippine way of life.

R. Kwan Laurel’s “Amah” is about a grandfather and Amah, his partner in a successful dumpling business. When Amah falls terminally ill, the grandfather seeks out all possible cures for her except Western medicine, despite his family’s suggestions. The story underscores the conflict between tradition and modernity, which is paralleled by generational conflict.

The theme of connection to one’s roots is evident in Caroline Hau’s “Stories,” which presents a father’s stories of his life before and after migrating to the Philippines from the T’ang Mountains in China. The father’s marriage, memories of his children, making and stealing salt during hard times in China are told in a nostalgic tone. Hau’s “The True Story of Ah To” tells of the narrator’s communist father who leaves China to escape the war. Despite his integration into Philippine culture, he is disinterested in the social and political events in his adopted country because of his sense of alienation.

Harriet Ann Dy’s essay, “Living Precariously in Dangerous Times,” describes the toll that the abduction of Chinese Filipinos takes on their community, particularly those living in Binondo. The myth of the wealthy Chinese being the cause of these abductions, Dy contradicts this myth by presenting the Chinese Filipino as a member of the working class struggling to make ends meet. On the other hand, in another essay, “Face to Face with Rural Living,” Dy celebrates the undaunted spirit of the Filipino people and her shared heritage with them as she witnesses village people in La Union rebuilding their lives in the wake of a tragedy.

Doreen Yu’s “Singkit Nga Naman” (Oh, the Slant Eyed) and Audrey Lim Tan’s “Ang Tsinoy Ay Pinoy Rin!” (The Chinese Filipino Is Filipino Too!) tell of the disadvantages of one's having slanted eyes in the Philippines. Chinese Filipinos must endure the fear of being kidnapped for ransom and being taunted for being “singkit.” Yu and Tan argue that Chinese Filipinos, being a minority group, naturally want to belong, but they must constantly prove themselves more Filipino than the average Filipino.

Joaquin Sy’s poem, “Dalawang Maikling Kuwento tungkol sa Kung Bakit Magulo sa Bayan ni Pedro” (Two Short Stories about Why Pedro’s Country Is in Chaos), observes the Filipinos’ lack of discipline and driving etiquette of Filipinos.

Te, and Aileen June Wang. The other poets are Sze Man Chi, Lyn Ching, Ramoncito Lim Ching, Eddie Choa, Bartolome Chua, Karen Huang, Go Bon Juan, Ong Lian Kiao, Bliss Cua Lim, James Na, Juvy T. Ong, Ivan Tsang, Lyonel Ty, and Ma. Lucila T. Uy.

Taken together, the selections in the anthology are optimistic about Chinese Filipino and Filipino relations without denying areas of tension.   Written by Jeffrey Yap

article_title: Waiting for Mariang Makiling: Essays in Philippine Cultural History
text:
Published 2002. Author, Resil Mojares. With a preface by the author. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This book is a collection of 12 critical essays covering aspects of Philippine cultural history. The title essay discusses the importance of using folklore as an indicator of a people’s way of seeing the world. As a demonstration, Mojares uses the folk legend “Mariang Makiling.” He finds embedded in it precolonial, colonial, and postcolonial imaginings. He also shows how the Mariang Makiling legend has been appropriated for both conservative and liberative purposes as historical moments allow or induce.

Several essays dwell on history writing itself. “The Islands according to Pigafetta” investigates the Philippine section of the book First Voyage around the World, one of the earliest accounts about the Philippines. Mojares sees Pigafetta as writing in the mode of the European chivalric romance, thereby domesticating the new world in the image of the old. “The Brief and Blessed Life of Miguel Ayatumo” analyzes the biography of a 16-year-old Christian convert appended to a conduct book. Through the strategies of reduction and figuration, the life of the native is made to fit and offered as an image of the model Christian. “Time, Memory, and the Birth of the Nation” surveys the representations of the 1896 Philippine Revolution in biographies and memoirs written by Apolinario Mabini, Emilio Aguinaldo, Teodoro M. Kalaw, and Rafael Palma among others. Mojares shows how memories of the revolution eventually figure in and produce official histories of the nation. “The Epiphany of Pedro Calungsod” narrates how the local church in a bid for his canonization represented the life of Calungsod. In recounting the process of canonization of another Filipino, Lorenzo Ruiz, during the presidency of Ferdinand Marcos, Mojares shows the confluence of motives of the pope and the state.

In these essays, Mojares demonstrates that histories produce as much as discover the objects that they inquire into. They are products of historical moments and political contingencies. As such, historical representations are subject to distortions, deletions, and contestation, and to the tropes of the modes in which they are written. The mode of sacred history, for example, in which the lives of Miguel Ayatumo and Calungsod are framed, give up specificities in favor of Christian types.

The problem of colonial subjects representing themselves is taken up in “Rizal Reading Pigafetta.” Jose Rizal illustrates the predicament of the colonial subject writing against European texts by using—and sometimes misusing—European texts, whether historical, scientific, or anthropological. For example, through the methods of comparative linguistics which he had learned from German thinkers, Rizal made a case for the Philippines’ being an ancient and advanced civilization before the coming of Spain. The “defects” of the natives, such as indolence, were the product of Spanish colonialism. Rizal thus uses discourses of racial superiority which Spain had used to justify its colonization of the islands.

The other essays in the collection are “Stalking the Virgin,” which shows the hybridity in the cult of the Virgin of Guadalupe in Cebu; “Catechisms of the Body,” which sketches the colonial Church’s attempts to regulate native bodies along Christian lines through conduct books; “Deciphering a Meal,” which teases out the politics embedded in two banquets in Cebu during the Spanish and American colonial periods; “Reading Vicente Ranudo,” which gleans Cebuano concepts of poetry from an examination of Ranudo’s poem “Pag-usara” (Solitude); “Talking Politics,” which reveals the importance and limits of radio komentaryo (commentary), a genre of Cebuano political discourse that rose to prominence after the lifting of martial law in 1981; and “The Haunting of the Filipino Writer,” which suggests that it is the psychic lack, or the sense of having lost the soul, caused by colonialism that drives Filipino writers to write.

Waiting for Mariang Makiling fleshes out cultural and historical signs, symbols, and texts that seem innocent but which need to be reevaluated and deconstructed. It is a significant book that reminds its readers, to quote from Mojares’s preface, that “we are a culture blessed with moves to avoid the claims of those who say they have seen the Truth.”  Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos

article_title: Woman Enough and Other Essays
text:
Published 1963. Author, Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil. Quezon City: Vibal Publishing House. Reprinted, 1964; Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1999.

This collection contains essays originally written as opinion-column pieces during the period 1943-63. The essays are virtually sociological notes on the Filipino psyche, evidently formed by long observation and written from a well-wrought point of view. Nakpil’s are not off-the-cuff remarks; neither will her ideas ever be mistaken for tentative opinions.

The book is divided into five sections: “Woman,” “Politics and Manners,” “Perspective,” “Humor,” and “Reminiscence.” The first group of essays sets out to define the notions of femininity and womanhood in an unabashed tone. “The Filipino Woman” is almost a full sociological delineation, which is fleshed out further in “Myth and Reality,” a juxtaposition of the myth and reality about Filipino men. For present-day readers, “Maria Clara” remains an important and pioneering essay in feminism. The section “Politics and the Social Scene” is a proposal for political activism for women within the framework of electoral politics. Nakpil’s cynicism occasionally comes through in, for instance, “Charity,” when she comments on society ladies putting their slum dwellers’ “poverty on display at one of [their] tea parties as if it were a cunning centerpiece” that they had themselves created; or in “The Neediest Cases,” when she looks into the eyes of Dalmacio, “18, jobless, sleek haired and sullen, leering at what—the social order?”

Whether she is writing of a historical Lapulapu and Magellan, or a masterful sketch of London, or an affecting portrait of her childhood teacher she calls Maestra Nena, Nakpil brings to her writing a discriminating eye and a disdain for facile logic.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

article_title: Women Reading: Feminist Perspectives on Philippine Literary Texts
text:
Published 1992. Editor, Thelma B. Kintanar. Quezon City: University of the Philippines (UP) Press and the UP Center for Women’s Studies.

One of the first collections of feminist criticism, this anthology brings to bear a variety of feminist critical perspectives on different Philippine literary texts. The anthology is divided into four sections. The two essays in section 1 give a literary history of women and women writing. Marjorie Evasco’s “The Writer and Her Roots” stresses the need for Filipina writers “to connect” not just to tradition but also to a deeper “racial memory, a mythic consciousness” back to the babaylan (ancient priestesses and tribal poets), in order to recover a sundered wholeness. Rosalinda Pineda-Ofreneo’s “Trading a Hidden Tapestry: Women and Literature in the Philippines” traces historical patterns, problems, and trends in women’s literature and discusses representative models. Notable for its attempt to localize each writer within a definite historical context, the essay describes the effects of “friarcracy,” the introduction of the English language and American culture, Japanese censorship, the national liberation movements, and feminism on the representations of women and women writing.

Compiled in sections 2 and 3 under the general heading “Deconstructing Patriarchy” are readings of various texts from a feminist perspective. The feminist perspective, according to Kintanar’s introduction, is premised on the distinction between biological sex and “culturally constructed gender,” the latter being an identity shaped by sex roles and expectations into which women have been socialized.

Priscelina Patajo-Legasto’s “The Pasyon Pilapil: An ‘Other’ Reading” details the “reconstruction” of maternity in the Pasyon Pilapil. The text denies woman’s source of power, her ability to reproduce. In Eve, biological reproduction is seen as a curse; representations of Mary emphasize her as a virgin-wife and virgin-mother. Helen Lopez’s “The Outsider Within: The Cultural Representation of Women in Selected Tagalog Novels of the 1920s” demonstrates how the Tagalog novel is especially susceptible to the workings of patriarchy because of its traditional twofold function: to “mirror” reality and to provide lessons in life. Lilia Quindoza-Santiago’s “The Filipina as Metaphor for Crisis” contends that the women characters of Jose Rizal, Amado Hernandez, and NickJoaquin are generally portrayed as weak, indecisive, and wretched. Thelma B. Kintanar’s “From Formalism to Feminism: Rereading Nick Joaquin’s The Woman Who Had Two Navels” demonstrates the difference between a formalist reading and a deconstructive feminist reading. The former emphasizes the unity of the text and portrays reality as timeless; the latter brings out ambiguities and contradictions in the text concealed by the apparent unity. Sylvia Mendez-Ventura’s “Sexism and the Mythification of Woman: A Feminist Reading of Nick Joaquin’s ‘The Summer Solstice’ and Alfred Yuson’s ‘The Hill of Samuel’” shows antifemale bias in two male writers’ use of myth. Although Joaquin’s use of fertility rites demonstrates woman’s recuperated power over man, he negates this by representing the triumphant woman as almost monstrous in the end. Yuson’s story, a version of the Dionysian myth, shows an aggressive male perpetrating violence on willing and submissive females.

Section 4, “Women Reading Women,” discusses the fate of women and women writers in a patriarchal society. Thelma Arambulo’s “The Filipina as Writer: Against All Odds” and Edna Z. Manlapaz and Stella Pagsanghan’s “A Feminist Reading of the Poetry of Angela Manalang Gloria” point to the marginalization and the silencing of women writers, their “critical invisibility,” but also their ability to assert themselves in the gaps and interstices of patriarchal discourse.  Written by Cynthia Lumbera

article_title: The Wounded Diamond: Studies in Modern Philippine Literature
text:
Published 1964. Author, Leonard Casper. Manila: Bookmark Inc.

This is a collection of Leonard Casper’s critical essays on Philippine literature. It includes studies on the English translation of Jose Rizal’s two novels.

Commenting on the fiction, poetry, or plays of 29 writers, Casper uses a formal-thematic approach, with characterization as his focus. He begins with the premise that the Filipino writer’s subject matter derives from social realities, but he evaluates the literary works according to New Critical standards of universality, “restraint and virile delicacy.” For example, he praises Manuel Arguilla’s stories for their compassionate but not propagandistic tone; N. V. M. Gonzalez’s fiction, not for its portrayal of class struggle but for the “fully beating heart, human awareness, and compassion” and its “severe formal restraint”; Nick Joaquin’s novel and play, not for their nostalgia for the Spanish tradition but for their “indirection and inner ironies.” On the other hand, he faults Estrella Alfon for the “formlessness” of some of her stories, calling them “uneven.” He decries Aida Rivera Ford’s “unexplained and, worse, unexplored” crisis in her stories.

Casper also discusses the works of Alberto S. Florentino, Carlos Bulosan, Alejandro Roces, Celso Carunungan, Juan Laya, Kerima Polotan-Tuvera, Jose Garcia Villa, Rafael Zulueta da Costa, Bienvenido Santos, Alejandrino Hufana, Francisco Arcellana, and Gregorio Brillantes.

Casper’s emphasis on form derives from the standards of New Criticism, a critical theory that was especially influential on both writers and critics in the 1950s and 1960s.  Written by David Jonathan Bayot and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Writers and Their Milieu: An Oral History of Second Generation Writers in English
text:
Volume 2 published 1987. Reprinted 1993.  Authors, Edilberto N. Alegre and Doreen G. Fernandez. With an introduction by Isagani R. Cruz. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

The books are the first two volumes of a planned five-volume oral history project that would cover Philippine writing in English from the 1920s to the 1980s.

The first book consists of separate interviews with 14 first-generation writers, who started writing in the 1920s and were the first products of the American public school system in the Philippines. Among them were Paz Marquez-Benitez, Jose Garcia Villa, Maria Luna-Lopez, Bienvenido Santos, Angela Manalang-Gloria, Arturo Rotor, Loreto Paras-Sulit, Salvador Lopez, Leopoldo Y. Yabes, and Fernando Leaño.

The interviews were so fashioned that the writers could share their conscious motives for selecting particular devices, materials, or situations that went into their work. The book shows that their favorite models were O. Henry, Guy de Maupassant, and Edgar Allan Poe. Heroes were Pollyanna, Hiawatha, and Horatio Alger. Vocabulary was a “plaything” and they were “drunk with words.” Here, too, popular legends about these writers are either finally confirmed or corrected.

All of the writers interviewed, except Villa, give credit to Paz Marquez-Benitez for inspiring them with her kindness and her bag of “tricks” to make them productive. It was an era of constant literary activity; there were writers’ clubs, editorial jobs, meetings at the Sulit store and the Arguilla basement. Lopez and Yabes are notable for their understanding of Philippine literature in English as well as its relations with society and the local traditions.

The second book focuses on 19 writers of the “second generation,” who began writing around the mid-1930s and into World War II. These writers include Armando Malay, E. Aguilar Cruz, Serafin Lanot, Renato Tayag, Nick Joaquin, Narciso Reyes, Manuel Viray, Ricaredo Demetillo, Dominador Ilio, Carlos Angeles, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, Rafael Zulueta da Costa, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, Sinai Hamada, Edith and Edilberto Tiempo, N. V. M.Gonzalez, and Francisco Arcellana. What marks them as the second generation is not merely chronology but more the influence, whether negative or positive, on them of the “first generation.”

The American writers whom they emulated were Erskine Caldwell, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and Thomas Wolfe; but they were also influenced by British writers and poets. A number, such as the Tiempos, Demetillo, Ilio, Arcellana, and Gonzalez, were trained under American writers and critics and brought home with them the tenets of New Criticism. It was this school of criticism that dominated both Philippine writing in English and literary criticism, through creative writing workshops at Silliman and the University of the Philippines.

Like the first, this second book settles manifold questions of literary history. The book provides biographical information, notes, sources and influences, and presents writing methods. These two books are valuable in the reconstruction of the historical period or the biographical context of the writers’ works.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and Victoria S. Calizo

The books are the first two volumes of a planned five-volume oral history project that would cover Philippine writing in English from the 1920s to the 1980s.

The first book consists of separate interviews with 14 first-generation writers, who started writing in the 1920s and were the first products of the American public school system in the Philippines. Among them were Paz Marquez-Benitez, Jose Garcia Villa, Maria Luna-Lopez, Bienvenido Santos, Angela Manalang-Gloria, Arturo Rotor, Loreto Paras-Sulit, Salvador Lopez, Leopoldo Y. Yabes, and Fernando Leaño.

The interviews were so fashioned that the writers could share their conscious motives for selecting particular devices, materials, or situations that went into their work. The book shows that their favorite models were O. Henry, Guy de Maupassant, and Edgar Allan Poe. Heroes were Pollyanna, Hiawatha, and Horatio Alger. Vocabulary was a “plaything” and they were “drunk with words.” Here, too, popular legends about these writers are either finally confirmed or corrected.

All of the writers interviewed, except Villa, give credit to Paz Marquez-Benitez for inspiring them with her kindness and her bag of “tricks” to make them productive. It was an era of constant literary activity; there were writers’ clubs, editorial jobs, meetings at the Sulit store and the Arguilla basement. Lopez and Yabes are notable for their understanding of Philippine literature in English as well as its relations with society and the local traditions.

The second book focuses on 19 writers of the “second generation,” who began writing around the mid-1930s and into World War II. These writers include Armando Malay, E. Aguilar Cruz, Serafin Lanot, Renato Tayag, Nick Joaquin, Narciso Reyes, Manuel Viray, Ricaredo Demetillo, Dominador Ilio, Carlos Angeles, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, Rafael Zulueta da Costa, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, Sinai Hamada, Edith and Edilberto Tiempo, N. V. M.Gonzalez, and Francisco Arcellana. What marks them as the second generation is not merely chronology but more the influence, whether negative or positive, on them of the “first generation.”

The American writers whom they emulated were Erskine Caldwell, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and Thomas Wolfe; but they were also influenced by British writers and poets. A number, such as the Tiempos, Demetillo, Ilio, Arcellana, and Gonzalez, were trained under American writers and critics and brought home with them the tenets of New Criticism. It was this school of criticism that dominated both Philippine writing in English and literary criticism, through creative writing workshops at Silliman and the University of the Philippines.

Like the first, this second book settles manifold questions of literary history. The book provides biographical information, notes, sources and influences, and presents writing methods. These two books are valuable in the reconstruction of the historical period or the biographical context of the writers’ works.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and Victoria S. Calizo

article_title: Writing the Nation/Pag-Akda ng Bansa
text:
Published 2000. Author, Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Composed of 61 reviews, conference papers, lectures, critical essays, and articles of varying length, the collection offers a spectrum of the issues around culture and nationalism. In this collection, the reader sees how Lumbera’s consciousness has been shaped by his own encounter with interlocking historical processes from the 1980s, the assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr being a crucial event, until the 1990s.

The book is divided into five sections. The first section, “Culture and Politics/Kultura at Politika,” provides the major perspective through which the rest of the essays could be viewed. The deep historical consciousness informs Lumbera’s discussion of the meaning of nationalist culture, the sources of tradition which continue to shape contemporary texts, the far-reaching and generally negative impact of American colonialism, and writing by Filipinos about the “land of milk and honey.”

Running through these essays in the first section is the full awareness that texts must be approached as the dynamic product of a complex series of sociopolitical processes that defined a specific historical period. Of special interest are the essays “After the Yellow Year: The Literary Scene since 21 August 1983,” where texts were contextualized against the fateful event of Aquino’s assassination, and “Ambushing the New Enemy: Artists and the Revolution of 1898,” where Lumbera shows various Filipino artists actively responding to the series of events precipitated by the Revolution of 1898.

The second section, “Language and Culture / Wika at Kultura,” pursues the thorny and polarizing issue of language where Filipino has remained the “other” of English. He also shows how Tagalog has resisted this imprisonment in various texts. In “Ang Pagpasok sa Lumang Kultura” (Upon Entering Old Culture), Lumbera shows how through the language, powerful symbols woven into the fabric of Tagalog texts could be made to resonate with the people’s deepest aspirations to be free. Of further interest, especially in light of the renewed interest in translation is “Pagsasalin tungo sa Panahong Tapos na ang Pagkabilanggo sa Wikang Ingles” (Translation toward Liberation from English).

Lumbera then focuses on the area where he first achieved critical acclaim in the 1970s as a pioneering critic of Tagalog poetry during the Spanish period. In the section “Literature/Panitikan,” the essay “Harnessing Regional Literature for National Literature” lays down the premises of a continuing debate on the distinction between “regional” and “national” literature. Lumbera writes that the hierarchy is rooted in colonial institutions, such as the American-style public school system, that privileged the colonial tongue. However, he ends with a contentious assertion that the categories “regional” and “national” should “be kept separate,” with the former depicting “specificities of life experienced and viewed with a narrower framework” and the latter “expressing larger concerns and broader perspectives.” A number of scholars and writers from outside Manila have since engaged this point of view.

The other issues in the literature section include the need to frame evaluative criticism against norms, traditional and modern; the continuing relevance of Amado V. Hernandez and the tradition of protest that his writing exemplifies; the production of texts, both primary and secondary, after EDSA, 1986-95, and the major issues involved; and the context of Philippine literature as a country in Southeast Asia.

In the fourth section, “Theatre/Teatro,” Lumbera discusses a genre he helped nurture with his own creative works as a playwright. He eulogizes a great artist in “Ka Atang: Honorata de la Rama, Artista ng Bayan” (Ka Atang: Honorata de la Rama, National Artist) and pays tribute to his friend and colleague Rolando Tinio in “Rolando S. Tinio: Artist of All Arts.”

As in the other essays, Lumbera valorizes theatrical productions where burning issues, such as patriotism and betrayal, exploitation and capital greed, among others, occupy center stage, and in the process, problematize taken-for-granted realities that the elite have successfully manufactured. Such reviews as “‘Pagsalunga’ by Sikat: Poignant Insights, Moving Performances” and “The Trial / Ang Paglilitis: Putting Bonifacio’s Enemies on Trial” eloquently reaffirm the duty of a critic committed to expose what lies beneath the surface.

The final section, “Film/Pelikula,” includes essays on the history of film, the stages in its evolution from entertainment to serious portraits of society, and the roles it must play in a fractious and violent society.

In a way a summation of Lumbera’s career as critic, Writing the Nation / Pag-akda ng Bansa reveals a critical voice that remains uncompromising and relentless in its systematic exposition and critique of texts from different genres. To read Lumbera’s essays is to open the reader’s mind to the complex working of a powerful intellect, always probing beneath the surface of whatever text needed to be analyzed and evaluated.   Written by Soledad Reyes
